original: iyam pitryā rāṣṭrī etu agre prathamāya januṣe bhuvaneṣṭhāḥ / tasmai etam su rucam hvāram ahyam gharmam śrīṇantu prathamāya dhāsyave /
analyzed: iyam pitryā rāṣṭrī etu agre prathamāya januṣe bhuvaneṣṭhāḥ   tasmai etam su rucam hvāram ahyam gharmam śrīṇantu prathamāya dhāsyave  /
translated: This is the ancestral, the royal, the first to be born, the ruler of the world. For him, for the first to be nourished, let them mix the bright, the shining, the hot milk.

original: pra yaḥ jajñe vidvān asya bandhuḥ viśvā devānām janimā vivakti / brahma brahmaṇaḥ ud jabhāra madhyāt nicais uccais svadhāḥ abhi pra tasthau /
analyzed: pra yaḥ jajñe vidvān asya bandhuḥ viśvā devānām janimā vivakti   brahma brahmaṇaḥ ud jabhāra madhyāt nicais uccais svadhāḥ abhi pra tasthau  /
translated: He who was born knowing, related to this, reveals the birth of all the gods. From the midst of Brahman, Brahman was lifted up. He has stood firm in his own power, low and high.

original: sa hi vidaḥ sa pṛthivyāḥ ṛta sthāḥ mahī kṣemam rodasī askabhāyat / mahān mahī askabhāyat vi jātaḥ dyām sadma pārthivam ca rajaḥ /
analyzed: sa hi vidaḥ sa pṛthivyāḥ ṛta sthāḥ mahī kṣemam rodasī askabhāyat   mahān mahī askabhāyat vi jātaḥ dyām sadma pārthivam ca rajaḥ  /
translated: He is the knower, the upholder of the earth's order. He has firmly established the two great worlds of safety. The great one has firmly established the heaven, the abode, and the earthly realm, when born.

original: sa bhudhnyāt āṣṭra januṣaḥ abhi agram bṛhaspatiḥ devatā tasya samrāj / ahar yat śukram jyotiṣaḥ janiṣṭa atha dyumantaḥ vi vasantu viprāḥ /
analyzed: sa bhudhnyāt āṣṭra januṣaḥ abhi agram bṛhaspatiḥ devatā tasya samrāj    ahar yat śukram jyotiṣaḥ janiṣṭa atha dyumantaḥ vi vasantu viprāḥ  /
translated: He, the son of Bhu, the firstborn, is the deity of that. Brhaspati is its overlord. When the bright light of the day was born, then let the radiant sages be spread out.

original: nūnam tat asya kāvyaḥ hinoti mahaḥ devasya pūrvyasya dhāma / eṣa jajñe bahubhiḥ sākam itthā pūrve ardhe viṣite sasan nu /
analyzed: nūnam tat asya kāvyaḥ hinoti mahaḥ devasya pūrvyasya dhāma    eṣa jajñe bahubhiḥ sākam itthā pūrve ardhe viṣite sasan nu  /
translated: Now indeed that Kavya praises his great, ancient abode of the god. He was born here together with many. In the former half of the divided (world), the former ones were born.

original: yaḥ atharvāṇam pitaram deva bandhum bṛhaspatim namasā ava ca gacchāt / tvam viśveṣām janitā yathā asaḥ kaviḥ devaḥ na dabhāyat svadhāvān /
analyzed: yaḥ atharvāṇam pitaram deva bandhum bṛhaspatim namasā ava ca gacchāt   tvam viśveṣām janitā yathā asaḥ kaviḥ devaḥ na dabhāyat svadhāvān  /
translated: Thou art the begetter of all things as thou art: the God, the Sage, hath not been deceived by his own nature.🔽He who giveth life, who giveth strength, in whose commandment all things live, whose are the Gods,

original: yaḥ ātma dāḥ bala dāḥ yasya viśve upāsate praśiṣam yasya devāḥ / yaḥ asya īśe dvipadaḥ yaḥ catuṣpadaḥ kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema /
analyzed: yaḥ ātma dāḥ bala dāḥ yasya viśve upāsate praśiṣam yasya devāḥ   yaḥ asya īśe dvipadaḥ yaḥ catuṣpadaḥ kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema  /
translated: Who is the Lord of this man and of this beast, to what God shall we offer with our oblation?

original: yaḥ prāṇataḥ nimiṣataḥ mahitvā ekaḥ rājā jagataḥ babhūva / yasya chāyā amṛtam yasya mṛtyuḥ kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema /
analyzed: yaḥ prāṇataḥ nimiṣataḥ mahitvā ekaḥ rājā jagataḥ babhūva   yasya chāyā amṛtam yasya mṛtyuḥ kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema  /
translated: Who, through his greatness, when he openeth and shutteth, hath become the sole King of the moving world,🔽Whom, when the two worlds, trembling, in fear and awe, call down to be the stay and prop of all things,

original: yam krandasī avataḥ caskabhāne bhiyasāne rodasī ahvayethām / yasya asau panthāḥ rajasaḥ vimānaḥ kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema /
analyzed: yam krandasī avataḥ caskabhāne bhiyasāne rodasī ahvayethām    yasya asau panthāḥ rajasaḥ vimānaḥ kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema  /
translated: Whose is this path, this measureless path through the region of the air, to what God shall we offer with our oblation?

original: yasya dyauḥ urvī pṛthivī ca mahī yasya adaḥ uru antarikṣam / yasya asau sūraḥ vitataḥ mahitvā kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema /
analyzed: yasya dyauḥ urvī pṛthivī ca mahī yasya adaḥ uru antarikṣam   yasya asau sūraḥ vitataḥ mahitvā kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema  /
translated: Whose is this broad and mighty earth, and this wide firmament, and this sun spread out in his greatness, to what God shall we offer with our oblation?

original: yasya viśve himavantaḥ mahitvā samudre yasya rasām id āhuḥ / imāḥ ca pradiśaḥ yasya bāhū kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema /
analyzed: yasya viśve himavantaḥ mahitvā samudre yasya rasām id āhuḥ    imāḥ ca pradiśaḥ yasya bāhū kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema  /
translated: To whom all the mountains are subject by his greatness, and the ocean, whose salt waters they call his,🔽And whose arms are these regions of the world, to what God shall we offer with oblation?

original: āpaḥ agre viśvam āvan garbham dadhānāḥ amṛtāḥ ṛta jñāḥ / yāsu devīṣu adhi devaḥ āsīt kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema /🔽hiraṇya garbhaḥ sam avartata agre bhūtasya jātaḥ patiḥ ekaḥ āsīt / sa dādhāra pṛthivīm uta dyām kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema /
analyzed: āpaḥ agre viśvam āvan garbham dadhānāḥ amṛtāḥ ṛta jñāḥ   yāsu devīṣu adhi devaḥ āsīt kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema  / hiraṇya garbhaḥ sam avartata agre bhūtasya jātaḥ patiḥ ekaḥ āsīt   sa dādhāra pṛthivīm uta dyām kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema  /
translated: The waters, in the beginning, all-sustaining, bearing the germ, immortal, knowing truth,🔽In whom the God was seated, to what God shall we offer with oblation?🔽The golden germ was first produced, the only Lord of what hath been. He hath supported earth and heaven. To what God shall we offer with oblation?

original: āpaḥ vatsam janayantīḥ garbham agre sam airayan / tasya uta jāyamānasya ulbaḥ āsīt hiraṇyayaḥ kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema /
analyzed: āpaḥ vatsam janayantīḥ garbham agre sam airayan    tasya uta jāyamānasya ulbaḥ āsīt hiraṇyayaḥ kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema  /
translated: The waters, bringing forth the calf, the germ, in the beginning, have sent forth. Of him, as he was born, the caul was of gold. To what God shall we offer with oblation?

original: ud itas trayaḥ akraman vyāghraḥ puruṣaḥ vṛkaḥ / hiruk ghi yanti sindhavaḥ hiruk devaḥ vanaspatiḥ hiruk namantu śatravaḥ /
analyzed: ud itas trayaḥ akraman vyāghraḥ puruṣaḥ vṛkaḥ    hiruk ghi yanti sindhavaḥ hiruk devaḥ vanaspatiḥ hiruk namantu śatravaḥ  /
translated: Three have gone forth from hence, the tiger, the man, the wolf. The rivers flow on in haste. The God, the tree, flows on in haste. Let our enemies flow on in haste.

original: pareṇa etu pathā vṛkaḥ parameṇa uta taskaraḥ / pareṇa datvatī rajjuḥ pareṇa aghāyuḥ arṣatu /
analyzed: pareṇa etu pathā vṛkaḥ parameṇa uta taskaraḥ   pareṇa datvatī rajjuḥ pareṇa aghāyuḥ arṣatu  /
translated: Let the wolf go away by the farthest path, and the thief by the most remote. Let the rope that binds the thief go away by the farthest, and let the sinner go away by the most remote.

original: akṣyau ca te mukham ca te vyāghra jambhayāmasi / āt sarvān viṃśatim nakhān /
analyzed: akṣyau ca te mukham ca te vyāghra jambhayāmasi   āt sarvān viṃśatim nakhān
translated: We crush thy eyes and crush thy mouth, O tiger. We crush all thy twenty claws.

original: vyāghram datvatām vayam prathamam jambhayāmasi / āt u stenam atha u ahim yātudhānam atha u vṛkam /
analyzed: vyāghram datvatām vayam prathamam jambhayāmasi   āt u stenam atha u ahim yātudhānam atha u vṛkam  /
translated: The tiger, first of all the fierce, we crush to pieces. Then the thief, then the snake, then the demon, then the wolf.

original: yaḥ adya stenaḥ āyati sa saṃpiṣṭaḥ apāyati / pathām apadhvaṃsena etu indraḥ vajreṇa hantu tam /
analyzed: yaḥ adya stenaḥ āyati sa saṃpiṣṭaḥ apāyati    pathām apadhvaṃsena etu indraḥ vajreṇa hantu tam  /
translated: The thief who comes to-day, he is crushed as he goes away. Let him go by the way that is trodden by the wicked. Let Indra with his thunderbolt slay him.

original: mūrṇāḥ mṛgasya dantāḥ apiśīrṇāḥ u pṛṣṭayaḥ / nimruc te godhā bhavatu nīcāyat śaśayuḥ mṛgaḥ /
analyzed: mūrṇāḥ mṛgasya dantāḥ apiśīrṇāḥ u pṛṣṭayaḥ   nimruc te godhā bhavatu nīcāyat śaśayuḥ mṛgaḥ  /
translated: The teeth of the beast are broken, his shoulders are crushed to pieces. Let thy jaw, O beast, be broken. Let the hare go low before the tiger.

original: yat saṃyamaḥ na vi yamaḥ vi yamaḥ yat na saṃyamaḥ / indra jāḥ soma jāḥ ātharvaṇam asi vyāghra jambhanam //
analyzed: yat saṃyamaḥ na vi yamaḥ vi yamaḥ yat na saṃyamaḥ   indra jāḥ soma jāḥ ātharvaṇam asi vyāghra jambhanam  /
translated: What is bound together and what is not bound, what is not bound and what is bound together, O Indra, O Soma, thou art the son of Atharvan, the crusher of tigers.

original: yām tvā gandharvaḥ akhanat varuṇāya mṛtabhraje / tām tvā vayam khanāmasi oṣadhim śepaharṣaṇīm /
analyzed: yām tvā gandharvaḥ akhanat varuṇāya mṛtabhraje    tām tvā vayam khanāmasi oṣadhim śepaharṣaṇīm  /
translated: The plant which the Gandharva dug for Varuna when he was victorious in the battle, that plant we dig up for thee, O beast, to make thy hair stand on end.

original: ud uṣāḥ ud u sūryaḥ ud idam māmakam vacaḥ / ud ejatu prajāpatiḥ vṛṣā śuṣmeṇa vājinā /
analyzed: ud uṣāḥ ud u sūryaḥ ud idam māmakam vacaḥ   ud ejatu prajāpatiḥ vṛṣā śuṣmeṇa vājinā  /
translated: Up the Dawn, up the Sun, up this my word. Up let Prajapati rise, the strong one with his mighty power.

original: yathā sma te virohataḥ abhitaptam iva anati / tatas te śuṣmavattaram iyam kṛṇotu oṣadhiḥ /
analyzed: yathā sma te virohataḥ abhitaptam iva anati   tatas te śuṣmavattaram iyam kṛṇotu oṣadhiḥ
translated: As they grow up, as if scorched by the sun, let this plant make you stronger still.

original: ud śuṣmā oṣadhīnām sārāḥ ṛṣabhāṇām / sam puṃsām indra vṛṣṇyam asmin dhehi tanū vaśin /
analyzed: ud śuṣmāḥ oṣadhīnām sārāḥ ṛṣabhāṇām    sam puṃsām indra vṛṣṇyam asmin dhehi tanū vaśin  /
translated: The strength of plants, the sap of the bulls, and the vigour of men, O Indra, the powerful one, bestow on him.

original: apām rasaḥ prathama jaḥ atha u vanaspatīnām / uta somasya bhrātā asi uta arśam asi vṛṣṇyam /
analyzed: apām rasaḥ prathama jaḥ atha u vanaspatīnām      / uta somasya bhrātā asi uta arśam asi vṛṣṇyam  /
translated: The essence of the waters, the first-born, and the sap of the trees, you are the brother of Soma, and you are the vigour of the bull.

original: adya agne adya savitar adya devi sarasvati / adya asya brahmaṇaḥ pate dhanuḥ iva ā tānaya pasaḥ /
analyzed: adya agne adya savitar adya devi sarasvati      adya asya brahmaṇaḥ pate dhanuḥ iva ā tānaya pasaḥ  /
translated: Today, O Agni, today, O Savitar, today, O goddess Sarasvati, today, O Brahmaṇaspati, draw his disease like a bowstring.

original: ā aham tanomi te pasaḥ adhi jyām iva dhanvani / kramasva rśaḥ iva rohitam an avaglāyatā sadā /
analyzed: ā aham tanomi te pasaḥ adhi jyām iva dhanvani   kramasva rśaḥ iva rohitam an avaglāyatā sadā  /
translated: I draw your disease out of you, as if it were a bowstring from the bow. Go, O disease, like a red horse, never to return.

original: aśvasya aśvatarasya ajasya petvasya ca / atha ṛṣabhasya ye vājāḥ tān asmin dhehi tanū vaśin //
analyzed: aśvasya aśvatarasya ajasya petvasya ca    atha ṛṣabhasya ye vājāḥ tān asmin dhehi tanū vaśin
translated: The strength of the horse, the mule, the goat, and the ram, and also the bull, O powerful one, bestow those on him.

original: sahasra śṛṅgaḥ vṛṣabhaḥ yaḥ samudrāt udācarat / tena sahasyena vayam ni janān svāpayāmasi //
analyzed: sahasra śṛṅgaḥ vṛṣabhaḥ yaḥ samudrāt udācarat   tena sahasyena vayam ni janān svāpayāmasi  /
translated: The thousand-horned bull who rises from the ocean, with that invincible one we cause the people to fall asleep.

original: na bhūmim vātaḥ ati vāti na ati paśyati kaś cana / striyaḥ ca sarvāḥ svāpaya śunaḥ ca indra sakhā caran /
analyzed: na bhūmim vātaḥ ati vāti na ati paśyati kaś cana    striyaḥ ca sarvāḥ svāpaya śunaḥ ca indra sakhā caran  /
translated: The wind blows not too strongly, nor does any one look too closely. Put all the women to sleep, and the dogs, O Indra, as thou goest about with thy friend.

original: proṣṭheśayāḥ talpeśayāḥ nārīḥ yāḥ vahya śīvarīḥ / striyaḥ yāḥ puṇya gandhayaḥ tāḥ sarvāḥ svāpayāmasi //
analyzed: proṣṭheśayāḥ talpeśayāḥ nārīḥ yāḥ vahya śīvarīḥ   striyaḥ yāḥ puṇya gandhayaḥ tāḥ sarvāḥ svāpayāmasi  /
translated: Those women who lie on the ground, on the floor, or in the open air, those women who are fragrant with virtue, all of them we put to sleep.

original: ejat ejat ajagrabham cakṣuḥ prāṇam ajagrabham / aṅgāni ajagrabham sarvā rātrīṇām atiśarvare /
analyzed: ejat ejat ajagrabham cakṣuḥ prāṇam ajagrabham    aṅgāni ajagrabham sarvā rātrīṇām atiśarvare
translated: I have seized the moving, I have seized the eye, I have seized the breath. I have seized all the limbs, in the exceeding cold of the nights.

original: yaḥ āste yaḥ carati yaḥ ca tiṣṭhan vipaśyati / teṣām sam dadhmaḥ akṣīṇi yathā idam harmyam tathā /
analyzed: yaḥ āste yaḥ carati yaḥ ca tiṣṭhan vipaśyati   teṣām sam dadhmaḥ akṣīṇi yathā idam harmyam tathā  /
translated: He who sits, he who moves about, he who stands and looks around, their eyes we join together, as this house is joined.

original: svaptu mātā svaptu pitā svaptu śvā svaptu viśpatiḥ / svapantu asyai jñātayaḥ svaptu ayam abhitas janaḥ /
analyzed: svaptu mātā svaptu pitā svaptu śvā svaptu viśpatiḥ   svapantu asyai jñātayaḥ svaptu ayam abhitas janaḥ  /
translated: Let the mother sleep, let the father sleep, let the dog sleep, let the master of the house sleep. Let his kinsmen sleep, let the people around him sleep.

original: svapna svapna abhikaraṇena sarvam ni svāpaya janam / otsūryam anyān svāpaya avyuṣam jāgṛtāt aham indraḥ iva ariṣṭaḥ akṣitaḥ /
analyzed: svapna svapna abhikaraṇena sarvam ni svāpaya janam    otsūryam anyān svāpaya avyuṣam jāgṛtāt aham indraḥ iva ariṣṭaḥ akṣitaḥ  /
translated: O Sleep, O Sleep, with thy instrument put all the people to sleep. Put the others to sleep beyond the sun, and let me alone be awake, like Indra, unharmed and undecayed.

original: brāhmaṇaḥ jajñe prathamaḥ daśa śīrṣaḥ daśa āsyaḥ / sa somam prathamaḥ papau sa cakāra arasam viṣam /
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ jajñe prathamaḥ daśa śīrṣaḥ daśa āsyaḥ   sa somam prathamaḥ papau sa cakāra arasam viṣam  /
translated: The Brahman first was born, ten-headed, ten-faced. He first drank Soma, and made poison powerless.

original: yāvatī dyāvāpṛthivī varimṇā yāvat sapta sindhavaḥ vitaṣṭhire / vācam viṣasya dūṣaṇīm tām itas niḥ avādiṣam /
analyzed: yāvatī dyāvāpṛthivī varimṇā yāvat sapta sindhavaḥ vitaṣṭhire   vācam viṣasya dūṣaṇīm tām itas niḥ avādiṣam  /
translated: As far as heaven and earth extend in compass, as far as the seven rivers have extended, I have pronounced against this poison the curse of speech.

original: suparṇaḥ tvā garutmān viṣa prathamam āvayat / na amīmadaḥ na ārūrupaḥ uta asmai abhavaḥ pituḥ /
analyzed: suparṇaḥ tvā garutmān viṣa prathamam āvayat   na amīmadaḥ na ārūrupaḥ uta asmai abhavaḥ pituḥ  /
translated: The bird of fair feathers, Garutman, first brought thee, O poison. Thou hast not maddened him, nor hast thou mounted up to him, but hast become his father.

original: yaḥ te āsyat pañca aṅguriḥ vakrāt cit adhi dhanvanaḥ / apaskambhasya śalyāt niḥ avocam aham viṣam /
analyzed: yaḥ te āsyat pañca aṅguriḥ vakrāt cit adhi dhanvanaḥ   apaskambhasya śalyāt niḥ avocam aham viṣam  /
translated: I have extracted the poison from the five-clawed one who hath pierced thee, even from the crooked bow, from the shaft of the tree without pith.

original: śalyāt viṣam niḥ avocam prāñjanāt uta parṇadheḥ / apāṣṭhāt śṛṅgāt kulmalāt niḥ avocam aham viṣam /
analyzed: śalyāt viṣam niḥ avocam prāñjanāt uta parṇadheḥ   apāṣṭhāt śṛṅgāt kulmalāt niḥ avocam aham viṣam  /
translated: I have extracted the poison from the shaft, from the saw, from the leaf-cutter, from the stump, from the horn, from the splinter.

original: arasaḥ te iṣaḥ śalyaḥ atho te arasam viṣam / uta arasasya vṛkṣasya dhanuḥ te arasa arasam /
analyzed: arasaḥ te iṣaḥ śalyaḥ atho te arasam viṣam    uta arasasya vṛkṣasya dhanuḥ te arasa arasam  /
translated: Thy arrow is without strength, and thy poison is without strength. And the bow of the tree without strength is without strength.

original: ye apīṣan ye adihan ye āsyan ye avāsṛjan / sarve te vadhrayaḥ kṛtāḥ vadhriḥ viṣa giriḥ kṛtaḥ /
analyzed: ye apīṣan ye adihan ye āsyan ye avāsṛjan     sarve te vadhrayaḥ kṛtāḥ vadhriḥ viṣa giriḥ kṛtaḥ  /
translated: They who have ground, they who have rubbed, they who have chewed, they who have cast forth, all have become impotent; the impotent one hath been made the poison-bearing mountain.

original: vadhrayaḥ te khanitāraḥ vadhriḥ tvam asi oṣadhe / vadhriḥ sa parvataḥ giriḥ yatas jātam idam viṣam /
analyzed: vadhrayaḥ te khanitāraḥ vadhriḥ tvam asi oṣadhe   vadhriḥ sa parvataḥ giriḥ yatas jātam idam viṣam  /
translated: Thy diggers are the lame, and thou art lame, O Plant. Lame is the mountain-peak whence this poison hath sprung.

original: vār idam vārayātai varaṇāvatyām adhi / tatra amṛtasya āsiktam tena te vāraye viṣam /
analyzed: vār idam vārayātai varaṇāvatyām adhi   / tatra amṛtasya āsiktam tena te vāraye viṣam  /
translated: This water shall repel the water. In Varana's abode. There hath the nectar been poured out. Therewith I drive thy poison hence.

original: arasam prācyam viṣam arasam yat udīcyam / atha idam adharācyam karambheṇa vi kalpate /
analyzed: arasam prācyam viṣam arasam yat udīcyam     atha idam adharācyam karambheṇa vi kalpate  /
translated: The poison that is in the east is powerless, and that which is in the north is powerless. But this that is in the south is mixed with the Karambha.

original: karambham kṛtvā tiryam pībaspākam udārathim / kṣudhā kila tvā duṣṭano jakṣivān sa na rūrupaḥ /
analyzed: karambham kṛtvā tiryam pībaspākam udārathim    kṣudhā kila tvā duṣṭano jakṣivān sa na rūrupaḥ  /
translated: Having made the Karambha thy equal, drink the Pīpaspāka, O thou with the swift car. Thou hast been eaten, O Rūrupa, by hunger, and thou hast not been digested.

original: vi te madam madāvati śaram iva pātayāmasi / pra tvā carum iva yeṣantam vacasā sthāpayāmasi //
analyzed: vi te madam madāvati śaram iva pātayāmasi   pra tvā carum iva yeṣantam vacasā sthāpayāmasi  /
translated: We make thy madness fall like an arrow, O thou who madest mad. We make thee stay, as 'twere a chariot, with a will to go, with this our hymn.

original: pari grāmam iva ācitam vacasā sthāpayāmasi / tiṣṭha vṛkṣe iva sthāmni abhri khāte na rūrupaḥ /
analyzed: pari grāmam iva ācitam vacasā sthāpayāmasi   tiṣṭha vṛkṣe iva sthāmni abhri khāte na rūrupaḥ  /
translated: We make thee stay, as 'twere a village, with a will to go, with this our hymn. Stay, as it were, in a firm place, in the trench dug by the spade, O Rūrupa.

original: pavastaiḥ tvā pari akrīṇan dūrśebhiḥ ajinaiḥ uta / prakrīḥ asi tvam oṣadhe abhri khāte na rūrupaḥ /
analyzed: pavastaiḥ tvā pari akrīṇan dūrśebhiḥ ajinaiḥ uta   prakrīḥ asi tvam oṣadhe abhri khāte na rūrupaḥ  /
translated: They have bought thee round with girdles, with rugs and skins of beasts. Thou art a purchase, O thou Plant. Stay, as it were, in a trench dug by the spade, O Rūrupa.

original: an āptāḥ ye vaḥ prathamāḥ yāni karmāṇi cakrire / vīrān naḥ atra mā dabhan tat vaḥ etat puras dadhe /
analyzed: an āptāḥ ye vaḥ prathamāḥ yāni karmāṇi cakrire   vīrān naḥ atra mā dabhan tat vaḥ etat puras dadhe  /
translated: Those who are not trusted, who have performed the first rites, may they not deceive us here, O heroes. I place this before you.

original: bhūtaḥ bhūteṣu payaḥ ā dadhāti sa bhūtānām adhipatiḥ babhūva / tasya mṛtyuḥ carati rājasūyam sa rājā anu manyatām idam /
analyzed: bhūtaḥ bhūteṣu payaḥ ā dadhāti sa bhūtānām adhipatiḥ babhūva   tasya mṛtyuḥ carati rājasūyam sa rājā anu manyatām idam  /
translated: He places the milk in the beings. He became the lord of beings. His death moves around the Rajasuya. May that king approve of this.

original: abhi prehi mā apa venaḥ ugraḥ cettā sapatna hā / ā tiṣṭha mitra vardhana tubhyam devāḥ adhi bruvan //
analyzed: abhi prehi mā apa venaḥ ugraḥ cettā sapatna hā    ā tiṣṭha mitra vardhana tubhyam devāḥ adhi bruvan
translated: Go forward, do not turn back. The fierce one is the punisher, the destroyer of enemies. Stand here, the increaser of friends. The gods speak to you.

original: ātiṣṭhantam pari viśve abhūṣam śriyam vasānaḥ carati sva rociḥ / mahat tat vṛṣṇaḥ asurasya nāma ā viśva rūpaḥ amṛtāni tasthau //
analyzed: ātiṣṭhantam pari viśve abhūṣam śriyam vasānaḥ carati sva rociḥ   mahat tat vṛṣṇaḥ asurasya nāma ā viśva rūpaḥ amṛtāni tasthau  /
translated: I have surrounded him who stands near. He moves, clothed in glory, shining of himself. That is the great name of the strong Asura. He stands in the immortal forms of all.

original: vyāghraḥ adhi vaiyāghre vi kramasva diśaḥ mahīḥ / viśaḥ tvā sarvāḥ vāñchantu āpaḥ divyāḥ payasvatīḥ /
analyzed: vyāghraḥ adhi vaiyāghre vi kramasva diśaḥ mahīḥ   viśaḥ tvā sarvāḥ vāñchantu āpaḥ divyāḥ payasvatīḥ  /
translated: The tiger in the tiger-skin, spread out in the great directions. May all the people long for you. The heavenly waters full of milk.

original: yāḥ āpaḥ divyāḥ payasā madanti antarikṣe uta vā pṛthivyām / tāsām tvā sarvāsām apām abhi siñcāmi varcasā /
analyzed: yāḥ āpaḥ divyāḥ payasā madanti antarikṣe uta vā pṛthivyām   tāsām tvā sarvāsām apām abhi siñcāmi varcasā  /
translated: Those waters which rejoice in the milk of heaven, or in the atmosphere, or on the earth, of all those waters I sprinkle you with their radiance.

original: abhi tvā varcasā asican āpaḥ divyāḥ payasvatīḥ / yathā asaḥ mitra vardhanaḥ tathā tvā savitā karat /
analyzed: abhi tvā varcasā asican āpaḥ divyāḥ payasvatīḥ   yathā asaḥ mitra vardhanaḥ tathā tvā savitā karat  /
translated: The heavenly waters rich in milk have sprinkled thee with their effulgence. As thou art, O Mitra-Vardhana, so may Savitar make thee.

original: enā vyāghram pariṣasvajānāḥ siṃham hinvanti mahate saubhagāya / samudram na su bhuvaḥ tasthivāṃsam marmṛjyante dvīpinam apsu antar /
analyzed: enā vyāghram pariṣasvajānāḥ siṃham hinvanti mahate saubhagāya   samudram na su bhuvaḥ tasthivāṃsam marmṛjyante dvīpinam apsu antar  /
translated: They who have girt about the tiger, urge the lion on to great good fortune. They deck the well-disposed one like the ocean, the island-born, in the midst of the waters.

original: ehi jīvam trāyamāṇam parvatasya asi akṣyam / viśvebhiḥ devaiḥ dattam paridhiḥ jīvanāya kam /
analyzed: ehi jīvam trāyamāṇam parvatasya asi akṣyam   viśvebhiḥ devaiḥ dattam paridhiḥ jīvanāya kam  /
translated: Come hither, thou art the life-giving, the eye of the mountain. Given by all the Gods, a fence to give life to some one.

original: paripāṇam puruṣāṇām paripāṇam gavām asi / aśvānām arvatām paripāṇāya tasthiṣe /
analyzed: paripāṇam puruṣāṇām paripāṇam gavām asi    aśvānām arvatām paripāṇāya tasthiṣe  /
translated: Thou art the guard of men, thou art the guard of kine. Thou standest as a guard for horses and for steeds.

original: uta asi paripāṇam yātu jambhanam āñjana / uta amṛtasya tvam vettha atho asi jīva bhojanam atho harita bheṣajam /
analyzed: uta asi paripāṇam yātu jambhanam āñjana   uta amṛtasya tvam vettha atho asi jīva bhojanam atho harita bheṣajam  /
translated: And thou art the guard that slayest the Yātu, the ointment. And thou knowest the immortal, and art the food of life, and the healing herb.

original: yasya añjana prasarpasi aṅgam aṅgam paruḥ paruḥ / tatas yakṣmam vi bādhase ugraḥ madhyamaśīḥ iva /
analyzed: yasya añjana prasarpasi aṅgam aṅgam paruḥ paruḥ   tatas yakṣmam vi bādhase ugraḥ madhyamaśīḥ iva  /
translated: On whatever limb of thine the ointment is spread, on every limb, on every joint, Thence thou drivest away disease, like a fierce creditor.

original: na enam prāpnoti śapathaḥ na kṛtyā na abhiśocanam / na enam viṣkandham aśnute yaḥ tvā bibharti āñjana //
analyzed: na enam prāpnoti śapathaḥ na kṛtyā na abhiśocanam   na enam viṣkandham aśnute yaḥ tvā bibharti āñjana  /
translated: No curse, no spell, no sorrow ever reaches him, No evil-working malady attacks him, who wears thee, O ointment, on his body.

original: asat mantrāt duṣvapnyāt duṣkṛtāt śamalāt uta / durhārdaḥ cakṣuṣaḥ ghorāt tasmāt naḥ pāhi āñjana /
analyzed: asat mantrāt duṣvapnyāt duṣkṛtāt śamalāt uta     cakṣuṣaḥ ghorāt tasmāt naḥ pāhi āñjana
translated: From evil counsel, from a dream of evil, from evil deed and trouble, and from sorrow, From the fierce eye of him who hates, O ointment, from all these keep thou us in safety.

original: idam vidvān āñjana satyam vakṣyāmi na anṛtam / saneyam aśvam gām aham ātmānam tava pūruṣa /
analyzed: idam vidvān āñjana satyam vakṣyāmi na anṛtam   saneyam aśvam gām aham ātmānam tava pūruṣa  /
translated: O ointment, knowing this, I will speak truth, and not untruth. I will win horse and cow and myself, O man, for thee.

original: trayaḥ dāsāḥ āñjanasya takmā balāsaḥ āt ahiḥ / varṣiṣṭhaḥ parvatānām trikakud nāma te pitā /
analyzed: trayaḥ dāsāḥ āñjanasya takmā balāsaḥ āt ahiḥ    varṣiṣṭhaḥ parvatānām trikakud nāma te pitā  /
translated: Three are the slaves of ointment, fever, consumption, and the serpent. The highest of the mountains, Trikakud is thy father by name.

original: yat āñjanam traikakudam jātam himavataḥ pari / yātūn ca sarvān jambhayat sarvāḥ ca yātudhānyaḥ /
analyzed: yat āñjanam traikakudam jātam himavataḥ pari   yātūn ca sarvān jambhayat sarvāḥ ca yātudhānyaḥ  /
translated: The ointment that is born around the Himavat, the Trikakud, Destroy all the demons and all the female demons.

original: yadi vā asi traikakudam yadi yāmunam ucyase / ubhe te bhadre nāmnī tābhyām naḥ pāhi āñjana //
analyzed: yadi vā asi traikakudam yadi yāmunam ucyase    ubhe te bhadre nāmnī tābhyām naḥ pāhi āñjana  /
translated: If thou art the Trikakud, if thou art called the Yamuna, Both thy names are good. O ointment, save us by both of them.

original: vātāt jātaḥ antarikṣāt vidyutaḥ jyotiṣaḥ pari / sa naḥ hiraṇya jāḥ śaṅkhaḥ kṛśanaḥ pātu aṃhasaḥ /
analyzed: vātāt jātaḥ antarikṣāt vidyutaḥ jyotiṣaḥ pari   sa naḥ hiraṇya jāḥ śaṅkhaḥ kṛśanaḥ pātu aṃhasaḥ  /
translated: Born from the wind, from the atmosphere, from the lightning, from the light, May the conch-shell, born of gold, the spotted one, protect us from distress.

original: yaḥ agratas rocanānām samudrāt adhi jajñiṣe / śaṅkhena hatvā rakṣāṃsi attriṇaḥ vi sahāmahe /
analyzed: yaḥ agratas rocanānām samudrāt adhi jajñiṣe   / śaṅkhena hatvā rakṣāṃsi attriṇaḥ vi sahāmahe  /
translated: Thou who wast born above the luminous regions, from out the ocean, with the conch-shell, slaying the Rakshas, the devourers, we will conquer.

original: śaṅkhena amīvām amatim śaṅkhena uta sadānvāḥ / śaṅkhaḥ naḥ viśva bheṣajaḥ kṛśanaḥ pātu aṃhasaḥ /🔽divi jātaḥ samudra jaḥ sindhutas pari ābhṛtaḥ / sa naḥ hiraṇya jāḥ śaṅkhaḥ āyuṣprataraṇaḥ maṇiḥ /
analyzed: śaṅkhena amīvām amatim śaṅkhena uta sadānvāḥ   śaṅkhaḥ naḥ viśva bheṣajaḥ kṛśanaḥ pātu aṃhasaḥ  / divi jātaḥ samudra jaḥ sindhutas pari ābhṛtaḥ   sa naḥ hiraṇya jāḥ śaṅkhaḥ āyuṣprataraṇaḥ maṇiḥ  /
translated: With the conch-shell we conquer evil, and the disease that wastes the body, and the deadly fever. May the conch-shell, the universal remedy, protect us from distress.🔽Born in the sky, born in the ocean, brought hither from the river, may that shell, born of gold, the amulet that lengthens life, protect us.

original: samudrāt jātaḥ maṇiḥ vṛtrāt jātaḥ divākaraḥ / saḥ asmān sarvatas pātu hetyāḥ deva asurebhyaḥ /
analyzed: samudrāt jātaḥ maṇiḥ vṛtrāt jātaḥ divākaraḥ   saḥ asmān sarvatas pātu hetyāḥ deva asurebhyaḥ  /
translated: The amulet is born from the ocean, born from the cloud, born from the sun. May it protect us on every side from the curse, O God, from the Asuras.

original: hiraṇyānām ekaḥ asi somāt tvam adhi jajñiṣe / rathe tvam asi darśataḥ iṣudhau rocanaḥ tvam pra naḥ āyūṃṣi tāriṣat /
analyzed: hiraṇyānām ekaḥ asi somāt tvam adhi jajñiṣe   rathe tvam asi darśataḥ iṣudhau rocanaḥ tvam pra naḥ āyūṃṣi tāriṣat  /
translated: Thou art the one of all the golden ones. From Soma art thou generated. On the car thou art the beautiful one. In the quiver thou art the shining one. May the shell prolong our lives.

original: devānām asthi kṛśanam babhūva tat ātmanvat carati apsu antar / tat te badhnāmi āyuṣe varcase balāya dīrgha āyu tvāya śata śāradāya kārśanaḥ tvā abhi rakṣatu //
analyzed: devānām asthi kṛśanam babhūva tat ātmanvat carati apsu antar   tat te badhnāmi āyuṣe varcase balāya dīrgha āyu tvāya śata śāradāya kārśanaḥ tvā abhi rakṣatu  /
translated: The bone of the gods became the shell. It moves with life within the waters. I bind it on thee for life, for splendour, for strength, for long life, for a hundred years. Let the shell protect thee.

original: anaḍvān dādhāra pṛthivīm uta dyām anaḍvān dādhāra uru antarikṣam / anaḍvān dādhāra pradiśaḥ ṣaṭ urvīḥ anaḍvān viśvam bhuvanam ā viveśa /
analyzed: anaḍvān dādhāra pṛthivīm uta dyām anaḍvān dādhāra uru antarikṣam   anaḍvān dādhāra pradiśaḥ ṣaḍ urvīḥ anaḍvān viśvam bhuvanam ā viveśa  /
translated: The ox supports the earth and the sky. The ox supports the wide air. The ox supports the six broad regions. The ox hath entered every world.

original: anaḍvān indraḥ sa paśubhyaḥ vi caṣṭe trayām śakraḥ vi mimīte adhvanaḥ / bhūtam bhaviṣyat bhuvanā duhānaḥ sarvā devānām carati vratāni //
analyzed: anaḍvān indraḥ sa paśubhyaḥ vi caṣṭe trayām śakraḥ vi mimīte adhvanaḥ   bhūtam bhaviṣyat bhuvanā duhānaḥ sarvā devānām carati vratāni  /
translated: Indra, the ox, hath looked upon the cattle. Shakra, the ox, hath measured out the three ways. Milking the worlds that have been and that are to be, he goeth through all the rites of the gods.

original: indraḥ jātaḥ manuṣyeṣu antar gharmaḥ taptaḥ carati śośucānaḥ / su prajāḥ san saḥ udāre na sarṣat yaḥ na aśnīyāt anaḍuhaḥ vijānan /
analyzed: indraḥ jātaḥ manuṣyeṣu antar gharmaḥ taptaḥ carati śośucānaḥ   su prajāḥ san saḥ udāre na sarṣat yaḥ na aśnīyāt anaḍuhaḥ vijānan  /
translated: Indra, the ox, hath been born among mankind. The heated caldron moveth on, shining. Let him not, being well-born, perish in a narrow place, who, knowing, should not eat of the ox.

original: anaḍvān duhe su kṛtasya loke ā enam pyāyayati pavamānaḥ purastāt / parjanyaḥ dhārāḥ marutaḥ ūdhar asya yajñaḥ payaḥ dakṣiṇā dohaḥ asya /
analyzed: anaḍvān duhe su kṛtasya loke ā enam pyāyayati pavamānaḥ purastāt   parjanyaḥ dhārāḥ marutaḥ ūdhar asya yajñaḥ payaḥ dakṣiṇā dohaḥ asya  /
translated: The ox milketh in the world of good works. The purifying one maketh him to swell in front. Parjanya is the udder of his streams. The sacrifice is his milk. The sacrificial fee is his milking.

original: yasya naḥ īśe yajñapatiḥ na yajñaḥ na asya dātā īśe na pratigrahītā / yaḥ viśvajit viśvabhṛt viśvakarmā gharmam naḥ brūta yatamaḥ catuṣpād /
analyzed: yasya naḥ īśe yajñapatiḥ na yajñaḥ na asya dātā īśe na pratigrahītā   yaḥ viśvajit viśvabhṛt viśvakarmā gharmam naḥ brūta yatamaḥ catuṣpād  /
translated: He whose lord of sacrifice is not lord of sacrifice, nor his giver lord, nor he who receiveth, he who is all-conquering, all-supporting, all-creating, tell us, O caldron, which of the four-footed is he?

original: yena devāḥ svar āruruhuḥ hitvā śarīram amṛtasya nābhim / tena geṣma su kṛtasya lokam gharmasya vratena tapasā yaśasyavaḥ //
analyzed: yena devāḥ svar āruruhuḥ hitvā śarīram amṛtasya nābhim    tena geṣma su kṛtasya lokam gharmasya vratena tapasā yaśasyavaḥ  /
translated: By that we go to the world of the virtuous, by the vow of the Gharma, by penance, by fame.🔽Indra by form, Agni by strength, Prajapati by supreme lordship, Viraj,

original: indraḥ rūpeṇa agniḥ vahena prajāpatiḥ parameṣṭhī virāj / viśvānare akramata vaiśvānare akramata anaduhi akramata / saḥ adṛṃhayata saḥ adhārayata /
analyzed: indraḥ rūpeṇa agniḥ vahena prajāpatiḥ parameṣṭhī virāj    viśvānare akramata vaiśvānare akramata anaduhi akramata    saḥ adṛṃhayata saḥ adhārayata  /
translated: He entered the all-consuming fire, he entered the all-consuming fire, he entered the unblemished. He made it firm, he supported it.

original: madhyam etat anaḍuhaḥ yatra eṣa vahaḥ āhitaḥ / etāvat asya prācīnam yāvān pratyaṅ samāhitaḥ /
analyzed: madhyam etat anaḍuhaḥ yatra eṣa vahaḥ āhitaḥ   etāvat asya prācīnam yāvān pratyaṅ samāhitaḥ  /
translated: This is the middle of the ox, where this strength is placed. So much is in front of it, as much as is placed behind.🔽He who knows the seven milkings of the ox, following one another,

original: yaḥ veda anaduhaḥ dohān sapta anupadasvataḥ / prajām ca lokam ca āpnoti tathā sapta ṛṣayaḥ viduḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ veda anaduhaḥ dohān sapta anupadasvataḥ   prajām ca lokam ca āpnoti tathā sapta ṛṣayaḥ viduḥ  /
translated: Obtains offspring and the world. So do the seven sages know.🔽With his feet he treads down the fatigue, with his thighs he throws off the weariness.

original: padbhiḥ sedim avakrāman irām jaṅghābhiḥ utkhidan / srameṇa anaḍvān kīlālam kīnāśaḥ ca abhi gacchataḥ /
analyzed: padbhiḥ sedim avakrāman irām jaṅghābhiḥ utkhidan    srameṇa anaḍvān kīlālam kīnāśaḥ ca abhi gacchataḥ  /
translated: The ox with his sweat, the bull with his urine, they both go to the sweet drink.

original: dvādaśa vai etāḥ rātrīḥ vratyāḥ āhuḥ prajāpateḥ / tatra upa brahma yaḥ veda tat vai anaḍuhaḥ vratam /
analyzed: dvādaśa vai etāḥ rātrīḥ vratyāḥ āhuḥ prajāpateḥ   tatra upa brahma yaḥ veda tat vai anaḍuhaḥ vratam  /
translated: They say these twelve nights are the vow of Prajapati. The Brahman there which one knows, that is the vow of the ox.

original: duhe sāyam duhe prātar duhe madhyaṃdinam pari / dohāḥ ye asya saṃyanti tān vidma anupadasvataḥ /
analyzed: duhe sāyam duhe prātar duhe madhyaṃdinam pari   dohāḥ ye asya saṃyanti tān vidma anupadasvataḥ  /
translated: He milks in the evening, he milks in the morning, he milks at noon. We know the milkings that come to him, who never fails to give.

original: rohaṇī asi rohaṇī asthnaḥ chinnasya rohaṇī / rohaya idam arundhati //
analyzed: rohaṇī asi rohaṇī asthnaḥ chinnasya rohaṇī    rohaya idam arundhati
translated: Thou art the healer of the broken bone, the restorer of the severed limb. O Arundhati, heal up this wound.

original: yat te riṣṭam yat te dyuttam asti peṣṭram te ātmani / dhātā tat bhadrayā punar sam dadhat paruṣā paruḥ /
analyzed: yat te riṣṭam yat te dyuttam asti peṣṭram te ātmani    dhātā tat bhadrayā punar sam dadhat paruṣā paruḥ  /
translated: Whatever is decayed or broken in thee, whatever is rotten in thy frame, may the Creator with his right hand join it again, bone to bone.

original: sam te majjā majjñā bhavatu sam u te paruṣā paruḥ / sam te māṃsasya visrastam sam asthi api rohatu //
analyzed: sam te majjā majjñā bhavatu sam u te paruṣā paruḥ   sam te māṃsasya visrastam sam asthi api rohatu  /
translated: Let thy marrow be united with thy marrow, let thy flesh be united with thy flesh. Let thy bone be united with thy bone, let thy broken bone be healed.

original: majjā majñā sam dhīyatām carmaṇā carma rohatu / asṛk te asthi rohatu māṃsam māṃsena rohatu //
analyzed: majjā majñā sam dhīyatām carmaṇā carma rohatu   asṛk te asthi rohatu māṃsam māṃsena rohatu  /
translated: Let thy marrow be united with thy marrow, let thy skin be united with thy skin. Let thy blood be united with thy bone, let thy flesh be united with thy flesh.

original: loma lomnā sam kalpaya tvacā sam kalpaya tvacam / asṛk te asthi rohatu chinnam sam dhehi oṣadhe //
analyzed: loma lomnā sam kalpaya tvacā sam kalpaya tvacam   asṛk te asthi rohatu chinnam sam dhehi oṣadhe  /
translated: Let thy hair be united with thy hair, let thy skin be united with thy skin. Let thy blood be united with thy bone. Heal up the wound, O Plant.

original: saḥ ud tiṣṭha prehi pra drava rathaḥ su cakraḥ / su paviḥ su nābhiḥ prati tiṣṭha ūrdhvaḥ //
analyzed: saḥ ud tiṣṭha prehi pra drava rathaḥ su cakraḥ   su paviḥ su nābhiḥ prati tiṣṭha ūrdhvaḥ  /
translated: Rise up, go forward, run, O chariot, with thy well-made wheels, with thy well-made nave and fellies. Stand erect.

original: yadi kartam patitvā saṃśaśre yadi vā aśmā prahṛtaḥ jaghāna / ṛbhū rathasya iva aṅgāni sam dadhat paruṣā paruḥ /
analyzed: yadi kartam patitvā saṃśaśre yadi vā aśmā prahṛtaḥ jaghāna    ṛbhū rathasya iva aṅgāni sam dadhat paruṣā paruḥ  /
translated: As a chariot-maker mends the parts of a chariot, so do I join together thy limbs, bone by bone.

original: uta devāḥ avahitam devāḥ ud nayatha punar / uta agaḥ cakruṣam devāḥ devāḥ jīvayatha punar /
analyzed: uta devāḥ avahitam devāḥ ud nayatha punar   uta agaḥ cakruṣam devāḥ devāḥ jīvayatha punar  /
translated: The Gods have bent him, the Gods have straightened him again. The Gods have bent him, the Gods have straightened him again.

original: dvau imau vātau vāte ā sindhoḥ ā parāvataḥ / dakṣam te anyaḥ āvātu vi anyaḥ vātu yat rapaḥ /
analyzed: dvau imau vātau vāte ā sindhoḥ ā parāvataḥ   dakṣam te anyaḥ āvātu vi anyaḥ vātu yat rapaḥ  /
translated: These two winds blow here, one from the river, one from the distant sea. Let one of them blow health to thee, and let the other blow away thy malady.

original: ā vāta vāhi bheṣajam vi vāta vāhi yat rapaḥ / tvam hi viśva bheṣaja devānām dūtaḥ īyase //
analyzed: ā vāta vāhi bheṣajam vi vāta vāhi yat rapaḥ tvam hi viśva bheṣaja devānām dūtaḥ īyase
translated: O Vata, blow the remedy, blow away whatever malady there is. For thou, O thou of all remedies, art sent as messenger of the Gods.

original: trāyantām imam devāḥ trāyantām marutām gaṇāḥ / trāyantām viśvā bhūtāni yathā ayam arapāḥ asat /
analyzed: trāyantām imam devāḥ trāyantām marutām gaṇāḥ   trāyantām viśvā bhūtāni yathā ayam arapāḥ asat  /
translated: May the Gods protect this man, may the Maruts' bands protect him. May all beings protect him, that he may be free from disease.

original: ā tvā agamam śaṃtātibhiḥ atha u ariṣṭatātibhiḥ / dakṣam te ugram ābhāriṣam parā yakṣmam suvāmi te /
analyzed: ā tvā agamam śaṃtātibhiḥ atha u ariṣṭatātibhiḥ    dakṣam te ugram ābhāriṣam parā yakṣmam suvāmi te  /
translated: I have come to thee with blessings, and with gifts of perfect safety. I have brought thee strong invigorating food. I drive thy malady away.

original: ayam me hastaḥ bhagavān ayam me bhagavattaraḥ / ayam me viśva bheṣajaḥ ayam śiva abhimarśanaḥ //
analyzed: ayam me hastaḥ bhagavān ayam me bhagavattaraḥ   ayam me viśva bheṣajaḥ ayam śiva abhimarśanaḥ  /
translated: This hand of mine is blessed, this hand of mine is most blessed. This hand of mine is all-healing, this hand of mine is a gracious touch.

original: hastābhyām daśa śākhābhyām jihvā vācaḥ purogavī / anāmayitnubhyām hastābhyām tābhyām tvā abhi mṛśāmasi //🔽ajaḥ hi agneḥ ajaniṣṭa śokāt saḥ apaśyat janitāram agre / tena devāḥ devatām agre āyan tena rohān ruruhuḥ medhyāsaḥ /
analyzed: hastābhyām daśa śākhābhyām jihvā vācaḥ purogavī    anāmayitnubhyām hastābhyām tābhyām tvā abhi mṛśāmasi  / ajaḥ hi agneḥ ajaniṣṭa śokāt saḥ apaśyat janitāram agre   tena devāḥ devatām agre āyan tena rohān ruruhuḥ medhyāsaḥ  /
translated: With both hands, with ten fingers, with the tongue, with speech as foremost, with hands that are not harmful, with these we touch thee.🔽The goat was born from Agni's heat. He first beheld his progenitor. By him the gods first attained the rank of gods. By him the pure ones ascended the worlds.

original: kramadhvam agninā nākam ukhyān hasteṣu bibhrataḥ / divaḥ pṛṣṭham svar gatvā miśrāḥ devebhiḥ ādhvam //
analyzed: kramadhvam agninā nākam ukhyān hasteṣu bibhrataḥ   divaḥ pṛṣṭham svar gatvā miśrāḥ devebhiḥ ādhvam  /
translated: Mount ye the vault of heaven by Agni, bearing him in your hands. Having gone to the back of heaven, to the light, dwell ye together with the gods.

original: pṛṣṭhāt pṛthivyāḥ aham antarikṣam āruham antarikṣāt divam āruham / divaḥ nākasya pṛṣṭhāt svar jyotiḥ agām aham /
analyzed: pṛṣṭhāt pṛthivyāḥ aham antarikṣam āruham antarikṣāt divam āruham   divaḥ nākasya pṛṣṭhāt svar jyotiḥ agām aham  /
translated: From the back of the earth I have ascended the atmosphere. From the atmosphere I have ascended the sky. From the back of the vault of heaven I have gone to the light of heaven.

original: svar yantaḥ na apekṣante ā dyām rohanti rodasī / yajñam ye viśvatas dhāram su vidvāṃsaḥ vitenire /
analyzed: svar yantaḥ na apekṣante ā dyām rohanti rodasī    yajñam ye viśvatas dhāram su vidvāṃsaḥ vitenire  /
translated: Those who go to the light, not looking back, ascend the sky, the two world-halves,

original: agne prehi prathamaḥ devatānām cakṣuḥ devānām uta mānuṣānām / iyakṣamāṇāḥ bhṛgubhiḥ sajoṣāḥ svar yantu yajamānāḥ svasti //
analyzed: agne prehi prathamaḥ devatānām cakṣuḥ devānām uta mānuṣānām   iyakṣamāṇāḥ bhṛgubhiḥ sajoṣāḥ svar yantu yajamānāḥ svasti  /
translated: Agni, go first of the deities, the eye of the gods and of men. Accordant with the Bhṛgus, longing for the sacrifice, may the sacrificers go to heaven in safety.

original: ajam anajmi payasā ghṛtena divyam suparnam payasam bṛhantam / tena geṣma su kṛtasya lokam svar ārohantaḥ abhi nākam uttamam /
analyzed: ajam anajmi payasā ghṛtena divyam suparnam payasam bṛhantam    tena geṣma su kṛtasya lokam svar ārohantaḥ abhi nākam uttamam  /
translated: I set the Goat free with milk and with ghee, the heavenly bird, the great one who is full of sap. By him may we go to the world of the virtuous, ascending to the highest vault of heaven.

original: pañca odanam pañcabhiḥ aṅgulibhiḥ darvyā uddhara pañcadhā etam odanam / prācyām diśi śiraḥ ajasya dhehi dakṣiṇāyām diśi dakṣiṇam dhehi pārśvam /
analyzed: pañca odanam pañcabhiḥ aṅgulibhiḥ darvyā uddhara pañcadhā etam odanam    prācyām diśi śiraḥ ajasya dhehi dakṣiṇāyām diśi dakṣiṇam dhehi pārśvam  /
translated: With five fingers lift up the five-portioned mess of food with the ladle. In the eastern region place the head of the Goat; in the southern region place the right side.

original: pratīcyām diśi bhasadam asya dhehi uttarasyām diśi uttaram dhehi pārśvam / ūrdhvāyām diśi ajasya anūkam dhehi diśi dhruvāyām dhehi pājasyam antarikṣe madhyataḥ madhyam asya //
analyzed: pratīcyām diśi bhasadam asya dhehi uttarasyām diśi uttaram dhehi pārśvam   ūrdhvāyām diśi ajasya anūkam dhehi diśi dhruvāyām dhehi pājasyam antarikṣe madhyataḥ madhyam asya  /
translated: In the western region place the anus of the Goat; in the northern region place the left side. In the upper region place the neck of the Goat; in the firm region place the shoulder. In the middle of the air place the middle of the Goat.🔽Cover the cooked Goat with the cooked skin. Assembled with all its limbs, of every form,

original: śṛtam ajam śṛtayā prorṇuhi tvacā sarvaiḥ aṅgaiḥ saṃbhṛtam viśva rūpam / saḥ ud tisṭha itas abhi nākam uttamam padbhiḥ caturbhiḥ prati tiṣṭha dikṣu /
analyzed: śṛtam ajam śṛtayā prorṇuhi tvacā sarvaiḥ aṅgaiḥ saṃbhṛtam viśva rūpam    saḥ ud tisṭha itas abhi nākam uttamam padbhiḥ caturbhiḥ prati tiṣṭha dikṣu  /
translated: Rise up from here to the highest vault of heaven. Stand firm in the regions with thy four feet.

original: samutpatantu pradiśaḥ nabhasvatīḥ sam abhrāṇi vāta jūtāni yantu / mahā ṛṣabhasya nadataḥ nabhasvataḥ vāśrāḥ āpaḥ pṛthivīm tarpayantu /🔽sam īkṣayantu taviṣāḥ sudānavaḥ apām rasāḥ oṣadhībhiḥ sacantām / varṣasya sargāḥ mahayantu bhūmim pṛthak jāyantām oṣadhayaḥ viśva rūpāḥ /
analyzed: samutpatantu pradiśaḥ nabhasvatīḥ sam abhrāṇi vāta jūtāni yantu   mahā ṛṣabhasya nadataḥ nabhasvataḥ vāśrāḥ āpaḥ pṛthivīm tarpayantu  / sam īkṣayantu taviṣāḥ sudānavaḥ apām rasāḥ oṣadhībhiḥ sacantām   varṣasya sargāḥ mahayantu bhūmim pṛthak jāyantām oṣadhayaḥ viśva rūpāḥ  /
translated: Let the regions rise up, let the winds blow, let the clouds be driven on by the wind. Let the waters, the tears of the great bull's roar, satisfy the earth.🔽Let the bountiful ones look on with power. Let the saps of the waters agree with the plants. Let the showers of rain magnify the earth. Let the plants be born in various forms.

original: sam īkṣayasva gāyataḥ nabhāṃsi apām vegāsaḥ pṛthak ud vijantām / varṣasya sargāḥ mahayantu bhūmim pṛthak jāyantām vīrudhaḥ viśva rūpāḥ /🔽gaṇāḥ tvā upa gāyantu mārutāḥ parjanya ghoṣiṇaḥ pṛthak / sargāḥ varṣasya varṣataḥ varṣantu pṛthivīm anu /
analyzed: sam īkṣayasva gāyataḥ nabhāṃsi apām vegāsaḥ pṛthak ud vijantām   varṣasya sargāḥ mahayantu bhūmim pṛthak jāyantām vīrudhaḥ viśva rūpāḥ  / gaṇāḥ tvā upa gāyantu mārutāḥ parjanya ghoṣiṇaḥ pṛthak   sargāḥ varṣasya varṣataḥ varṣantu pṛthivīm anu  /
translated: Look on the clouds, O singer. Let the forces of the waters be scattered apart. Let the showers of rain magnify the earth. Let the plants be born in various forms.🔽Let the Maruts, the hosts, sing to thee. Let the showers of rain, roaring like clouds, be scattered apart. Let the showers of rain, falling from the rain, rain upon the earth.

original: ud īrayata marutaḥ samudrataḥ tveṣaḥ arkaḥ nabhaḥ ud pātayātha / mahā ṛṣabhasya nadataḥ nabhasvataḥ vāśrāḥ āpaḥ pṛthivīm tarpayantu /
analyzed: ud īrayata marutaḥ samudrataḥ tveṣaḥ arkaḥ nabhaḥ ud pātayātha    mahā ṛṣabhasya nadataḥ nabhasvataḥ vāśrāḥ āpaḥ pṛthivīm tarpayantu  /
translated: Lift up the rain, O Maruts, from the ocean. Let the bright sun drive the cloud up to the sky. Let the waters, the tears of the great bull's roar, satisfy the earth.

original: abhi kranda stanaya ardaya udadhim bhūmim parjanya payasā sam aṅdhi / tvayā sṛṣṭam bahulam aitu varṣam āśāraiṣī kṛśaguḥ etu astam /
analyzed: abhi kranda stanaya ardaya udadhim bhūmim parjanya payasā sam aṅdhi    tvayā sṛṣṭam bahulam aitu varṣam āśāraiṣī kṛśaguḥ etu astam  /
translated: Thunder out, roar, rend the ocean, and unite the earth with the rain-water of Parjanya. Let the rain come down in abundance, sent by thee. Let the cloudless region go to rest.

original: sam vaḥ avantu sudānavaḥ utsāḥ ajagarāḥ uta / marudbhiḥ pracyutāḥ meghāḥ varṣantu pṛthivīm anu /
analyzed: sam vaḥ avantu sudānavaḥ utsāḥ ajagarāḥ uta  / marudbhiḥ pracyutāḥ meghāḥ varṣantu pṛthivīm anu  /
translated: May the bountiful Utsa and Ajaras protect you all. Let the clouds, urged on by the Maruts, rain upon the earth.

original: āśām āśām vi dyotatām vātāḥ vāntu diśaḥ diśaḥ / marudbhiḥ pracyutāḥ meghāḥ sam yantu pṛthivīm anu /
analyzed: āśām āśām vi dyotatām vātāḥ vāntu diśaḥ diśaḥ   marudbhiḥ pracyutāḥ meghāḥ sam yantu pṛthivīm anu  /
translated: Let the winds blow from all the quarters of the sky. Let the clouds, urged on by the Maruts, gather together and rain upon the earth.🔽Let the bountiful Utsa and Ajaras protect you all. Let the clouds, urged on by the Maruts, rain upon the earth.

original: āpaḥ vidyut abhram varṣam sam vaḥ avantu sudānavaḥ utsāḥ ajagarāḥ uta / marudbhiḥ pracyutāḥ meghāḥ prāvantu pṛthivīm anu /
analyzed: āpaḥ vidyut abhram varṣam sam vaḥ avantu sudānavaḥ utsāḥ ajagarāḥ uta  / marudbhiḥ pracyutāḥ meghāḥ prāvantu pṛthivīm anu  /
translated: Let the waters, the lightning, the clouds, and the rain, be united with you. Let the bountiful Utsa and Ajaras protect you all. Let the clouds, urged on by the Maruts, rain upon the earth.

original: apām agniḥ tanūbhiḥ saṃvidānaḥ yaḥ oṣadhīnām adhipāḥ babhūva / sa naḥ varṣam vanutām jātavedāḥ prāṇam prajābhyaḥ amṛtam divaḥ pari /
analyzed: apām agniḥ tanūbhiḥ saṃvidānaḥ yaḥ oṣadhīnām adhipāḥ babhūva   sa naḥ varṣam vanutām jātavedāḥ prāṇam prajābhyaḥ amṛtam divaḥ pari  /
translated: Let the all-knowing Jâtavedas, who hath been made one with the bodies of the waters, who is the Lord of plants and herbs, send us rain. Let him, the immortal life of creatures, from heaven, send us rain.

original: prajāpatiḥ salilāt ā samudrāt āpaḥ īrayan udadhim ardayāti / pra pyāyatām vṛṣṇaḥ aśvasya retaḥ arvān etena stanayitnunā ihi /
analyzed: prajāpatiḥ salilāt ā samudrāt āpaḥ īrayan udadhim ardayāti   pra pyāyatām vṛṣṇaḥ aśvasya retaḥ arvān etena stanayitnunā ihi  /
translated: Prajapati, sending forth the waters from the ocean, makes the deep swell. Let the seed of the strong horse grow. Come hither with this roaring of the clouds.

original: apaḥ niṣiñcan asuraḥ pitā naḥ śvasantu gargarāḥ apām varuṇāva nīcīḥ apaḥ sṛja / vadantu pṛśni bāhavaḥ maṇḍūkāḥ iriṇānu /
analyzed: apaḥ niṣiñcan asuraḥ pitā naḥ śvasantu gargarāḥ apām varuṇa ava nīcīḥ apaḥ sṛja   vadantu pṛśni bāhavaḥ maṇḍūkāḥ iriṇānu  /
translated: Pouring out the waters, our father the Asura, let the water-pots breathe. O Varuna, let loose the low-lying waters. Let the frogs with their speckled arms croak in the marshes.

original: saṃvatsaram śaśayānāḥ brāhmaṇāḥ vrata cāriṇaḥ / vācam parjanya jinvitām pra maṇdūkāḥ avādiṣuḥ /
analyzed: saṃvatsaram śaśayānāḥ brāhmaṇāḥ vrata cāriṇaḥ   vācam parjanya jinvitām pra maṇdūkāḥ avādiṣuḥ  /
translated: The Brahmins, observing vows, have lain for a year. The frogs have croaked out the voice inspired by Parjanya.

original: upapravada maṇḍūki varṣam ā vada tāduri / madhye hradasya plavasva vigṛhya caturaḥ padaḥ /
analyzed: upapravada maṇḍūki varṣam ā vada tāduri    madhye hradasya plavasva vigṛhya caturaḥ padaḥ  /
translated: Croak forth, O frog, utter the rain, O tāduri. Swim in the middle of the lake, stretching out your four feet.

original: khaṇva khaima madhye taduri / varṣam vanudhvam pitaraḥ marutām manaḥ ichata //
analyzed: khaṇva khaima madhye taduri    varṣam vanudhvam pitaraḥ marutām manaḥ ichata
translated: Croak, khaim, in the middle, tāduri. Seek the rain, O fathers, desire the mind of the Maruts.

original: mahāntam kośam ud aca abhi siñca sa vidyutam bhavatu vātu vātaḥ / tanvatām yajñam bahudhā visṛṣṭāḥ ānandinīḥ oṣadhayaḥ bhavantu /
analyzed: mahāntam kośam ud aca abhi siñca sa vidyutam bhavatu vātu vātaḥ   tanvatām yajñam bahudhā visṛṣṭāḥ ānandinīḥ oṣadhayaḥ bhavantu  /
translated: Pour out the great vessel, let it be with lightning. Let the wind blow. Let the scattered limbs of the sacrifice become the rejoicing plants in many ways.

original: bṛhan eṣām adhiṣṭhātā antikāt iva paśyati / yaḥ stāyan manyate caran sarvam devāḥ idam viduḥ /
analyzed: bṛhan eṣām adhiṣṭhātā antikāt iva paśyati   yaḥ stāyan manyate caran sarvam devāḥ idam viduḥ  /
translated: He who is far away is their overlord, he sees as if he were near. He who, standing still, thinks he is moving, and he who, moving, thinks he is standing still, all this the Gods know.

original: yaḥ tiṣṭhati carati yaḥ ca vañcati yaḥ nilāyam carati yaḥ prataṅkam / dvau saṃniṣadya yat mantrayete rājā tat veda varuṇaḥ tṛtīyaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ tiṣṭhati carati yaḥ ca vañcati yaḥ nilāyam carati yaḥ prataṅkam   dvau saṃniṣadya yat mantrayete rājā tat veda varuṇaḥ tṛtīyaḥ  /
translated: He who stands still, he who moves, he who deceives, he who moves in a circle, he who moves in a straight line, what two sitting together consult, that the King knows, and Varuna as the third.

original: uta iyam bhūmiḥ varuṇasya rājñaḥ uta asau dyauḥ bṛhatī dūreantā / uta u samudrau varuṇasya kukṣī uta asmin alpe udake nilīnaḥ /
analyzed: uta iyam bhūmiḥ varuṇasya rājñaḥ uta asau dyauḥ bṛhatī dūreantā    uta u samudrau varuṇasya kukṣī uta asmin alpe udake nilīnaḥ  /
translated: This earth is the kingdom of King Varuna, and yonder lofty heaven is far away. The two oceans are the belly of Varuna, and he is hidden in this small water.

original: uta yaḥ dyām atisarpāt parastāt na sa mucyātai varuṇasya rājñaḥ / divaḥ spaśaḥ pra caranti idam asya sahasra akṣāḥ ati paśyanti bhūmim //
analyzed: uta yaḥ dyām atisarpāt parastāt na sa mucyātai varuṇasya rājñaḥ    divaḥ spaśaḥ pra caranti idam asya sahasra akṣāḥ ati paśyanti bhūmim  /
translated: And he who would pass beyond the sky yonder, he is not freed from King Varuna. The spies of heaven move about in this (world), and with a thousand eyes they look over the earth.

original: sarvam tat rājā varuṇaḥ vi caṣṭe yat antarā rodasī yat parastāt / saṃkhyātāḥ asya nimiṣaḥ janānām akṣān iva śva ghnī ni minoti tāni /
analyzed: sarvam tat rājā varuṇaḥ vi caṣṭe yat antarā rodasī yat parastāt    saṃkhyātāḥ asya nimiṣaḥ janānām akṣān iva śva ghnī ni minoti tāni  /
translated: All that the King Varuna sees, what is between the two worlds and what is beyond, the winking of men is counted by him, as a bitch carries off the dice.

original: ye te pāśāḥ varuṇa sapta sapta tredhā tiṣṭhanti viṣitāḥ ruṣantaḥ / chinantu sarve anṛtam vadantam yaḥ satya vādī ati tam sṛjantu //
analyzed: ye te pāśāḥ varuṇa sapta sapta tredhā tiṣṭhanti viṣitāḥ ruṣantaḥ    chinantu sarve anṛtam vadantam yaḥ satya vādī ati tam sṛjantu  /
translated: Let all of them entangle him who speaks untruth: let them alone the truthful one.🔽Bind him with a hundred fetters, O Varuna: let not the man who speaks untruth, the man who looks on men, loose thee.

original: śatena pāśaiḥ abhi dhehi varuṇa enam mā te moci anṛtavāc nṛ cakṣaḥ / āstām jālmaḥ udaram śraṃśayitvā kośaḥ iva ābandhaḥ parikṛtyamānaḥ /
analyzed: śatena pāśaiḥ abhi dhehi varuṇa enam mā te moci anṛtavāc nṛ cakṣaḥ   āstām jālmaḥ udaram śraṃśayitvā kośaḥ iva ābandhaḥ parikṛtyamānaḥ  /
translated: Let the cripple, having broken his belly, lie there, like a bag that is burst and turned inside out.

original: yaḥ samābhyaḥ varuṇaḥ yaḥ vyābhyaḥ yaḥ saṃdeśyaḥ varuṇaḥ yaḥ videśyaḥ / yaḥ daivaḥ varuṇaḥ yaḥ ca mānuṣaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ samābhyaḥ varuṇaḥ yaḥ vyābhyaḥ yaḥ saṃdeśyaḥ varuṇaḥ yaḥ videśyaḥ   yaḥ daivaḥ varuṇaḥ yaḥ ca mānuṣaḥ  /
translated: The Varuna who is for the equal, the Varuna who is for the unequal, the Varuna who is for the messenger, the Varuna who is for the foreigner, the Varuna who is divine, the Varuna who is human,

original: taiḥ tvā sarvaiḥ abhi syāmi pāśaiḥ asau āmuṣyāyaṇa amuṣyāḥ putra / tān u te sarvān anusaṃdiśāmi //
analyzed: taiḥ tvā sarvaiḥ abhi syāmi pāśaiḥ asau āmuṣyāyaṇa amuṣyāḥ putra   tān u te sarvān anusaṃdiśāmi  /
translated: With all these bonds will I bind thee, N.N., son of N.N., of N.N. I will deliver thee over to all of them.

original: īśāṇām tvā bheṣajānām ujjeṣe ā rabhāmahe / cakre sahasra vīryam sarvasmai oṣadhe tvā /
analyzed: īśāṇām tvā bheṣajānām ujjeṣe ā rabhāmahe   cakre sahasra vīryam sarvasmai oṣadhe tvā  /
translated: We take thee, O plant, the conqueror of the lords of sickness, the conqueror of the diseases, the plant of a thousand powers, for every ailment.

original: satyajitam śapatha yāvanīm sahamānām punaḥsarām / sarvāḥ sam ahvi oṣadhīḥ itas naḥ pārayāt iti //
analyzed: satyajitam śapatha yāvanīm sahamānām punaḥsarām    sarvāḥ sam ahvi oṣadhīḥ itas naḥ pārayāt iti  /
translated: The victorious, the conqueror of curses, the conqueror of the foe, the conqueror of the enemy, the conqueror of the foe again, all the plants have I invoked. Let them deliver us from this.

original: yā śaśāpa śapanena yā agham mūram ādadhe / yā rasasya haraṇāya jātam ārebhe tokam attu sā /
analyzed: yā śaśāpa śapanena yā agham mūram ādadhe   yā rasasya haraṇāya jātam ārebhe tokam attu sā  /
translated: She who hath cursed with curses, she who hath laid sin and folly on us, She who hath sought to rob us of our sap, may she who hath attacked our offspring eat it.

original: yām te cakruḥ āme pātre yām cakruḥ nīlalohite / āme māṃse kṛtyām yām cakruḥ tayā kṛtyā kṛtaḥ jahi //
analyzed: yām te cakruḥ āme pātre yām cakruḥ nīlalohite   āme māṃse kṛtyām yām cakruḥ tayā kṛtyā kṛtaḥ jahi  /
translated: The witchcraft which they wrought in a raw vessel, which they wrought in blue and red, The witchcraft which they wrought in raw flesh, with that witchcraft do thou slay the man who hath wrought witchcraft.

original: dauṣvapnyam daurjīvityam rakṣaḥ abhvam arāyyaḥ / durṇāmnīḥ sarvāḥ durvācaḥ tāḥ asmat nāśayāmasi //🔽kṣudhā māram tṛṣṇā māram a gotām anapatya tām / apāmārga tvayā vayam sarvam tat apa mṛjmahe /
analyzed: dauṣvapnyam daurjīvityam rakṣaḥ abhvam arāyyaḥ   durṇāmnīḥ sarvāḥ durvācaḥ tāḥ asmat nāśayāmasi  / kṣudhā māram tṛṣṇā māram a go tām anapatya tām      apāmārga tvayā vayam sarvam tat apa mṛjmahe  /
translated: Evil dreams, evil living, fiends, wild beasts, want, evil names, and all evil speech, All these we drive away from us.🔽Hunger, the demon, thirst, the demon, want of cattle, want of children, All that we wipe away from us with thee, O Apamarga.

original: tṛṣṇā māram kṣudhā māram atho akṣa parājayam / apāmārga tvayā vayam sarvam tat apa mṛjmahe /
analyzed: tṛṣṇā māram kṣudhā māram atho akṣa parājayam     apāmārga tvayā vayam sarvam tat apa mṛjmahe  /
translated: The demon of thirst, the demon of hunger, and the loss of a stake in gambling, All that we wipe away with thee, O Apamarga.

original: apāmārgaḥ oṣadhīnām sarvāsām ekaḥ id vaśī / tena te mṛjmaḥ āsthitam atha tvam agadaḥ cara /
analyzed: apāmārgaḥ oṣadhīnām sarvāsām ekaḥ id vaśī   tena te mṛjmaḥ āsthitam atha tvam agadaḥ cara  /
translated: Apamarga is the one lord of all the plants. With him we wipe away what thou hast seized upon, and then thou shalt go thy way healed.

original: samam jyotiḥ sūryeṇa ahnā rātrī samāvatī / kṛṇomi satyam ūtaye arasāḥ santu kṛtvarīḥ /
analyzed: samam jyotiḥ sūryeṇa ahnā rātrī samāvatī   kṛṇomi satyam ūtaye arasāḥ santu kṛtvarīḥ  /
translated: Equal is the light of the sun with the night and the day. I make truth for help. Let the sorcerers be powerless.

original: yaḥ devāḥ kṛtyām kṛtvā harāt aviduṣaḥ gṛham / vatsaḥ dhāruḥ iva mātaram tam pratyak upa padyatām /
analyzed: yaḥ devāḥ kṛtyām kṛtvā harāt aviduṣaḥ gṛham   vatsaḥ dhāruḥ iva mātaram tam pratyak upa padyatām  /
translated: As a calf seeks his mother, let him go back to him who wrought the spell.🔽He who, having wrought evil, would fain destroy another with it,

original: amā kṛtvā pāpmānam yaḥ tena anyam jighāṃsati / aśmānaḥ tasyām dagdhāyām bahulāḥ phaṭ karikrati //
analyzed: amā kṛtvā pāpmānam yaḥ tena anyam jighāṃsati    aśmānaḥ tasyām dagdhāyām bahulāḥ phaṭ karikrati  /
translated: When it is burnt, let many stones be shattered to pieces.🔽O thou of a thousand powers, with thy rays, with thy shadow,

original: sahasra dhāman viśikhān vigrīvām chāyayā tvam / prati sma cakruṣe kṛtyām priyām priyāvate hara /
analyzed: sahasra dhāman viśikhān vigrīvām chāyayā tvam   prati sma cakruṣe kṛtyām priyām priyāvate hara  /
translated: Thou turnest back the spell which the sorcerer hath wrought against us, the dear spell of the dear one, O Hari.🔽With this herb I have destroyed all the spells,

original: anayā aham oṣadhyā sarvāḥ kṛtyāḥ adūduṣam / yām kṣetre cakruḥ yām goṣu yām vā te puruṣeṣu /
analyzed: anayā aham oṣadhyā sarvāḥ kṛtyāḥ adūduṣam    yām kṣetre cakruḥ yām goṣu yām vā te puruṣeṣu
translated: Whether they have been wrought in the field, in the cattle, or in thy people.🔽He who hath wrought and hath not been able to do, hath cried out with pain, hath lost a limb,

original: yaḥ cakāra na śaśāka kartum śaśre pādam aṅgurim / cakāra bhadram asmabhyam ātmane tapanam tu saḥ /🔽apāmārgaḥ apa mārṣṭu kṣetriyam śapathaḥ ca yaḥ / apa aha yātudhānīḥ apa sarvāḥ arāyyaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ cakāra na śaśāka kartum śaśre pādam aṅgurim    cakāra bhadram asmabhyam ātmane tapanam tu saḥ  / apāmārgaḥ apa mārṣṭu kṣetriyam śapathaḥ ca yaḥ    apa aha yātudhānīḥ apa sarvāḥ arāyyaḥ  /
translated: Hath done well for us, but hath scorched himself.🔽The Apamarga (herb) shall wipe away the witchcraft and the curse,🔽Drive away the Yatudhanas, drive away all the wicked.🔽Having wiped away the Yatudhanas, having driven away all the wicked,

original: apamṛjya yātudhānān apa sarvāḥ arāyyaḥ / apāmārga tvayā vayam sarvam tat apa mṛjmahe /
analyzed: apamṛjya yātudhānān apa sarvāḥ arāyyaḥ   apāmārga tvayā vayam sarvam tat apa mṛjmahe  /
translated: With thee, O Apamarga, we wipe away all that.

original: uta u asi abandhu kṛt uta u asi nu jāmi kṛt / uta u kṛtyā kṛtaḥ prajām nadam iva ā chindhi vārṣikam /
analyzed: uta u asi abandhu kṛt uta u asi nu jāmi kṛt    uta u kṛtyā kṛtaḥ prajām nadam iva ā chinddhi vārṣikam  /
translated: Thou art the maker of a friend, thou art the maker of a foe, thou art the maker of a charm. Cut off the charm that works destruction like a river in the spring.

original: brāhmaṇena paryuktā asi kaṇvena nārṣadena / senā iva eṣi tviṣīmatī na tatra bhayam asti yatra prāpnoṣi oṣadhe /
analyzed: brāhmaṇena paryuktā asi kaṇvena nārṣadena    senā iva eṣi tviṣīmatī na tatra bhayam asti yatra prāpnoṣi oṣadhe  /
translated: Thou art appointed by the Brāhman, by Kaṇva, by Nāṛṣad. Like an army thou goest forth, flashing with light. There is no fear in the place where thou art found, O Plant.

original: agram eṣi oṣadhīnām jyotiṣā iva abhidīpayan / uta trātāsi pākasya atho hantāsi rakṣasaḥ /
analyzed: agram eṣi oṣadhīnām jyotiṣā iva abhidīpayan    uta trātā asi pākasya atho hantā asi rakṣasaḥ  /
translated: Thou goest forth as the first of plants, as one who with his light illumes them. Thou art the saviour of the ripe corn, and thou art the slayer of the Rakshas.

original: yat adaḥ devāḥ asurān tvayā agre nirakurvata / tatas tvam adhi oṣadhe apāmārgaḥ ajāyathāḥ /
analyzed: yat adaḥ devāḥ asurān tvayā agre nirakurvata   tatas tvam adhi oṣadhe apāmārgaḥ ajāyathāḥ  /
translated: When, in the days of old, the Gods with thee destroyed the Asuras, Then from that time, O Plant, thou wast born, the Apāmārga.

original: vibhindatī śata śākhā vibhindat nāma te pitā / pratyak vi bhindhi tvam tam yaḥ asmām abhidāsati //🔽asat bhūmyāḥ sam abhavat tat yām eti mahat vyacaḥ / tat vai tatas vidhūpāyat pratyak kartāram ṛchatu //
analyzed: vibhindatī śata śākhā vibhindat nāma te pitā   pratyak vi bhindhi tvam tam yaḥ asmām abhidāsati  / asat bhūmyāḥ sam abhavat tat yām eti mahat vyacaḥ   tat vai tatas vidhūpāyat pratyak kartāram ṛchatu  /
translated: Thou who hast hundred branches, breaking through, whose father is called Vibhīdaka. Break thou that man who threatens us.🔽The great expanse of thee that art, hath sprung from out the earth. From that place let the Apāmārga drive away the man who hates us.

original: pratyaṅ hi saṃbabhūvitha pratīcīna phalaḥ tvam / sarvān mat śapathām adhi varīyaḥ yāvaya vadham /
analyzed: pratyaṅ hi saṃbabhūvitha pratīcīna phalaḥ tvam    sarvān mat śapathām adhi varīyaḥ yāvaya vadham  /
translated: Thou hast become the man who threatens us. Thou hast become the man who threatens us. Thou hast become the man who threatens us. Thou hast become the man who threatens us.
