analyzed: yāḥ hṛdayam uparṣanti anutanvanti kīkasāḥ   a hiṃsantīḥ anāmayāḥ niḥ dravantu bahis bilam  /
translated: Those which approach the heart, and creep along the ribs, — depart, harmless and painless, from the cavity within.

original: yāḥ pārśve uparṣanti anunikṣanti pṛṣṭīḥ / a hiṃsantīḥ anāmayāḥ niḥ dravantu bahis bilam /🔽yāḥ tiraścīḥ uparṣanti arṣaṇīḥ vakṣaṇāsu te / a hiṃsantīḥ anāmayāḥ niḥ dravantu bahis bilam /🔽yāḥ gudāḥ anusarpanti āntrāṇi mohayanti ca / a hiṃsantīḥ anāmayāḥ niḥ dravantu bahis bilam /
analyzed: yāḥ pārśve uparṣanti anunikṣanti pṛṣṭīḥ   a hiṃsantīḥ anāmayāḥ niḥ dravantu bahis bilam  / yāḥ tiraścīḥ uparṣanti arṣaṇīḥ vakṣaṇāsu te   a hiṃsantīḥ anāmayāḥ niḥ dravantu bahis bilam  / yāḥ gudāḥ anusarpanti āntrāṇi mohayanti ca   a hiṃsantīḥ anāmayāḥ niḥ dravantu bahis bilam  /
translated: Those which approach the sides, and creep along the back-bones, — depart, harmless and painless, from the cavity within.🔽Those which approach thee crosswise, the piercing ones within the breast, — depart, harmless and painless, from the cavity within.🔽Those which creep along the bowels, and cause the entrails to be confused, — depart, harmless and painless, from the cavity within.

original: yāḥ majjñaḥ nirdhayanti parūṃṣi virujanti ca / a hiṃsantīḥ anāmayāḥ niḥ dravantu bahis bilam /🔽ye aṅgāni madayanti yakṣmāsaḥ ropaṇāḥ tava / yakṣmāṇām sarveṣām viṣam niḥ avocam aham tvat /
analyzed: yāḥ majjñaḥ nirdhayanti parūṃṣi virujanti ca   a hiṃsantīḥ anāmayāḥ niḥ dravantu bahis bilam  / ye aṅgāni madayanti yakṣmāsaḥ ropaṇāḥ tava   yakṣmāṇām sarveṣām viṣam niḥ avocam aham tvat  /
translated: Those which gnaw the marrow, and rend the limbs, — depart, harmless and painless, from the cavity within.🔽Those which intoxicate the limbs, the wasting, consumptive humours, — the poison of all consumptive humours have I extracted from thee.

original: visalpasya vidradhasya vātīkārasya vālajeḥ / yakṣmāṇām sarveṣām viṣam niḥ avocam aham tvat /
analyzed: visalpasya vidradhasya vātīkārasya vā alajeḥ   yakṣmāṇām sarveṣām viṣam niḥ avocam aham tvat
translated: The poison of the abscess, the carbuncle, the boil, the running sore, — the poison of all consumptive humours have I extracted from thee.

original: pādābhyām te jānubhyām śroṇibhyām pari bhaṃsasaḥ / anūkāt arṣaṇīḥ uṣṇihābhyaḥ śīrṣṇaḥ rogam anīnaśam /
analyzed: pādābhyām te jānubhyām śroṇibhyām pari bhaṃsasaḥ   anūkāt arṣaṇīḥ uṣṇihābhyaḥ śīrṣṇaḥ rogam anīnaśam  /
translated: From thy feet, thy knees, thy hips, thy hinder parts, from thy belly, from thy sides, from thy shoulders, from thy head, I have removed disease.

original: asya vāmasya palitasya hotuḥ tasya bhrātā madhyamaḥ asti aśnaḥ / tṛtīyaḥ bhrātā ghṛta pṛṣṭhaḥ asya atra apaśyam viśpatim sapta putram /
analyzed: asya vāmasya palitasya hotuḥ tasya bhrātā madhyamaḥ asti aśnaḥ   tṛtīyaḥ bhrātā ghṛta pṛṣṭhaḥ asya atra apaśyam viśpatim sapta putram  /
translated: Of this, the left, the hoary, the Hotar, his brother, the middle one, is called Ashna. His third brother is Ghrtapuch. Here I have seen the lord of the people, the seven-fold one.

original: sapta yuñjanti ratham eka cakram ekaḥ aśvaḥ vahati sapta nāmā / tri nābhi cakram ajaram anarvam yatra imā viśvā bhuvanā adhi tasthuḥ /
analyzed: sapta yuñjanti ratham eka cakram ekaḥ aśvaḥ vahati sapta nāmā    tri nābhi cakram ajaram anarvam yatra imā viśvā bhuvanā adhi tasthuḥ  /
translated: They yoke the one-wheeled chariot to the seven. One horse draws it, bearing the name of seven. The wheel with three naves, undecaying, uninjured, whereon all these worlds are established.

original: imam ratham adhi ye sapta tasthuḥ sapta cakram sapta vahanti aśvāḥ / sapta svasāraḥ abhi sam navanta yatra gavām nihitā sapta nāma /
analyzed: imam ratham adhi ye sapta tasthuḥ sapta cakram sapta vahanti aśvāḥ    sapta svasāraḥ abhi sam navanta yatra gavām nihitā sapta nāma  /
translated: Those seven who stand upon this chariot, the seven-wheeled one, the seven horses draw. The seven sisters sing together there, where the seven names of the cows are fixed.

original: kaḥ dadarśa prathamam jāyamānam a sthanvantam yat anasthā bibharti / bhūmyāḥ asuḥ asṛk ātmā kva svid kaḥ vidvāṃsam upa gāt praṣṭum etat /
analyzed: kaḥ dadarśa prathamam jāyamānam a sthanvantam yat anasthā bibharti   bhūmyāḥ asuḥ asṛk ātmā kva svid kaḥ vidvāṃsam upa gāt praṣṭum etat  /
translated: Who has seen the first-born, springing into life, who bears what is unmoving on that which moves not? Where is the soul of earth, the life, the body? Who has approached the wise one to ask this?

original: iha bravītu yaḥ īm aṅga veda asya vāmasya nihitam padam veḥ / śīrṣṇaḥ kṣīram duhrate gāvaḥ asya vavrim vasānāḥ udakam padā apuḥ /
analyzed: iha bravītu yaḥ īm aṅga veda asya vāmasya nihitam padam veḥ   śīrṣṇaḥ kṣīram duhrate gāvaḥ asya vavrim vasānāḥ udakam padā apuḥ  /
translated: Let him who knows declare it here, the place of rest of this bird's wing. From his head kine are milked with streams of milk; they have found water in the cloud.

original: pākaḥ pṛchāmi manasā a vijānan devānām enā nihitā padāni / vatse baṣkaye adhi sapta tantūn vi tatnire kavayaḥ otavai u /
analyzed: pākaḥ pṛcchāmi manasā a vijānan devānām enā nihitā padāni   vatse baṣkaye adhi sapta tantūn vi tatnire kavayaḥ otavai u  /
translated: I ask in my mind, not knowing, of the wise, the hidden places of the Gods. On the calf and the bull the sages have stretched the seven threads, the wise, not the unwise.

original: acikitvān cikituṣaḥ cit atra kavīn pṛchāmi vidvanaḥ na vidvān / vi yaḥ tastambha ṣaṭ imā rajāṃsi ajasya rūpe kim api svid ekam /🔽mātā pitaram ṛte ā babhāja adhi iti agre manasā sam hi jagme / sā bībhatsuḥ garbha rasā nividdhā namasvantaḥ id upavākam īyuḥ /
analyzed: acikitvān cikituṣaḥ cit atra kavīn pṛcchāmi vidvanaḥ na vidvān    vi yaḥ tastambha ṣaḍ imā rajāṃsi ajasya rūpe kim api svid ekam  / mātā pitaram ṛte ā babhāja adhi iti agre manasā sam hi jagme    sā bībhatsuḥ garbha rasā nividdhā namasvantaḥ id upavākam īyuḥ  /
translated: Not knowing, I ask the wise, the sages, though I am wise, not un- wise. He who hath propped these six regions, what is it, in the form of the Goat, that is one only?🔽The mother hath divided the father, before, in the beginning, in the mind. She, the fearful, the womb-born, is concealed. The reverent have gone to the invocation.

original: yuktā mātā asit dhuri dakṣiṇāyāḥ atiṣṭhat garbhaḥ vṛjanīṣu antar / amīmet vatsaḥ anu gām apaśyat viśvarūpyam triṣu yoganeṣu /
analyzed: yuktā mātā asit dhuri dakṣiṇāyāḥ atiṣṭhat garbhaḥ vṛjanīṣu antar   amīmet vatsaḥ anu gām apaśyat viśvarūpyam triṣu yoganeṣu  /
translated: The mother was yoked to the pole of the gift. The embryo stood in the middle of the two yokes. The calf has moved, and has seen the cow, the all-formed, in the three yokes.

original: tisraḥ matṝḥ trīn pitṝn bibhrat ekaḥ urdhvaḥ tasthau na īm ava glāpayanta / mantrayante divaḥ amuṣya pṛṣṭhe viśva vidaḥ vācam aviśva vidnām / / mantrayante divaḥ amuṣya pṛṣṭhe viśva vidaḥ vācam aviśva vidnām / / mantrayante divaḥ amuṣya pṛṣṭhe viśva vidaḥ vācam aviśva vidnām / / mantrayante divaḥ amuṣya pṛṣṭhe viśva vidaḥ vācam aviśva vidnām / / / mantrayante divaḥ amuṣya pṛṣṭhe viśva vidaḥ vācam aviśva
analyzed: tisraḥ matṝḥ trīn pitṝn bibhrat ekaḥ urdhvaḥ tasthau na īm ava glāpayanta    mantrayante divaḥ amuṣya pṛṣṭhe viśva vidaḥ vācam aviśva vidnām
translated: On the back of this highest heaven they, all-knowing, consult the speech of those who know not all.

original: pañca are cakre parivartamāne yasmin ātasthuḥ bhuvanāni viśvā / tasya na akṣaḥ tapyate bhūri bhāraḥ sanāt eva na chidyate sanābhiḥ //
analyzed: pañca are cakre parivartamāne yasmin ātasthuḥ bhuvanāni viśvā   tasya na akṣaḥ tapyate bhūri bhāraḥ sanāt eva na chidyate sanābhiḥ  /
translated: The five-spoked wheel revolves, in which all living things have their abode. Its axle is not heated, though it bears a heavy load: from ancient time it is not broken, though it be a central point.

original: pañca pādam pitaram dvādaśa ākṛtim divaḥ āhuḥ pare ardhe purīṣiṇam / atha ime anye upare vicakṣaṇe sapta cakre ṣaṣ are āhuḥ arpitam /
analyzed: pañca pādam pitaram dvādaśa ākṛtim divaḥ āhuḥ pare ardhe purīṣiṇam     atha ime anye upare vicakṣaṇe sapta cakre ṣaṣ are āhuḥ arpitam  /
translated: The five-footed sire of twelve forms, whose abode is in the upper half of heaven, the dust-begotten, they call the father. And these other two, the wise, in the lower half, they say, are set in the seven-wheeled six-spoked (car).

original: dvādaśa aram nahi tat jarāya varvarti cakram pari dyām ṛtasya / ā putrāḥ agne mithunāsaḥ atra sapta śatāni viṃśatiḥ ca tasthuḥ /
analyzed: dvādaśa aram nahi tat jarāya varvarti cakram pari dyām ṛtasya   ā putrāḥ agne mithunāsaḥ atra sapta śatāni viṃśatiḥ ca tasthuḥ  /
translated: The wheel of Order, which hath twelve spokes, doth not roll on, through age, to the end of the heavens. Here, O Agni, the seven hundred and twenty pairs of thy sons are established.

original: sanemi cakram ajaram vi vavṛte uttānāyām daśa yuktāḥ vahanti / sūryasya cakṣuḥ rajasā eti āvṛtam yasmin ātasthuḥ bhuvanāni viśvā /
analyzed: sanemi cakram ajaram vi vavṛte uttānāyām daśa yuktāḥ vahanti    sūryasya cakṣuḥ rajasā eti āvṛtam yasmin ātasthuḥ bhuvanāni viśvā  /
translated: The undecaying wheel hath rolled on, drawn by ten yoked (horses), on the outstretched (altar). The eye of the sun, covered with dust, goeth on, in which all the worlds have taken their stand.

original: striyaḥ satīḥ tām u me puṃsaḥ āhuḥ paśyat akṣaṇvān vi cetat andhaḥ / kaviḥ yaḥ putraḥ saḥ īm ā ciketa yaḥ tāḥ vijānāt sa pituḥ pitā asat /
analyzed: striyaḥ satīḥ tām u me puṃsaḥ āhuḥ paśyat akṣaṇvān vi cetat andhaḥ   kaviḥ yaḥ putraḥ saḥ īm ā ciketa yaḥ tāḥ vijānāt sa pituḥ pitā asat  /
translated: The women, though they be so, they call them of the man. The blind one, though he have no eyes, seeth. The son who is a sage hath understood this. He who knoweth them is the father of his father.

original: sākaṃjānām saptatham āhuḥ ekajam ṣaṭ id yamāḥ ṛṣayaḥ deva jāḥ iti / teṣām iṣṭāni vihitāni dhāmaśas sthātre rejante vikṛtāni rūpaśas //
analyzed: sākaṃjānām saptatham āhuḥ ekajam ṣaṭ id yamāḥ ṛṣayaḥ deva jāḥ iti   teṣām iṣṭāni vihitāni dhāmaśas sthātre rejante vikṛtāni rūpaśas  /
translated: The seven, they say, are the brothers of the twins. The six are the Rishis, the sons of the gods. Their portions are assigned in their several abodes. The various forms shine forth in their several forms.

original: avas pareṇa paras enāḥ avareṇa padā vatsam bibhratī gauḥ ud asthāt / sā kadrīcī kam svid ardham parāgāt kva svid sūte nahi yūthe asmin /
analyzed: avas pareṇa paras enāḥ avareṇa padā vatsam bibhratī gauḥ ud asthāt    sā kadrīcī kam svid ardham parāgāt kva svid sūte nahi yūthe asmin  /
translated: The cow, bearing her calf, hath risen up, with a foot above, and a foot below, and a foot beyond. She, looking askance, hath gone away to some place. Where hath she brought forth? Not in this herd.

original: avas pareṇa pitaram yaḥ asya veda avas pareṇa paras enā avareṇa / kavīyamānaḥ kaḥ iha pra vocat devam manaḥ kutas adhi prajātam /
analyzed: avas pareṇa pitaram yaḥ asya veda avas pareṇa paras enā avareṇa    kavīyamānaḥ kaḥ iha pra vocat devam manaḥ kutas adhi prajātam  /
translated: He who knows the father better than the son, and the son better than the father, he is the Brahman. He who knows the past better than the future, and the future better than the past, he is the Brahman. He who knows the unseen better than the seen, and the seen better than the unseen, he is the Brahman.

original: ye arvāñcaḥ tām u parācaḥ āhuḥ ye parāñcaḥ tām u arvācaḥ āhuḥ / indraḥ ca yā cakrathuḥ soma tāni dhurā na yuktāḥ rajasaḥ vahanti //
analyzed: ye arvāñcaḥ tām u parācaḥ āhuḥ ye parāñcaḥ tām u arvācaḥ āhuḥ   indraḥ ca yā cakrathuḥ soma tāni dhurā na yuktāḥ rajasaḥ vahanti  /
translated: Those that are coming hither they call the going ones; those that are going away they call the coming ones. O Indra and Soma, those deeds of yours which are yoked like two yoked oxen, they carry you through the realm.

original: dvā suparṇā sayujā sakhāyā samānam vṛkṣam pari sasvajāte / tayoḥ anyaḥ pippalam svādu atti an aśnan anyaḥ abhi cākaśīti //
analyzed: dvā suparṇā sayujā sakhāyā samānam vṛkṣam pari sasvajāte    tayoḥ anyaḥ pippalam svādu atti an aśnan anyaḥ abhi cākaśīti  /
translated: Two birds, companions, friends, cling to the same tree. One of them eats the sweet fig; the other, not eating, observes him.

original: yasmin vṛkṣe madhu adaḥ suparṇāḥ niviśante suvate ca adhi viśve / tasya yat āhuḥ pippalam svādu agre tat na ud naśat yaḥ pitaram na veda /
analyzed: yasmin vṛkṣe madhu adaḥ suparṇāḥ niviśante suvate ca adhi viśve   tasya yat āhuḥ pippalam svādu agre tat na ud naśat yaḥ pitaram na veda  /
translated: In that tree, O honey-eating birds, in which all the birds find a home and multiply, the sweet fig which they say is at the top, that is not to be had by him who knows not the father.

original: yatra suparṇāḥ amṛtasya bhakṣam animeṣam vidathāḥ abhisvaranti / enā viśvasya bhuvanasya gopāḥ sa mā dhīraḥ pākam atrā viveśa // // // viveśa // // // viśvasya bhuvanasya gopāḥ sa mā dhīraḥ pākam atrā viveśa // // //
analyzed: yatra suparṇāḥ amṛtasya bhakṣam animeṣam vidathāḥ abhisvaranti   enā viśvasya bhuvanasya gopāḥ sa mā dhīraḥ pākam atrā viveśa               viśvasya bhuvanasya gopāḥ sa mā dhīraḥ pākam atrā viveśa
translated: Where the unwinking birds, the Suparṇas, the immortal ones, sing out their songs together. They, the guardians of all the world, have entered me, the wise one, the cook, here.🔽What is placed in the Gāyatrī, the Gāyatrī itself, or what is fashioned from the Triṣṭubh,

original: yat gāyatre adhi gāyatram āhitam traiṣṭubham vā traiṣṭubhāt niratakṣata / yat vā jagat jagati āhitam padam ye id tat viduḥ te amṛta tvam ānuśuḥ //
analyzed: yat gāyatre adhi gāyatram āhitam traiṣṭubham vā traiṣṭubhāt niratakṣata   yat vā jagat jagati āhitam padam ye id tat viduḥ te amṛta tvam ānuśuḥ  /
translated: What is placed in the Jagatī, the Jagatī itself, those who know that have attained immortality.🔽He measures the Arka with the Gāyatrī, the Sāman with the Arka, the Vāka with the Triṣṭubh,

original: gāyatreṇa prati mimīte arkam arkeṇa sāma traiṣṭubhena vākam / vākena vākam dvipadā catuṣpadā akṣareṇa mimate sapta vāṇīḥ /
analyzed: gāyatreṇa prati mimīte arkam arkeṇa sāma traiṣṭubhena vākam   vākena vākam dvipadā catuṣpadā akṣareṇa mimate sapta vāṇīḥ  /
translated: The Vāka with the Vāka, the two-footed and four-footed, with the syllable they measure the seven tongues.

original: jagatā sindhum divi askabhāyat rathaṃtare sūryam pari apaśyat / gāyatrasya samidhaḥ tisraḥ āhuḥ tatas mahnā pra ririce mahitvā /
analyzed: jagatā sindhum divi askabhāyat rathaṃtare sūryam pari apaśyat   gāyatrasya samidhaḥ tisraḥ āhuḥ tatas mahnā pra ririce mahitvā  /
translated: He has set the river in the Jagatī in the sky, in the Rathantara he has seen the sun. They say the Gāyatrī has three kindling-verses, by its greatness it has surpassed them in greatness.

original: upa hvaye su dughām dhenum etām su hastaḥ go dhuk uta dohat enām / śreṣṭham savam savitā sāviṣat naḥ abhīddhaḥ gharmaḥ tat u su pra vocat /🔽hiṅkṛṇvatī vasu patnī vasūnām vatsam ichantī manasā abhyāgāt / duhām aśvibhyām payaḥ aghnyā iyam sā vardhatām mahate saubhagāya //🔽gauḥ amīmet abhi vatsam miṣantam mūrdhānam hiṅ akṛṇot mātave u / sṛkvāṇam gharmam abhi vāvaśānā mimāti māyum payate payobhiḥ /
analyzed: upa hvaye su dughām dhenum etām su hastaḥ go duh uta dohat enām    śreṣṭham savam savitā sāviṣat naḥ abhīddhaḥ gharmaḥ tat u su pra vocat  / hiṅkṛṇvatī vasu patnī vasūnām vatsam icchantī manasā abhyāgāt    duhām aśvibhyām payaḥ aghnyā iyam sā vardhatām mahate saubhagāya  / gauḥ amīmet abhi vatsam miṣantam mūrdhānam hiṅ akṛṇot mātave u sṛkvāṇam gharmam abhi vāvaśānā mimāti māyum payate payobhiḥ  /
translated: I call to her, the milch-cow, easy to milk, and let the skilful milker milk her well. May Savitar pour forth for us most plenteous milk. The caldron hath been heated: let him speak the word.🔽The Vasus' consort, lowing, hath come nigh, longing in spirit for her calf. Let this my milch-cow yield milk for the two Asvins. May she increase to great felicity.🔽The Cow hath moved, approaching to her bellowing calf. She hath lowed to her young one, to her head. Lowing to the steaming caldron, she, the milch-cow, hath filled it with her milk.

original: ayam sa śiṅkte yena gauḥ abhivṛtā mimāti mayum dhvasanau adhi śritā / sā cittibhiḥ ni hi cakāra martyān vidyut bhavantī prati vavrim auhata //
analyzed: ayam sa śiṅkte yena gauḥ abhivṛtā mimāti mayum dhvasanau adhi śritā    sā cittibhiḥ ni hi cakāra martyān vidyut bhavantī prati vavrim auhata  /
translated: She hath lowed with the sound whereby the Cow is covered. She hath moved the wild beast to destruction, seated on the dust. With her thoughts she hath made the mortal men to tremble. The lightning hath come, and hath taken away the mist.

original: anat śaye turagātu jīvam ejat dhruvam madhye ā pastyānām / jīvaḥ mṛtasya carati svadhābhiḥ amartyaḥ martyena sayoniḥ /
analyzed: anat śaye turagātu jīvam ejat dhruvam madhye ā pastyānām    jīvaḥ mṛtasya carati svadhābhiḥ amartyaḥ martyena sayoniḥ  /
translated: The living, moving, swift-paced life is laid within the house between the two world-halves. The life of the dead man moves on with the Svadha-calls. Immortal, of the same womb as the mortal.

original: vidhum dadrāṇam salilasya pṛṣṭhe yuvānam santam palitaḥ jagāra / devasya paśya kāvyam mahitvā adya mamāra sa hyaḥ sam āna /🔽yaḥ īm cakāra na saḥ asya veda yaḥ īm dadarśa hiruk id nu tasmāt / sa mātuḥ yonā parivītaḥ antar bahu prajāḥ nirṛtiḥ ā viveśa // sa mātuḥ yonā parivītaḥ antar bahu prajāḥ nirṛtiḥ ā viveśa // // sa mātuḥ yonā parivītaḥ antar bahu prajāḥ nirṛtiḥ ā viveśa // // sa mātuḥ yonā parivītaḥ antar bahu prajāḥ nirṛtiḥ ā viveśa // // sa mātuḥ yonā parivītaḥ antar bahu prajāḥ nirṛtiḥ ā viveśa // // sa mātuḥ yonā par
analyzed: vidhum dadrāṇam salilasya pṛṣṭhe yuvānam santam palitaḥ jagāra   devasya paśya kāvyam mahitvā adya mamāra sa hyaḥ sam āna  / yaḥ īm cakāra na saḥ asya veda yaḥ īm dadarśa hiruk id nu tasmāt    sa mātuḥ yonā parivītaḥ antar bahu prajāḥ nirṛtiḥ ā viveśa    sa mātuḥ yonā parivītaḥ antar bahu prajāḥ nirṛtiḥ ā viveśa
translated: The grey-haired one hath swallowed up the youthful Moon, who runs upon the surface of the waters. Behold the greatness of the God's contrivance. He died to-day, and now he lives again.🔽He who hath made him knoweth him not: he who hath looked upon him is confounded. He, wrapped about in his mother's bosom, hath entered into many a place of secret woe.

original: apaśyam gopām a nipadyamānam ā ca parā ca pathibhiḥ carantam / sa sadhrīcīḥ sa viṣūcīḥ vasānaḥ ā varīvarti bhuvaneṣu antar /
analyzed: apaśyam gopām a nipadyamānam ā ca parā ca pathibhiḥ carantam    sa sadhrīcīḥ sa viṣūcīḥ vasānaḥ ā varīvarti bhuvaneṣu antar  /
translated: I saw the Guardian, who standeth not with feet, but moveth on his paths to and fro. He, clothed with the directions and the regions, goeth between the worlds.

original: dyauḥ naḥ pitā janitā nābhiḥ atra bandhuḥ naḥ mātā pṛthivī mahī iyam / uttānayoḥ camvoḥ yoniḥ antar atrā pitā duhituḥ garbham ādhāt //
analyzed: dyauḥ naḥ pitā janitā nābhiḥ atra bandhuḥ naḥ mātā pṛthivī mahī iyam    uttānayoḥ camvoḥ yoniḥ antar atrā pitā duhituḥ garbham ādhāt  /
translated: Heaven is our Father, our begetter, our kin; this great Earth is our Mother, our relation. Between the two extended bowls the Womb is laid: the Father hath deposited the Daughter's germ.

original: pṛchāmi tvā param antam pṛthivyāḥ pṛchāmi vṛṣṇaḥ aśvasya retaḥ / pṛchāmi viśvasya bhuvanasya nābhim pṛchāmi vācaḥ paramam vyoma //
analyzed: pṛcchāmi tvā param antam pṛthivyāḥ pṛcchāmi vṛṣṇaḥ aśvasya retaḥ   pṛcchāmi viśvasya bhuvanasya nābhim pṛcchāmi vācaḥ paramam vyoma  /
translated: I ask thee of the earth's extremest limit, I ask of the seed of the strong courser. I ask of the navel of the universe, I ask of the highest sphere of speech.

original: iyam vediḥ paraḥ antar pṛthivyāḥ ayam somaḥ vṛṣṇaḥ aśvasya retaḥ / ayam yajñaḥ viśvasya bhuvanasya nābhiḥ brahmā ayam vācaḥ paramam vyoma //
analyzed: iyam vediḥ paraḥ antar pṛthivyāḥ ayam somaḥ vṛṣṇaḥ aśvasya retaḥ   ayam yajñaḥ viśvasya bhuvanasya nābhiḥ brahmā ayam vācaḥ paramam vyoma  /
translated: This is the altar, the extremest limit of the earth; this is the seed of the strong courser Soma; this is the navel of the universe, the sacrifice; this is the highest sphere of speech, the Brahman.

original: na vi jānāmi yat iva idam asmi niṇyaḥ saṃnaddhaḥ manasā carāmi / yadā mā agan prathama jāḥ ṛtasya āt id vācaḥ aśnuve bhāgam asyāḥ /
analyzed: na vi jānāmi yat iva idam asmi niṇyaḥ saṃnaddhaḥ manasā carāmi    yadā mā agan prathama jāḥ ṛtasya āt id vācaḥ aśnuve bhāgam asyāḥ  /
translated: I know not what this thing is that I am: I go about bound with the mind to a goal. When the first-born of truth came to me, then I obtained a share in this speech.

original: apāṅ prāṅ eti svadhayā gṛbhītaḥ amartyaḥ martyena sayoniḥ / tā śaśvantā viṣūcīnāḥ viyantā ni anyam cikyuḥ na ni cikyuḥ anyam /
analyzed: apāṅ prāṅ eti svadhayā gṛbhītaḥ amartyaḥ martyena sayoniḥ   tā śaśvantā viṣūcīnāḥ viyantā ni anyam cikyuḥ na ni cikyuḥ anyam  /
translated: He goes to the east, seized by his own nature, immortal, of the same birth as the mortal. They, ever moving, going in opposite directions, have sought one another, but have not found each other.

original: sapta ardha garbhāḥ bhuvanasya retaḥ viṣṇoḥ tiṣṭhanti pradiśā vidharmaṇi / te dhītibhiḥ manasā te vipaścitaḥ paribhuvaḥ pari bhavanti viśvatas /
analyzed: sapta ardha garbhāḥ bhuvanasya retaḥ viṣṇoḥ tiṣṭhanti pradiśā vidharmaṇi   te dhītibhiḥ manasā te vipaścitaḥ paribhuvaḥ pari bhavanti viśvatas  /
translated: Seven are the half-formed embryos of the world's seed, which in the region of the sky abide in Vishnu's place. They, wise in mind, with thoughts, the all-sustaining ones, are round about us on all sides.

original: ṛcaḥ akṣare parame vyoman yasmin devāḥ adhi viśve niṣeduḥ / yaḥ tat na veda kim ṛcā kariṣyati ye id tat viduḥ te amī sam āsate /
analyzed: ṛcaḥ akṣare parame vyoman yasmin devāḥ adhi viśve niṣeduḥ   yaḥ tat na veda kim ṛcā kariṣyati ye id tat viduḥ te amī sam āsate  /
translated: The Rikas in the highest imperishable sphere, where all the Gods are seated, have their home. What will he do who knows not that? But they who know it are assembled here.

original: ṛcaḥ padam mātrayā kalpayantaḥ ardharcena cakḷpuḥ viśvam ejat / tripād brahma puru rūpam vi taṣṭhe tena jīvanti pradiśaḥ catasraḥ /
analyzed: ṛcaḥ padam mātrayā kalpayantaḥ ardharcena cakḷpuḥ viśvam ejat  / tripād brahma puru rūpam vi taṣṭhe tena jīvanti pradiśaḥ catasraḥ  /
translated: The Rikas, measuring by the metre, have made the foot of the Rikas. By the half-verse they have measured all that moves. The Brahman, of three feet, of many forms, is spread abroad. By it the four regions of space are sustained.

original: sūyavasāt bhagavatī hi bhūyāḥ adhā vayam bhagavantaḥ syāma / addhi tṛṇam aghnye viśvadānīm piba śuddham udakam ācarantī // tṛṇam aghnye viśvadānīm piba śuddham udakam ācarantī // tṛṇam aghnye viśvadānīm piba śuddham udakam ācarantī // tṛṇam aghnye viśvadānīm piba śuddham udakam ācarantī // tṛṇam aghnye viśvadānīm piba śuddham udakam ācarantī // tṛṇam aghnye viśvadānīm piba śuddham udakam ācarantī // tṛṇam aghnye viśvadānīm
analyzed: sūyavasāt bhagavatī hi bhūyāḥ adhā vayam bhagavantaḥ syāma     addhi tṛṇam aghnye viśvadānīm piba śuddham udakam ācarantī    tṛṇam aghnye viśvadānīm piba śuddham udakam ācarantī     /
translated: Eat the grass, O thou of the house, at all times. Drink the pure water, O thou that goest about.🔽Eat the grass, O thou of the house, at all times. Drink the pure water, O thou that goest about.🔽The Cow, the only-footed, the two-footed, the four-footed, the eight-footed, the nine-footed, the thousand-eyed, the line of the world, she, the Cow, hath measured the waters, and formed them.

original: gauḥ id mimāya salilāni takṣatī ekapadī dvipadī sā catuṣpadī / aṣṭāpadī navapadī babhūvuṣī sahasra akṣarā bhuvanasya paṅktiḥ tasyāḥ samudrāḥ adhi vi kṣaranti /
analyzed: gauḥ id mimāya salilāni takṣatī ekapadī dvipadī sā catuṣpadī    aṣṭāpadī navapadī babhūvuṣī sahasra akṣarā bhuvanasya paṅktiḥ tasyāḥ samudrāḥ adhi vi kṣaranti  /
translated: The oceans flow upon her.

original: kṛṣṇam niyānam harayaḥ suparṇāḥ apaḥ vasānāḥ divam ud patanti / tam āvavṛtran sadanāt ṛtasya āt id ghṛtena pṛthivīm vi ūduḥ /
analyzed: kṛṣṇam niyānam harayaḥ suparṇāḥ apaḥ vasānāḥ divam ud patanti   tam āvavṛtran sadanāt ṛtasya āt id ghṛtena pṛthivīm vi ūduḥ  /
translated: The black-backed birds, the tawny-coloured birds, the birds with golden wings, clothed in water, fly up to heaven. They have covered him from the seat of truth, and with ghee have they anointed the earth.

original: apād eti prathamā padvatīnām kaḥ tat vām mitrāvaruṇā ciketa / garbhaḥ bhāram bharati ā cit asyāḥ ṛtam piparti anṛtam ni pāti /
analyzed: apād eti prathamā padvatīnām kaḥ tat vām mitrāvaruṇā ciketa    garbhaḥ bhāram bharati ā cit asyāḥ ṛtam piparti anṛtam ni pāti  /
translated: She goeth forth, the first of all that move in lines. Who hath observed your law, O Varuṇa and Mitra? The child beareth the burden of this (earth). Truth nourisheth, and falsehood guardeth it.

original: virāj vāc virāj pṛthivī virāj antarikṣam virāj prajāpatiḥ / virāj mṛtyuḥ sādhyānām adhirājaḥ babhūva tasya bhūtam bhavyam vaśe sa me bhūtam bhavyam vaśe kṛṇotu //
analyzed: virāj vāc virāj pṛthivī virāj antarikṣam virāj prajāpatiḥ   virāj mṛtyuḥ sādhyānām adhirājaḥ babhūva tasya bhūtam bhavyam vaśe sa me bhūtam bhavyam vaśe kṛṇotu  /
translated: The Virāj is speech, the Virāj is earth, the Virāj is the atmosphere, the Virāj is Prajāpati. The Virāj is death, the overlord of the Sādhyas. May it be in my power to control the past and the future.

original: śaka mayam dhūmam ārāt apaśyam viṣūvatā paras enā avareṇa / ukṣāṇam pṛśnim apacanta vīrāḥ tāni dharmāṇi prathamāni āsan /
analyzed: śaka mayam dhūmam ārāt apaśyam viṣūvatā paras enā avareṇa   ukṣāṇam pṛśnim apacanta vīrāḥ tāni dharmāṇi prathamāni āsan  /
translated: I have seen the smoke of the sacrificial butter from afar, which hath passed away above and below. The heroes have cooked the speckled bull. These were the first ordinances.

original: trayaḥ keśinaḥ ṛtuthā vi cakṣate saṃvatsare vapate ekaḥ eṣām / viśvam anyaḥ abhicaṣṭe śacībhiḥ dhrājiḥ ekasya dadṛśe na rūpam /
analyzed: trayaḥ keśinaḥ ṛtuthā vi cakṣate saṃvatsare vapate ekaḥ eṣām    viśvam anyaḥ abhicaṣṭe śacībhiḥ dhrājiḥ ekasya dadṛśe na rūpam  /
translated: Three Keśins, in due season, look around. One of them in the year casts off his skin. The other pervadeth all with his might. The course of the third is seen, but not his form.

original: catvāri vāc parimitā padāni tāni viduḥ brāhmaṇāḥ ye manīṣiṇaḥ / guhā trīṇi nihitā na iṅgayanti turīyam vācaḥ manuṣyāḥ vadanti //
analyzed: catvāri vāc parimitā padāni tāni viduḥ brāhmaṇāḥ ye manīṣiṇaḥ   guhā trīṇi nihitā na iṅgayanti turīyam vācaḥ manuṣyāḥ vadanti  /
translated: Four are the limits set to speech: the wise Brāhmans know them, they who are learned. Three are concealed in secret, they move not: the fourth is the speech of men.🔽They call him Indra, Mitra, Varuṇa, Agni, and also the divine bird Garuḍa of fair wings. The one existing, the learned call by many names: they call him Agni, Yama, Mātariśvan.

original: indram mitram varuṇam agnim āhuḥ atha u divyaḥ sa suparṇaḥ garutmān / ekam sat viprāḥ bahudhā vadanti agnim yamam mātariśvānam āhuḥ // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // //🔽yām kalpayanti vahatau vadhūm iva viśva rūpām hasta kṛtām cikitsavaḥ / sārāt etu apa nudāmaḥ enām /
analyzed: indram mitram varuṇam agnim āhuḥ atha u divyaḥ sa suparṇaḥ garutmān    ekam sat viprāḥ bahudhā vadanti agnim yamam mātariśvānam āhuḥ  yām kalpayanti vahatau vadhūm iva viśva rūpām hasta kṛtām cikitsavaḥ   sārāt etu apa nudāmaḥ enām  /
translated: The one whom the physicians make like a bride, all-formed, fashioned with the hands, to carry the sick, from the essence let her come forth: we drive her away.

original: śīrṣaṇvatī nasvatī karṇiṇī kṛtyā kṛtā saṃbhṛtā viśva rūpā / sārāt etu apa nudāmaḥ enām /
analyzed: śīrṣaṇvatī nasvatī karṇiṇī kṛtyā kṛtā saṃbhṛtā viśva rūpā    sārāt etu apa nudāmaḥ enām  /
translated: The one who has a head, who has a nose, who has ears, made by witchcraft, collected, all-formed, from the essence let her come forth: we drive her away.

original: śūdra kṛtā rāja kṛtā strī kṛtā brahmabhiḥ kṛtā / jāyā patyā nuttā iva kartāram bandhu ṛchatu //
analyzed: śūdra kṛtā rāja kṛtā strī kṛtā brahmabhiḥ kṛtā   jāyā patyā nuttā iva kartāram bandhu ṛchatu  /
translated: The curse that a Shudra, a king, a woman, or a Brahmana has pronounced, like a wife who is driven away by her husband, let it fall back on the one who pronounced it.

original: anayā aham oṣadhyā sarvāḥ kṛtyāḥ adūduṣam / yām kṣetre cakruḥ yām goṣu yām vā te puruṣeṣu /
analyzed: anayā aham oṣadhyā sarvāḥ kṛtyāḥ adūduṣam    yām kṣetre cakruḥ yām goṣu yām vā te puruṣeṣu
translated: By this herb I have destroyed all the curses, whether they were made in the field, in the cows, or in your men.

original: agham astu agha kṛte śapathaḥ śapathīyate / pratyak pratiprahiṇmaḥ yathā kṛtyā kṛtam hanat /
analyzed: agham astu agha kṛte śapathaḥ śapathīyate    pratyak pratiprahiṇmaḥ yathā kṛtyā kṛtam hanat  /
translated: Let there be evil for the one who has done evil, let the oath be taken by the one who has sworn. We send it back to the one who has done the curse, so that it may destroy the one who has done the curse.

original: pratīcīnaḥ āṅgirasaḥ adhyakṣaḥ naḥ purohitaḥ / pratīcīḥ kṛtyāḥ ākṛtya amūn kṛtyākṛtaḥ jahi //
analyzed: pratīcīnaḥ āṅgirasaḥ adhyakṣaḥ naḥ purohitaḥ   pratīcīḥ kṛtyāḥ ākṛtya amūn kṛtyākṛtaḥ jahi  /
translated: Pratichin, the son of Angiras, is our overseer and priest. Turn back the curses, and destroy these who have done the curse.

original: yaḥ tvā uvāca parehi iti pratikūlam udāyyam / tam kṛtye abhinivartasva mā asmān ichaḥ anāgasaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ tvā uvāca parehi iti pratikūlam udāyyam   tam kṛtye abhinivartasva mā asmān ichaḥ anāgasaḥ  /
translated: The one who told you to go against the rising sun, turn back the curse to him. Do not strike us who are innocent.

original: yaḥ te parūṃṣi saṃdadhau rathasya iva rbhuḥ dhiyā / tam gaccha tatra te ayanam a jñātaḥ te ayam janaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ te parūṃṣi saṃdadhau rathasya iva rbhuḥ dhiyā   tam gaccha tatra te ayanam a jñātaḥ te ayam janaḥ  /
translated: The one who put together your limbs like a chariot-maker with his mind, go to him. There is your course. This people is unknown to you.

original: ye tvā kṛtvā ālebhire vidvalāḥ abhicāriṇaḥ / śaṃbhu idam kṛtyā dūṣaṇam prativartma punaḥsaram tena tvā snapayāmasi //
analyzed: ye tvā kṛtvā ālebhire vidvalāḥ abhicāriṇaḥ    śaṃbhu idam kṛtyā dūṣaṇam prativartma punaḥsaram tena tvā snapayāmasi  /
translated: Those who, being learned and deceitful, have bound you up, O curse, go back to them, O curse, to the one who has done the curse. We sprinkle you with this auspicious curse-destroyer, which returns the curse to the one who has sent it.

original: yat durbhagām prasnapitām mṛta vatsām upeyima / apaitu sarvam mat pāpam draviṇam mā upa tiṣṭhatu // // // sarvam mat pāpam draviṇam mā upa tiṣṭhatu // // // sarvam mat pāpam draviṇam mā upa tiṣṭhatu // // // sarvam mat pāpam draviṇam mā upa tiṣṭhatu // // // sarvam mat pāpam draviṇam mā upa tiṣṭhatu // // // sarvam mat pāpam draviṇam mā upa tiṣṭhatu // // // sarvam mat pāpam draviṇam mā upa tiṣṭhatu // // // sarvam mat pāpa
analyzed: yat durbhagām prasnapitām mṛta vatsām upeyima   apaitu sarvam mat pāpam draviṇam mā upa tiṣṭhatu
translated: Whatever sin they have committed, whether in secret or openly, in thought, word, or deed, may all that sin of theirs be blotted out, and let not wealth forsake them.🔽Whatever name they have given thee when offering to the Fathers, or at sacrifice,

original: yat te pitṛbhyaḥ dadataḥ yajñe vā nāma jagṛhuḥ / saṃdeśyāt sarvasmāt pāpāt imāḥ muñcantu tvā oṣadhīḥ /
analyzed: yat te pitṛbhyaḥ dadataḥ yajñe vā nāma jagṛhuḥ   saṃdeśyāt sarvasmāt pāpāt imāḥ muñcantu tvā oṣadhīḥ  /
translated: from all sin, from all behest, from all the evil that is in thee, may these Plants deliver thee.🔽From sin against the Gods, from sin against the Fathers, from the behest of Namâgraha, from the sin that hath been wrought,

original: deva enasāt pitryāt nāma grāhāt saṃdeśyāt abhiniṣkṛtāt / muñcantu tvā vīrudhaḥ vīryeṇa brahmaṇā ṛgbhiḥ payasā ṛṣīṇām /
analyzed: deva enasāt pitryāt nāma grāhāt saṃdeśyāt abhiniṣkṛtāt   muñcantu tvā vīrudhaḥ vīryeṇa brahmaṇā ṛgbhiḥ payasā ṛṣīṇām  /
translated: from all sin may the Plants deliver thee with their heroic might, with prayer, with Ṛc, with milk of sages.

original: yathā vātaḥ cyāvayati bhūmyāḥ reṇum antarikṣāt ca abhram / eva mat sarvam durbhūtam brahma nuttam apāyati //
analyzed: yathā vātaḥ cyāvayati bhūmyāḥ reṇum antarikṣāt ca abhram   eva mat sarvam durbhūtam brahma nuttam apāyati  /
translated: even so may all evil be driven away from me, expelled by the Brahmanical power.🔽Go away, crying, unstrung, like a she-ass,

original: apa krāma nānadatī vinaddhā gardabhī iva / kartṝn nakṣasva itas nuttā brahmaṇā vīryāvatā /
analyzed: apa krāma nānadatī vinaddhā gardabhī iva  / kartṝn nakṣasva itas nuttā brahmaṇā vīryāvatā  /
translated: seek out the doers of this deed. Thou art driven away by the powerful Brahman.

original: ayam panthāḥ kṛtyā iti tvā nayāmaḥ abhiprahitām prati tvā pra hiṇmaḥ / tena abhi yāhi bhañjati anasvatī iva vāhinī viśva rūpā kurūtinī /
analyzed: ayam panthāḥ kṛtyā iti tvā nayāmaḥ abhiprahitām prati tvā pra hiṇmaḥ   tena abhi yāhi bhañjati anasvatī iva vāhinī viśva rūpā kurūtinī  /
translated: This is the way, O Kṛtyā, we lead thee, sent forth. We send thee back to him who sent thee forth. Go by that way. Thou art broken like a yoke-bearing ox, multiform, destructive.

original: parāk te jyotiḥ apatham te arvāk anyatra asmat ayanā kṛṇuṣva / pareṇa ihi navatim nāvyāḥ ati durgāḥ srotyāḥ mā kṣaṇiṣṭhāḥ parehi /
analyzed: parāk te jyotiḥ apatham te arvāk anyatra asmat ayanā kṛṇuṣva   pareṇa ihi navatim nāvyāḥ ati durgāḥ srotyāḥ mā kṣaṇiṣṭhāḥ parehi  /
translated: Thy light is far away, thy path is far away. Make thou our paths elsewhere. Go away beyond the ninety floods, the difficult-to-pass streams. Do not stay. Go away.

original: vātaḥ iva vṛkṣān ni mṛṇīhi pādaya mā gām aśvam puruṣam ud śiṣaḥ eṣām / kartṝn nivṛtya itas kṛtye a prajāstvāya bodhaya //
analyzed: vātaḥ iva vṛkṣān ni mṛṇīhi pādaya mā gām aśvam puruṣam ud śiṣaḥ eṣām    kartṝn nivṛtya itas kṛtye a prajāstvāya bodhaya  /
translated: Like the wind crush and overthrow the trees. Do not destroy their kine, their horses, their men. Turning away the doers of this deed from here, O Kṛtyā, deprive them of offspring. Wake them up.

original: yām te barhiṣi yām śmaśāne kṣetre kṛtyām valagam vā nicakhnuḥ / agnau vā tvā gārhapatye abhiceruḥ pākam santam dhīratarāḥ anāgasam /
analyzed: yām te barhiṣi yām śmaśāne kṣetre kṛtyām valagam vā nicakhnuḥ   agnau vā tvā gārhapatye abhiceruḥ pākam santam dhīratarāḥ anāgasam  /
translated: The spell, the curse, the magic power which they have buried in the grass, in the cremation ground, in the field, or in the fire, O Gārhapatya, against thee, the innocent, the wise, the cooked,

original: upāhṛtam anubuddham nikhātam vairam tsārī anu avidāma kartram / tat etu yatas ābhṛtam tatra aśvaḥ iva vi vartatām hantu kṛtyākṛtaḥ prajām /
analyzed: upāhṛtam anubuddham nikhātam vairam tsārī anu avidāma kartram   tat etu yatas ābhṛtam tatra aśvaḥ iva vi vartatām hantu kṛtyākṛtaḥ prajām  /
translated: The curse which we have found, discovered, dug up, the curse which we have traced to him who wrought it, thither let it go again, whence it was brought hither. Like a horse let it return to him who sent it. Destroy the progeny of him who wrought the spell.

original: tiṣṭha eva parehi itas a jñāte kim iha icchasi // // tiṣṭha eva parehi itas a jñāte kim iha icchasi // // tiṣṭha eva parehi itas a jñāte kim iha icchasi // // tiṣṭha eva parehi itas a jñāte kim iha icchasi // // tiṣṭha eva parehi itas a jñāte kim iha icchasi // // tiṣṭha eva parehi itas a jñāte kim iha icchasi // // tiṣṭha eva parehi itas a jñāte kim iha icchasi // // tiṣṭha eva parehi itas a jñāte kim iha icchasi // // tiṣṭha eva parehi
analyzed: tiṣṭha eva parehi itas a jñāte kim iha icchasi       tiṣṭha eva parehi itas a jñāte kim iha icchasi                                                               eva parehi itas a jñāte kim iha icchasi           eva parehi itas a jñāte kim iha icchasi         eva parehi itas a jñāte kim iha icchasi          eva parehi itas a jñāte kim iha icchasi              eva parehi itas a jñāte kim iha icchasi               eva parehi itas a jñāte kim iha icchasi
translated: Stay here, or go hence, unknown. What wouldst thou here?🔽I will break thy neck and thy feet, O thou that art to be destroyed.

original: grīvāḥ te kṛtye pādau ca api kartsyāmi niḥ drava / indra agnī asmān rakṣatām yau prajānām prajāvatī /
analyzed: grīvāḥ te kṛtye pādau ca api kartsyāmi niḥ drava   indra agnī asmān rakṣatām yau prajānām prajāvatī  /
translated: May Indra and Agni protect us, who are the most prolific of offspring among men.

original: somaḥ rājā adhipāḥ mṛḍitā ca bhūtasya naḥ patayaḥ mṛḍayantu //
analyzed: somaḥ rājā adhipāḥ mṛḍitā ca bhūtasya naḥ patayaḥ mṛḍayantu
translated: May Soma, the king, the lord, and Mṛḍitā, the mistresses of creatures, be gracious unto us.

original: bhava śarvau asyatām pāpa kṛte kṛtyā kṛte / duṣkṛte vidyutam deva hetim /
analyzed: bhava śarvau asyatām pāpa kṛte kṛtyā kṛte   duṣkṛte vidyutam deva hetim  /
translated: Bhava and Śarva, let the bolt of the gods, the lightning, fall upon the evildoer, the worker of witchcraft, the doer of evil.

original: yadi eyatha dvipadī catuṣpadī kṛtyā kṛtā saṃbhṛtā viśva rūpā / sā itas aṣṭāpadī bhūtvā punar parehi duchune /
analyzed: yadi eyatha dvipadī catuṣpadī kṛtyā kṛtā saṃbhṛtā viśva rūpā    sā itas aṣṭāpadī bhūtvā punar parehi duchune  /
translated: Go hence, O mischief, having become eight-footed, and go to another place.🔽Anointed, smeared, and well-adorned, bearing away all evil, go hence.

original: abhyakta aktā svaraṃkṛtā sarvam bharantī duritam parehi / jānīhi kṛtye kartāram duhitā iva pitaram svam /
analyzed: abhyakta aktā svaraṃkṛtā sarvam bharantī duritam parehi   jānīhi kṛtye kartāram duhitā iva pitaram svam  /
translated: Know the doer of the deed, as a daughter knows her own father.🔽Go away, O mischief, do not stay, as one leads the foot of one who is pierced.

original: parehi kṛtye mā tiṣṭhaḥ viddhasya iva padam naya / mṛgaḥ sa mṛgayuḥ tvam na tvā nikartum arhati //
analyzed: parehi kṛtye mā tiṣṭhaḥ viddhasya iva padam naya   mṛgaḥ sa mṛgayuḥ tvam na tvā nikartum arhati  /
translated: Thou art a deer, he is a hunter; he ought not to injure thee.

original: uta hanti pūrva asinam pratyādāya aparaḥ iṣvā / uta pūrvasya nighnataḥ ni hanti aparaḥ prati /
analyzed: uta hanti pūrva asinam pratyādāya aparaḥ iṣvā    uta pūrvasya nighnataḥ ni hanti aparaḥ prati  /
translated: He slays the one who comes first, taking up the weapon, and the other slays the one who is slaying the first.🔽Listen to these words of mine, then go whither thou camest from.

original: etat hi śṛṇu me vacaḥ atha ihi yatas eyatha / yaḥ tvā cakāra tam prati /
analyzed: etat hi śṛṇu me vacaḥ atha ihi yatas eyatha   yaḥ tvā cakāra tam prati
translated: To him who made thee, to him go back.🔽The slaughter of a cow is terrible, O mischief; do not slay our cow, our horse, or our man.

original: anāgohatyā vai bhīmā kṛtye mā naḥ gām aśvam puruṣam vadhīḥ / yatra yatra asi nihitā tatas tvā ud thāpayāmasi parṇāt laghīyasī bhava /
analyzed: anāgohatyā vai bhīmā kṛtye mā naḥ gām aśvam puruṣam vadhīḥ   yatra yatra asi nihitā tatas tvā ud thāpayāmasi parṇāt laghīyasī bhava  /
translated: Whithersoever thou art laid, thence we raise thee up. Be lighter than a leaf.

original: yadi stha tamasā āvṛtāḥ jālena abhihitāḥ iva / sarvāḥ saṃlupya itas kṛtyāḥ punar kartre pra hiṇmasi //
analyzed: yadi stha tamasā āvṛtāḥ jālena abhihitāḥ iva    sarvāḥ saṃlupya itas kṛtyāḥ punar kartre pra hiṇmasi  /
translated: If ye are covered with the darkness, as if ye were enclosed within a net, We crush together all the curses here, and send them back again to him who cursed.

original: kṛtyā kṛtaḥ valaginaḥ abhiniṣkāriṇaḥ prajām / mṛṇīhi kṛtye mā ud śiṣaḥ amūn kṛtyā kṛtaḥ jahi //
analyzed: kṛtyā kṛtaḥ valaginaḥ abhiniṣkāriṇaḥ prajām   mṛṇīhi kṛtye mā ud śiṣaḥ amūn kṛtyā kṛtaḥ jahi  /
translated: The curse-workers, the sorcerers, the mischief-makers, and the men who injure offspring, Crush them, O Curse, and leave not one alive. Destroy the men who work with curses.

original: eva aham sarvam durbhūtam kartram kṛtyā kṛtā kṛtam hastī iva rajaḥ duritam jahāmi // // iva rajaḥ duritam jahāmi //🔽kena pārṣṇī ābhṛte pūruṣasya kena māṃsam saṃbhṛtam kena gulphau / kena aṅgulīḥ peśanīḥ kena khāni kena ucchlaṅkhau madhyataḥ kaḥ pratiṣṭhām /
analyzed: eva aham sarvam durbhūtam kartram kṛtyā kṛtā kṛtam hastī iva rajaḥ duritam jahāmi       iva rajaḥ duritam jahāmi  kena pārṣṇī ābhṛte pūruṣasya kena māṃsam saṃbhṛtam kena gulphau   kena aṅgulīḥ peśanīḥ kena khāni kena ucchlaṅkhau madhyataḥ kaḥ pratiṣṭhām  /
translated: Thus I cast off all evil, the curse-worker, the sorcerer, the man who works with curses, as an elephant shakes off the dust, as an elephant shakes off the mire.🔽By what was the heel of man constructed? By what was flesh and sinew gathered? By what the ankle-bones? By what the toes? By what the joints? By what the knee-bones? By what the thighs? By what the waist?

original: kasmāt nu gulphau adharau akṛṇvan aṣṭhīvantau uttarau puruṣasya / jaṅghe nirṛtya ni adadhuḥ kva svid jānunoḥ saṃdhī kaḥ u tat ciketa /
analyzed: kasmāt nu gulphau adharau akṛṇvan aṣṭhīvantau uttarau puruṣasya   jaṅghe nirṛtya ni adadhuḥ kva svid jānunoḥ saṃdhī kaḥ u tat ciketa  /
translated: Why did they make the ankles of man so low, and the knee-bones so high? Where did they place the shanks? Who knows the joining of the knees?

original: catuṣṭayam yujate saṃhitā antam jānubhyām ūrdhvam śithiram kabandham / śroṇī yat ūrū kaḥ u tat jajāna yābhyām kusindham su dṛḍham babhūva //
analyzed: catuṣṭayam yujate saṃhitā antam jānubhyām ūrdhvam śithiram kabandham   śroṇī yat ūrū kaḥ u tat jajāna yābhyām kusindham su dṛḍham babhūva  /
translated: The four are yoked together, the trunk above the knees is loose and shapeless. Who made the hips and thighs, whence the firm-jointed knee was formed?

original: kati devāḥ katame te āsan ye uraḥ grīvāḥ cikyuḥ puruṣasya / kati stanau vi adadhuḥ kaḥ kaphodau kati skandhān kati pṛṣṭīḥ acinvan /
analyzed: kati devāḥ katame te āsan ye uraḥ grīvāḥ cikyuḥ puruṣasya    kati stanau vi adadhuḥ kaḥ kaphodau kati skandhān kati pṛṣṭīḥ acinvan  /
translated: How many Gods were there, and who were they, who formed the breast and neck of man? How many set his two breasts? Who made his shoulders? How many formed his ribs?

original: kaḥ asya bāhū sam abharat vīryām karavāt iti / aṃsau kaḥ asya tat devaḥ kusindhe adhi ā dadhau //
analyzed: kaḥ asya bāhū sam abharat vīryām karavāt iti   aṃsau kaḥ asya tat devaḥ kusindhe adhi ā dadhau
translated: Who put together his two arms, that they might be strong and able to do all things? Who, the God, set them on his shoulders, on the firm-jointed neck?

original: kaḥ sapta khāni vi tatarda śīrṣaṇi karṇau imau nāsike cakṣaṇī mukham / yeṣām purutrā vijayasya mahnani catuṣpādaḥ dvipadaḥ yanti yāmam /
analyzed: kaḥ sapta khāni vi tatarda śīrṣaṇi karṇau imau nāsike cakṣaṇī mukham    yeṣām purutrā vijayasya mahnani catuṣpādaḥ dvipadaḥ yanti yāmam  /
translated: Who opened the seven cavities in the head? Who made these two ears, and these two nostrils, and these two eyes, and this mouth? By whom, in the great sacrifice of conquest, in many places, the four-footed and the two-footed go their way?

original: hanvoḥ hi jihvām adadhāt purūcīm adhāḥ mahīm adhi śiśrāya vācam / saḥ ā varīvarti bhuvaneṣu antar apaḥ vasānaḥ kaḥ u tat ciketa /
analyzed: hanvoḥ hi jihvām adadhāt purūcīm adhāḥ mahīm adhi śiśrāya vācam    saḥ ā varīvarti bhuvaneṣu antar apaḥ vasānaḥ kaḥ u tat ciketa  /
translated: He set the tongue in the jaws, the great one, and placed speech on the head. He moves about in the midst of the worlds, clothed in the waters. Who knows that?

original: mastiṣkam asya yatamaḥ lalātam kakāṭikām prathamaḥ yaḥ kapālam / citvā cityam hanvoḥ pūruṣasya divam ruroha katamaḥ sa devaḥ /
analyzed: mastiṣkam asya yatamaḥ lalātam kakāṭikām prathamaḥ yaḥ kapālam   citvā cityam hanvoḥ pūruṣasya divam ruroha katamaḥ sa devaḥ  /
translated: What God hath mounted to the heavens, having cut out the brain of this man, the forehead, the first bone of the skull, and the jaw-bones of the man who is to be sacrificed?

original: priya apriyāṇi bahulā svapnam saṃbādha tandyaḥ / ānandān ugraḥ nandān ca kasmāt vahati pūruṣaḥ /
analyzed: priya apriyāṇi bahulā svapnam saṃbādha tandyaḥ   ānandān ugraḥ nandān ca kasmāt vahati pūruṣaḥ
translated: The many joys and sorrows, the crowded and confused thoughts, the pleasures and the pains, why doth a man bear?

original: ārtiḥ avartiḥ nirṛtiḥ kutas nu puruṣe amatiḥ / rāddhiḥ samṛddhiḥ avyṛddhiḥ matiḥ uditayaḥ kutas / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / /
analyzed: ārtiḥ avartiḥ nirṛtiḥ kutas nu puruṣe amatiḥ   rāddhiḥ samṛddhiḥ avyṛddhiḥ matiḥ uditayaḥ kutas
translated: From what source hath he his pain, his grief, his sorrow, his despair, his want of understanding? From what source hath he his gain, his prosperity, his success, his wisdom, his knowledge?

original: kaḥ asmin āpaḥ vi adadhāt viṣūvṛtaḥ purūvṛtaḥ sindhusṛtyāya jātāḥ / tīvrāḥ aruṇāḥ lohinīḥ tāmra dhūmrāḥ ūrdhvāḥ avācīḥ puruṣe tiraścīḥ /
analyzed: kaḥ asmin āpaḥ vi adadhāt viṣūvṛtaḥ purūvṛtaḥ sindhusṛtyāya jātāḥ   tīvrāḥ aruṇāḥ lohinīḥ tāmra dhūmrāḥ ūrdhvāḥ avācīḥ puruṣe tiraścīḥ  /
translated: Who hath in him placed the waters, the many, the various, the rivers, born for the journey? The strong, the red, the tawny, the dark, the brown, the upward, the downward, and the transverse in man?

original: kaḥ asmin rūpam adadhāt kaḥ mahmānam ca nāma ca / gātum kaḥ asmin kaḥ ketum kaḥ caritrāni puruṣe /
analyzed: kaḥ asmin rūpam adadhāt kaḥ mahmānam ca nāma ca   / gātum kaḥ asmin kaḥ ketum kaḥ caritrāni puruṣe  /
translated: Who hath given him his form, who hath given him his greatness, his name, his motion, his light, his ways, his actions?

original: kaḥ asmin prāṇam avayat kaḥ apānam vyānam u / samānam asmin kaḥ devaḥ adhi śiśrāya puruṣe /
analyzed: kaḥ asmin prāṇam avayat kaḥ apānam vyānam u samānam asmin kaḥ devaḥ adhi śiśrāya puruṣe
translated: What God hath settled in this man, the breath that goes below, the breath that goes above, the breath that spreads through all the frame, the breath that dwells within the body?

original: kaḥ asmin yajñam adadhāt ekaḥ devaḥ adhi puruṣe / kaḥ asmin satyam kaḥ anṛtam kutas mṛtyuḥ kutas amṛtam /
analyzed: kaḥ asmin yajñam adadhāt ekaḥ devaḥ adhi puruṣe   kaḥ asmin satyam kaḥ anṛtam kutas mṛtyuḥ kutas amṛtam  /
translated: What one God hath established in this man, the sacrifice, the truth, the untruth, the death, the immortality?

original: kaḥ asmai vāsaḥ pari adadhāt kaḥ asya āyuḥ akalpayat / balam kaḥ asmai prāyacchat kaḥ asya akalpayat javam //
analyzed: kaḥ asmai vāsaḥ pari adadhāt kaḥ asya āyuḥ akalpayat   balam kaḥ asmai prāyacchat kaḥ asya akalpayat javam  /
translated: Who hath bestowed upon this man his garment? Who hath ordained his life? Who hath bestowed upon him strength? Who hath ordained his swiftness?

original: kena apaḥ anu atanuta kena ahar akarot ruce / uṣasam kena anu ainddha kena sāyaṃbhavam dade /
analyzed: kena apaḥ anu atanuta kena ahar akarot ruce    uṣasam kena anu ainddha kena sāyaṃbhavam dade  /
translated: Who hath extended the waters? Who hath made the day to shine? Who hath kindled the dawn? Who hath given us the evening?

original: kaḥ asmin retaḥ ni adadhāt tantuḥ ā tāyatām iti / medhām kaḥ asmin adhi auhat kaḥ bāṇam kaḥ nṛtaḥ dadhau /
analyzed: kaḥ asmin retaḥ ni adadhāt tantuḥ ā tāyatām iti   medhām kaḥ asmin adhi auhat kaḥ bāṇam kaḥ nṛtaḥ dadhau  /
translated: Who hath laid in him the seed, saying, 'Let the thread be spun out'? Who hath bestowed upon him wisdom? Who hath given him the dart and song?

original: kena imām bhūmim aurṇot kena pari abhavat divam / kena abhi mahnā parvatān kena karmāṇi puruṣaḥ /
analyzed: kena imām bhūmim aurṇot kena pari abhavat divam   kena abhi mahnā parvatān kena karmāṇi puruṣaḥ  /
translated: By what hath he extended this earth? By what hath he encompassed the sky? By what hath he extended the mountains? By what hath man performed his works?

original: kena parjanyam anu eti kena somam vicakṣaṇam / kena yajñam ca śraddhām ca kena asmin nihitam manaḥ //
analyzed: kena parjanyam anu eti kena somam vicakṣaṇam   kena yajñam ca śraddhām ca kena asmin nihitam manaḥ  /
translated: By what doth he follow Parjanya? By what the bright and watchful Soma? By what the sacrifice and faith? By what hath mind been placed in him?

original: kena śrotriyam āpnoti kena imam parameṣṭhinam / kena imam agnim pūruṣaḥ kena saṃvatsaram mame // // //
analyzed: kena śrotriyam āpnoti kena imam parameṣṭhinam   kena imam agnim pūruṣaḥ kena saṃvatsaram mame
translated: by what this Agni, by what the year does man obtain?🔽By Brahman one attains the learned Brāhman, by Brahman this highest lord,

original: brahma śrotriyam āpnoti brahma imam parameṣṭhinam / brahma imam agnim pūruṣaḥ brahma saṃvatsaram mame //
analyzed: brahma śrotriyam āpnoti brahma imam parameṣṭhinam   brahma imam agnim pūruṣaḥ brahma saṃvatsaram mame  /
translated: by Brahman this Agni, by Brahman the year does man obtain.🔽By what does one follow the gods, by what the families of the divine people,

original: kena devām anu kṣiyati kena daivajanīḥ viśaḥ / kena idam anyat nakṣatram kena sat kṣatram ucyate /
analyzed: kena devām anu kṣiyati kena daivajanīḥ viśaḥ   kena idam anyat nakṣatram kena sat kṣatram ucyate  /
translated: by what this other constellation, by what is the true Kshatriya called?🔽By Brahman one follows the gods, by Brahman the families of the divine people,

original: brahma devām anu kṣiyati brahma daivajanīḥ viśaḥ / brahma idam anyat nakṣatram brahma sat kṣatram ucyate /
analyzed: brahma devām anu kṣiyati brahma daivajanīḥ viśaḥ   brahma idam anyat nakṣatram brahma sat kṣatram ucyate  /
translated: by Brahman this other constellation, by Brahman is the true Kshatriya called.🔽By what is this earth measured, by what is the sky placed above,

original: kena iyam bhūmiḥ vihitā kena dyauḥ uttarā hitā / kena idam ūrdhvam tiryak ca antarikṣam vyacaḥ hitam /
analyzed: kena iyam bhūmiḥ vihitā kena dyauḥ uttarā hitā   kena idam ūrdhvam tiryak ca antarikṣam vyacaḥ hitam  /
translated: by what is this wide firmament placed above and across?🔽By Brahman is the earth measured, by Brahman the sky is placed above,

original: brahmaṇā bhūmiḥ vihitā brahma dyauḥ uttarā hitā / brahma idam ūrdhvam tiryak ca antarikṣam vyacaḥ hitam /
analyzed: brahmaṇā bhūmiḥ vihitā brahma dyauḥ uttarā hitā   brahma idam ūrdhvam tiryak ca antarikṣam vyacaḥ hitam  /
translated: by Brahman this wide firmament is placed above and across.

original: mūrdhānam asya saṃsīvya atharvā hṛdayam ca yat / mastiṣkāt ūrdhvaḥ prairayat pavamānaḥ adhi śīrṣataḥ /
analyzed: mūrdhānam asya saṃsīvya atharvā hṛdayam ca yat    mastiṣkāt ūrdhvaḥ prairayat pavamānaḥ adhi śīrṣataḥ  /
translated: Atharvan sewed together the head and heart of this (victim), and Pavamâna sent forth (the vital air) from the brain upwards, from the top of the head.

original: tat vai atharvaṇaḥ śiraḥ deva kośaḥ samubjitaḥ / tat prāṇaḥ abhi rakṣati śiraḥ annam atha u manaḥ /
analyzed: tat vai atharvaṇaḥ śiraḥ deva kośaḥ samubjitaḥ   tat prāṇaḥ abhi rakṣati śiraḥ annam atha u manaḥ  /
translated: That is the head of the Atharvan, the treasure of the gods, well-closed. The vital air guards it, the head, the food, and also the mind.

original: ūrdhvaḥ nu sṛṣṭaḥ tiryak nu sṛṣṭaḥ sarvāḥ diśaḥ puruṣaḥ ā babhūva am / puram yaḥ brahmaṇaḥ veda yasyāḥ puruṣaḥ ucyate /
analyzed: ūrdhvaḥ nu sṛṣṭaḥ tiryak nu sṛṣṭaḥ sarvāḥ diśaḥ puruṣaḥ ā babhūva am    puram yaḥ brahmaṇaḥ veda yasyāḥ puruṣaḥ ucyate  /
translated: He was created upwards, he was created transversely: man hath become all the regions of the world. He who knows that city of Brahman, of which man is said to be the name,

original: yaḥ vai tām brahmaṇaḥ veda amṛtena āvṛtām puram / tasmai brahma ca brāhmāḥ ca cakṣuḥ prāṇam prajām daduḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ vai tām brahmaṇaḥ veda amṛtena āvṛtām puram    tasmai brahma ca brāhmāḥ ca cakṣuḥ prāṇam prajām daduḥ  /
translated: To him who knows that city of Brahman, which is encompassed by immortality, Brahman and the Brahmans have given the eye, the vital air, and offspring.

original: na vai tam cakṣuḥ jahāti na prāṇaḥ jarasaḥ purā / puram yaḥ brahmaṇaḥ veda yasyāḥ puruṣaḥ ucyate /
analyzed: na vai tam cakṣuḥ jahāti na prāṇaḥ jarasaḥ purā   puram yaḥ brahmaṇaḥ veda yasyāḥ puruṣaḥ ucyate  /
translated: The eye never leaves him, nor the vital air, before old age. He who knows that city of Brahman, of which man is said to be the name,

original: aṣṭācakrā nava dvārā devānām pūḥ ayodhyā / tasyām hiraṇyayaḥ kośaḥ svargaḥ jyotiṣā āvṛtaḥ /
analyzed: aṣṭācakrā nava dvārā devānām pūḥ ayodhyā   tasyām hiraṇyayaḥ kośaḥ svargaḥ jyotiṣā āvṛtaḥ  /
translated: The city of the gods, Ayodhyâ, hath eight wheels, nine gates, and is well-fortified. In it is a golden casket, heaven, encompassed by the light.

original: tasmin hiraṇyaye kośe tri are tri pratiṣṭhite / tasmin yat yakṣam ātmanvat tat vai brahma vidaḥ viduḥ /
analyzed: tasmin hiraṇyaye kośe tri are tri pratiṣṭhite   tasmin yat yakṣam ātmanvat tat vai brahma vidaḥ viduḥ  /
translated: In that golden treasury, three-cornered, with three supports, Wherein is the treasure of the self-moving one, that the knowers of Brahman know.

original: prabhrājamānām hariṇīm yaśasā saṃparīvṛtām / puram hiraṇyayīm brahmā viveśa aparājitām // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // //
analyzed: prabhrājamānām hariṇīm yaśasā saṃparīvṛtām   puram hiraṇyayīm brahmā viveśa aparājitām
translated: The shining tawny one, surrounded by glory, The invincible golden city, Brahman entered.

original: ayam me varaṇaḥ maṇiḥ sapatna kṣayaṇaḥ vṛṣā / tena ā rabhasva tvam śatrūn pra mṛṇīhi durasyataḥ /
analyzed: ayam me varaṇaḥ maṇiḥ sapatna kṣayaṇaḥ vṛṣā   tena ā rabhasva tvam śatrūn pra mṛṇīhi durasyataḥ  /
translated: This Varana gem of mine, the bull that destroys foes, With it grasp thou the enemies, crush thou the spiteful ones.

original: pra eṇān śṛṇīhi pra mṛṇā rabhasva maṇiḥ te astu puraetā purastāt / avārayanta varaṇena devāḥ abhyācāram asurāṇām śvas śvas /
analyzed: pra eṇān śṛṇīhi pra mṛṇa ā rabhasva maṇiḥ te astu puraetā purastāt   avārayanta varaṇena devāḥ abhyācāram asurāṇām śvas śvas  /
translated: Sharpen them, crush them, grasp them; let the gem be thy leader in front. The gods with the Varana have repelled the Asuras' approach day by day.

original: ayam maṇiḥ varaṇaḥ viśva bheṣajaḥ sahasra akṣaḥ haritaḥ hiraṇyayaḥ / sa te śatrūn adharān pādayāti pūrvaḥ tān dabhnuhi ye tvā dviṣanti /
analyzed: ayam maṇiḥ varaṇaḥ viśva bheṣajaḥ sahasra akṣaḥ haritaḥ hiraṇyayaḥ    sa te śatrūn adharān pādayāti pūrvaḥ tān dabhnuhi ye tvā dviṣanti  /
translated: This Varana gem is the universal remedy, thousand-eyed, green, golden. It makes thy enemies fall lower than the lowest. Crush those who hate thee.

original: ayam te kṛtyām vitatām pauruṣeyāt ayam bhayāt / ayam tvā sarvasmāt pāpāt varaṇaḥ vārayiṣyate /
analyzed: ayam te kṛtyām vitatām pauruṣeyāt ayam bhayāt    ayam tvā sarvasmāt pāpāt varaṇaḥ vārayiṣyate  /
translated: This Amulet shall guard thee from the witchcraft spread by human power, from this dread danger,

original: varaṇaḥ vārayātai ayam devaḥ vanaspatiḥ / yakṣmaḥ yaḥ asmin āviṣṭaḥ tam u devāḥ avīvaran /
analyzed: varaṇaḥ vārayātai ayam devaḥ vanaspatiḥ   yakṣmaḥ yaḥ asmin āviṣṭaḥ tam u devāḥ avīvaran  /
translated: From all misfortune shall this Amulet, this God, this Tree, protect thee. The God hath driven from thee the disease that had possessed thee.🔽If thou hast seen a dream, O sleeper, and it be evil, if a deer runneth in an unaccustomed course,

original: svapnam suptvā yadi paśyāsi pāpam mṛgaḥ sṛtim yati dhāvāt ajuṣṭām / parikṣavāt śakuneḥ pāpa vādāt ayam maṇiḥ varaṇaḥ vārayiṣyate /
analyzed: svapnam suptvā yadi paśyāsi pāpam mṛgaḥ sṛtim yati dhāvāt ajuṣṭām    parikṣavāt śakuneḥ pāpa vādāt ayam maṇiḥ varaṇaḥ vārayiṣyate  /
translated: From the ill-omened bird's cry, from the evil-omened cry, this Amulet, this Varana, shall guard thee.

original: arātyāḥ tvā nirṛtyāḥ abhicārāt atho bhayāt / mṛtyoḥ ojīyasaḥ vadhāt varaṇaḥ vārayiṣyate /
analyzed: arātyāḥ tvā nirṛtyāḥ abhicārāt atho bhayāt   mṛtyoḥ ojīyasaḥ vadhāt varaṇaḥ vārayiṣyate  /
translated: From want, from famine, from enchantment, from fear, from death, from the strong snare, the Varana shall guard thee.🔽From whatever sin my mother, my father, my brothers, and my kinsmen have committed,

original: yat me mātā yat me pitā bhrātaraḥ yat ca me svāḥ yat enaḥ cakṛma vayam / tatas naḥ vārayiṣyate ayam devaḥ vanaspatiḥ /
analyzed: yat me mātā yat me pitā bhrātaraḥ yat ca me svāḥ yat enaḥ cakṛma vayam   tatas naḥ vārayiṣyate ayam devaḥ vanaspatiḥ  /
translated: From all that sin shall this God, this Tree, protect us.

original: varaṇena pravyathitāḥ bhrātṛvyāḥ me sabandhavaḥ / asūrtam rajaḥ api aguḥ te yantu adhamam tamaḥ /
analyzed: varaṇena pravyathitāḥ bhrātṛvyāḥ me sabandhavaḥ   asūrtam rajaḥ api aguḥ te yantu adhamam tamaḥ  /
translated: By Varana my kinsmen and my foes are sore distressed. They have gone down into the path that none may tread. Let them go down into the lowest darkness.

analyzed: tam mā ayam varaṇaḥ maṇiḥ pari pātu diśaḥ diśaḥ
translated: May this my Varana gem protect me on every side.

original: ayam me varaṇaḥ urasi rājā devaḥ vanaspatiḥ / sa me śatrūn vi bādhatām indraḥ dasyūn iva asurān /
analyzed: ayam me varaṇaḥ urasi rājā devaḥ vanaspatiḥ    sa me śatrūn vi bādhatām indraḥ dasyūn iva asurān  /
translated: This Varana, the king, the god, the lord of the forest, is on my breast. May he drive away my foes as Indra did the Asura-Dasas.

original: imam bibharmi varaṇam āyuṣmān śata śāradaḥ / sa me rāṣṭram ca kṣatram ca paśūn ojaḥ ca me dadhat /🔽yathā vātaḥ vanaspatīn vṛkṣān bhanakti ojasā / eva sapatnān me bhaṅgdhi pūrvān jātām uta aparān varaṇaḥ tvā abhi rakṣatu /
analyzed: imam bibharmi varaṇam āyuṣmān śata śāradaḥ    sa me rāṣṭram ca kṣatram ca paśūn ojaḥ ca me dadhat  / yathā vātaḥ vanaspatīn vṛkṣān bhanakti ojasā    eva sapatnān me bhaṅgdhi pūrvān jātām uta aparān varaṇaḥ tvā abhi rakṣatu  /
translated: I wear this Varana, long-lived, a hundred autumns. May it bestow on me a kingdom, power, cattle, and strength.🔽As the wind with its force breaks the trees, the forest trees, so break thou my foes, those born before and those born after. Let the Varana protect thee.

original: yathā vātaḥ ca agniḥ ca vṛkṣān psātaḥ vanaspatīn / eva sapatnān me psāhi pūrvān jātām uta aparān varaṇaḥ tvā abhi rakṣatu /
analyzed: yathā vātaḥ ca agniḥ ca vṛkṣān psātaḥ vanaspatīn    eva sapatnān me psāhi pūrvān jātām uta aparān varaṇaḥ tvā abhi rakṣatu  /
translated: As the wind and fire consume the trees, the forest trees, so consume thou my foes, those born before and those born after. Let the Varana protect thee.

original: yathā vātena prakṣīṇāḥ vṛkṣāḥ śere nyarpitāḥ / eva sapatnān tvam mama pra kṣiṇīhi ni arpaya / pūrvān jātām uta aparān varaṇaḥ tvā abhi rakṣatu //
analyzed: yathā vātena prakṣīṇāḥ vṛkṣāḥ śere nyarpitāḥ   eva sapatnān tvam mama pra kṣiṇīhi ni arpaya   pūrvān jātām uta aparān varaṇaḥ tvā abhi rakṣatu  /
translated: So scatter thou and overthrow my rivals, those who are before me born, and those who come after me. Let Varana protect thee well.🔽Cut them off, Varana, before the time appointed, before their life is ended,

original: tān tvam pra chinddhi varaṇa purā diṣṭāt purā āyuṣaḥ / ye enam paśuṣu dipsanti ye ca asya rāṣṭra dipsavaḥ /
analyzed: tān tvam pra chinddhi varaṇa purā diṣṭāt purā āyuṣaḥ   ye enam paśuṣu dipsanti ye ca asya rāṣṭra dipsavaḥ  /
translated: Those who would injure his cattle, those who would injure his kingdom.🔽As the sun shines above, as in him is light deposited,

original: yathā sūryaḥ atibhāti yathā asmin tejaḥ āhitam / eva me varaṇaḥ maṇiḥ kīrtim bhūtim ni yacchatu / tejasā mā sam ukṣatu yaśasā sam anaktu mā /

translated: So let the Varana Amulet bestow on me renown and prosperity. With splendour let it sprinkle me, and balm me with felicity.🔽As glory is in the moon, and in the sun that men behold,

translated: Let it sprinkle me with radiance, let it anoint me with glory.🔽As glory is in the sacrificer, as it is in this sacrifice,

original: indrasya prathamaḥ rathaḥ devānām aparaḥ rathaḥ varuṇasya tṛtīyaḥ id / ahīnām apamā ratha sthānum ārat atha arṣat /
analyzed: indrasya prathamaḥ rathaḥ devānām aparaḥ rathaḥ varuṇasya tṛtīyaḥ id   ahīnām apamā ratha sthānum ārat atha arṣat  /
translated: The first car of Indra, the second car of the Gods, the third car of Varuna, the lowest car of the Snakes, the car of the Sun has gone away, and now it flows.

original: darbhaḥ śociḥ tarūṇakam aśvasya vāraḥ paruṣasya vāraḥ / rathasya bandhuram //
analyzed: darbhaḥ śociḥ tarūṇakam aśvasya vāraḥ paruṣasya vāraḥ    rathasya bandhuram
translated: The Darbha is the flame, the young shoot, the covering of the horse, the covering of the chariot. The cross-bar of the chariot.

original: ava śveta padā jahi pūrveṇa ca apareṇa ca / udaplutam iva dāru ahīnām arasam viṣam vār ugram /
analyzed: ava śveta padā jahi pūrveṇa ca apareṇa ca   / udaplutam iva dāru ahīnām arasam viṣam vār ugram  /
translated: O white one, strike him with thy forefoot and with thy hind foot. Like a log that hath been submerged, O thou of mighty waters, make the poison of the snakes powerless and tasteless.

original: araṃghuṣaḥ nimajya unmaja punar abravīt / udaplutam iva dāru ahīnām arasam viṣam vār ugram /
analyzed: araṃghuṣaḥ nimajya unmaja punar abravīt    udaplutam iva dāru ahīnām arasam viṣam vār ugram  /
translated: The slow-moving one, having dived down, hath risen up again and said: Like a log that hath been submerged, O thou of mighty waters, make the poison of the snakes powerless and tasteless.

original: paidvaḥ hanti kasarṇīlam paidvaḥ śvitram uta asitam / paidvaḥ ratharvyāḥ śiraḥ sam bibheda pṛdākvāḥ /
analyzed: paidvaḥ hanti kasarṇīlam paidvaḥ śvitram uta asitam   paidvaḥ ratharvyāḥ śiraḥ sam bibheda pṛdākvāḥ  /
translated: The Paippali kills the Kasarnila, the Paippali the white and the black. The Paippali hath cleft the head of the Ratharva and the Pridasva.

original: paidva prehi prathamaḥ anu tvā vayam emasi / ahīn vi asyatāt pathaḥ yena smā vayam emasi /
analyzed: paidva prehi prathamaḥ anu tvā vayam emasi    ahīn vi asyatāt pathaḥ yena smā vayam emasi  /
translated: Go forward, Paippali, the first. We will follow after thee. Open the paths for the snakes, by which we may go.

original: idam paidvaḥ ajāyata idam asya parāyaṇam / imāni arvataḥ padā ahi ghnyaḥ vājinīvataḥ /
analyzed: idam paidvaḥ ajāyata idam asya parāyaṇam   / imāni arvataḥ padā ahi ghnyaḥ vājinīvataḥ  /
translated: Here was the Paippali born, here is his resting-place. These are the steps of the courser, the snake-slaying, rich in booty.

original: saṃyatam na vi sparat vyāttam na sam yamat / asmin kṣetre dvau ahī strī ca pumān ca tau ubhau arasā /
analyzed: saṃyatam na vi sparat vyāttam na sam yamat    asmin kṣetre dvau ahī strī ca pumān ca tau ubhau arasā  /
translated: Let not the closed be opened, let not the opened be closed. In this field are two snakes, a male and a female. Both of them are powerless.

original: arasāsaḥ iha ahayaḥ ye anti ye ca dūrake / ghanena hanmi vṛścikam ahim daṇḍena āgatam /
analyzed: arasāsaḥ iha ahayaḥ ye anti ye ca dūrake     ghanena hanmi vṛścikam ahim daṇḍena āgatam  /
translated: The snakes that are here and those that are afar, all are powerless. With the net I smite the scorpion, with the staff the snake that cometh.

translated: Indra, the slayer of Ahi, has torn away the wicked Ahi for me.🔽Indra, the slayer of Ahi, has torn away the wicked Ahi for me.🔽Indra, the slayer of Ahi, has torn away the wicked Ahi for me.🔽Indra, the slayer of Ahi, has torn away the wicked Ahi for me.🔽We meditate on Paiḍva, the firm one, of firm abode.

original: paidvasya manmahe vayam sthirasya sthira dhāmnaḥ / ime paścā pṛdākavaḥ pradīdhyataḥ āsate /
analyzed: paidvasya manmahe vayam sthirasya sthira dhāmnaḥ   ime paścā pṛdākavaḥ pradīdhyataḥ āsate  /
translated: These snakes, the Pr̥idākus, lie here hissing from behind.

original: naṣṭa asavaḥ naṣṭa viṣāḥ hatāḥ indreṇa vajriṇā / jaghāna indraḥ jaghnima vayam /
analyzed: naṣṭa asavaḥ naṣṭa viṣāḥ hatāḥ indreṇa vajriṇā   jaghāna indraḥ jaghnima vayam  /
translated: With life destroyed, with poison destroyed, slain by Indra the wielder of the thunderbolt. Indra has struck them down, we have struck them down.

original: hatāḥ tiraścirājayaḥ nipiṣṭāsaḥ pṛdākavaḥ / darvim karikratam śvitram darbheṣu asitam jahi //
analyzed: hatāḥ tiraścirājayaḥ nipiṣṭāsaḥ pṛdākavaḥ    darvim karikratam śvitram darbheṣu asitam jahi  /
translated: The serpents' crests are slain, the vipers are crushed down. Destroy the stick, the white-backed worm, the black one on the Darbha grass.

original: kairātikā kumārikā sakā khanati bheṣajam / hiraṇyayībhiḥ abhribhiḥ girīnām upa sānuṣu /
