original: ākūtim devīm subhagām puras dadhe cittasya mātā su havā naḥ astu / yām āśām emi kevalī sā me astu videyam enām manasi praviṣṭām /
analyzed: ākūtim devīm subhagām puras dadhe cittasya mātā su havā naḥ astu   yām āśām emi kevalī sā me astu videyam enām manasi praviṣṭām  /
translated: I place in front the Goddess Inspiration, the happy mother of the mind. May she be easy to invoke for us. Whatever hope I have, may that be mine. May I find her who hath entered into my mind.

original: ākūtyā naḥ bṛhaspate ākūtyā naḥ upa ā gahi / atha u bhagasya naḥ dhehi atha u naḥ su havaḥ bhava /
analyzed: ākūtyā naḥ bṛhaspate ākūtyā naḥ upa ā gahi   atha u bhagasya naḥ dhehi atha u naḥ su havaḥ bhava  /
translated: By Inspiration, O Br̥ihaspati, by Inspiration come thou nigh to us. And then bestow upon us happiness. And then be easy to invoke for us.

original: bṛhaspatiḥ me ākūtim āṅgirasaḥ prati jānātu vācam etām / yasya devāḥ devatāḥ saṃbabhūvuḥ sa su praṇītāḥ kāmaḥ anu etu asmān /
analyzed: bṛhaspatiḥ me ākūtim āṅgirasaḥ prati jānātu vācam etām    yasya devāḥ devatāḥ saṃbabhūvuḥ sa su praṇītāḥ kāmaḥ anu etu asmān  /
translated: May Br̥ihaspati, son of Angiras, accept this speech and this my thought. He with whose Gods the Gods have been united. May that well-ordered wish of his attend us.

original: indraḥ rājā jagataḥ carṣaṇīnām adhi kṣami viṣurūpam yat asti / tatas dadāti dāśuṣe vasūni codat rādhaḥ upastutaḥ cit arvāk /
analyzed: indraḥ rājā jagataḥ carṣaṇīnām adhi kṣami viṣurūpam yat asti   tatas dadāti dāśuṣe vasūni codat rādhaḥ upastutaḥ cit arvāk  /
translated: Indra is King of all the people of the earth, of all the varied form that is upon the earth. From him he gives the worshipper wealth and treasure, and sends him gifts, though he be not implored.

original: sahasra bāhuḥ puruṣaḥ sahasra akṣaḥ sahasrapād / sa bhūmim viśvatas vṛtvā ati atiṣṭhat daśa aṅgulam //🔽tribhiḥ padbhiḥ dyām arohat pād asya iha bhavat punar / tathā vi akrāmat viṣvaṅ aśanān aśane anu /
analyzed: sahasra bāhuḥ puruṣaḥ sahasra akṣaḥ sahasrapād    sa bhūmim viśvatas vṛtvā ati atiṣṭhat daśa aṅgulam  / tribhiḥ padbhiḥ dyām arohat pād asya iha bhavat punar   tathā vi akrāmat viṣvaṅ aśanān aśane anu  /
translated: The Person is all this universe, what hath been and what yet shall be. Lord of all worlds is He, the One God, the Master of all that hath been born.🔽With three feet hath he mounted the sky, and one foot of him is here again. So hath he spread himself out through all the regions, through food and breath.

original: tāvantaḥ asya mahimānaḥ tatas jyāyān ca pūruṣaḥ / pādaḥ asya viśvā bhūtāni tripād asya amṛtam divi //
analyzed: tāvantaḥ asya mahimānaḥ tatas jyāyān ca pūruṣaḥ   pādaḥ asya viśvā bhūtāni tripād asya amṛtam divi  /
translated: As many are his glories, so much greater is Purusha. One fourth of him are all existing things, and three fourths are immortal in heaven.

original: puruṣaḥ eva idam sarvam yat bhūtam yat ca bhāvyam / uta amṛta tvasya īśvaraḥ yat anyena abhavat saha //
analyzed: puruṣaḥ eva idam sarvam yat bhūtam yat ca bhāvyam   uta amṛta tvasya īśvaraḥ yat anyena abhavat saha  /
translated: This all was in the beginning, and what is now, and what will be hereafter. He, the Self-existent One, is Lord of what was created. He is the Master of all that hath been born.

original: yat puruṣam vi adadhuḥ katidhā vi akalpayan / mukham kim asya kim bāhū kim ūrū pādau ucyate /
analyzed: yat puruṣam vi adadhuḥ katidhā vi akalpayan   mukham kim asya kim bāhū kim ūrū pādau ucyate  /
translated: When they divided Purusha how many portions did they make? What do they call his mouth, his two arms? What do they call his two thighs and his two feet?

original: brāhmaṇaḥ asya mukham āsīt bāhūḥ rājanyaḥ abhavat / madhyam tat asya yat vaiśyaḥ padbhyām śūdraḥ ajāyata /
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ asya mukham āsīt bāhūḥ rājanyaḥ abhavat   madhyam tat asya yat vaiśyaḥ padbhyām śūdraḥ ajāyata  /
translated: The Brahman was his mouth, of his two arms was the Kshatriya made. His thighs became the Vaisya, from his feet the Sudra was produced.

original: candramāḥ manasaḥ jātaḥ cakṣoḥ sūryaḥ ajāyata / mukhāt indraḥ ca agniḥ ca prāṇāt vāyuḥ ajāyata /
analyzed: candramāḥ manasaḥ jātaḥ cakṣoḥ sūryaḥ ajāyata   mukhāt indraḥ ca agniḥ ca prāṇāt vāyuḥ ajāyata  /
translated: The Moon was born of his mind, from his eye the Sun was generated. Indra and Agni from his mouth, and Vayu from his breath was born.

original: nābhyāḥ āsīt antarikṣam śīrṣṇaḥ dyauḥ sam avartata / padbhyām bhūmiḥ diśaḥ śrotrāt tathā lokām akalpayan /
analyzed: nābhyāḥ āsīt antarikṣam śīrṣṇaḥ dyauḥ sam avartata   padbhyām bhūmiḥ diśaḥ śrotrāt tathā lokām akalpayan  /
translated: The firmament was in his navel, from his head arose the sky. The earth was from his feet, and from his ear the regions were created.

original: virāj agre sam abhavat virājaḥ adhi pūruṣaḥ / sa jātaḥ ati aricyata paścāt bhūmim atho puras /🔽yat puruṣeṇa haviṣā devāḥ yajñam atanvata / vasantaḥ asya āsīt ājyam grīṣmaḥ idhmaḥ śarad haviḥ /
analyzed: virāj agre sam abhavat virājaḥ adhi pūruṣaḥ   sa jātaḥ ati aricyata paścāt bhūmim atho puras  / yat puruṣeṇa haviṣā devāḥ yajñam atanvata    vasantaḥ asya āsīt ājyam grīṣmaḥ idhmaḥ śarad haviḥ  /
translated: Virāj first came into being, and from Virāj sprang Purusha. When he was born, he spread over all this earth, over the earth and over the sky.🔽When the gods spread the sacrifice with the oblation of Purusha, the spring was his ghee, the summer his fuel, the autumn his oblation.

original: tam yajñam prāvṛṣā praukṣan puruṣam jātam agraśas / tena devāḥ ayajanta sādhyāḥ vasavaḥ ca ye /
analyzed: tam yajñam prāvṛṣā praukṣan puruṣam jātam agraśas    tena devāḥ ayajanta sādhyāḥ vasavaḥ ca ye  /
translated: In the rainy season they poured that sacrifice, the first-born Purusha, and with him the gods, the Sadhyas, and the Vasus worshipped.

original: tasmāt aśvāḥ ajāyanta ye ca ke ca ubhayāt atas / gāvaḥ ha jajñire tasmāt tasmāt jātāḥ aja avayaḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt aśvāḥ ajāyanta ye ca ke ca ubhayāt atas   gāvaḥ ha jajñire tasmāt tasmāt jātāḥ aja avayaḥ  /
translated: From him were born the horses, and whatever other creatures there are of two feet or more. From him were born the cows, from him the goats and sheep.

original: tasmāt yajñāt sarva huta ṛcaḥ sāmāni jajñire / chandaḥ ha jajñire tasmāt yajuḥ tasmāt ajāyata //
analyzed: tasmāt yajñāt sarva huta ṛcaḥ sāmāni jajñire   chandaḥ ha jajñire tasmāt yajuḥ tasmāt ajāyata  /
translated: From that sacrifice, the Rikas and Samans were born, all offered up. From it the metres were born, and from it the Yajus came to birth.

original: tasmāt yajñāt sarva hutaḥ saṃbhṛtam pṛṣadājyam / paśūn tān cakre vāyavyān āraṇyāḥ grāmyāḥ ca ye /
analyzed: tasmāt yajñāt sarva hutaḥ saṃbhṛtam pṛṣadājyam   paśūn tān cakre vāyavyān āraṇyāḥ grāmyāḥ ca ye
translated: From that sacrifice, all offered up, the speckled butter was collected. He made those animals, the wild and the domestic, the offspring of Vayu.

original: sapta asya āsan paridhayaḥ tris sapta samidhaḥ kṛtāḥ / devāḥ yat yajñam tanvānāḥ abadhnan puruṣam paśum //
analyzed: sapta asya āsan paridhayaḥ tris sapta samidhaḥ kṛtāḥ   devāḥ yat yajñam tanvānāḥ abadhnan puruṣam paśum  /
translated: Seven were his enclosing-sticks, thrice seven the logs that were prepared, when the Gods, performing sacrifice, bound Purusha as victim.

original: mūrdhnaḥ devasya bṛhataḥ aṃśavaḥ sapta saptatīḥ / rājñaḥ somasya ajāyanta jātasya puruṣāt adhi //
analyzed: mūrdhnaḥ devasya bṛhataḥ aṃśavaḥ sapta saptatīḥ   rājñaḥ somasya ajāyanta jātasya puruṣāt adhi  /
translated: The rays of the high God's head, seventy and seven in number, were born after the birth of King Soma from the Person.

original: citrāṇi sākam divi rocanāni sarīsṛpāṇi bhuvane javāni / turmiśam sumatim ichamānaḥ ahāni gīrbhiḥ saparyāmi nākam /
analyzed: citrāṇi sākam divi rocanāni sarīsṛpāṇi bhuvane javāni   turmiśam sumatim ichamānaḥ ahāni gīrbhiḥ saparyāmi nākam  /
translated: The various lights in the sky together, the creeping things in the world that move, the swift, seeking the favour of Turmisha, I honour the days with songs, the vault of heaven.

original: su havam agne kṛttikā rohiṇī ca astu bhadram mṛgaśiraḥ śam ārdrā / punarvasū sūnṛtā cāru puṣyaḥ bhānuḥ āśleṣāḥ ayanam maghā me /
analyzed: su havam agne kṛttikā rohiṇī ca astu bhadram mṛgaśiraḥ śam ārdrā   punarvasū sūnṛtā cāru puṣyaḥ bhānuḥ āśleṣāḥ ayanam maghā me  /
translated: Be the Krittikas, O Agni, easy of access, and Rohini auspicious, and Mrigasiras propitious, and Ardra good, and Punarvasu kindly, and Pushya charming, and Ashlesha my path, and Magha my abode.

original: puṇyam pūrvā phalgunyau ca atra hastaḥ citrā śivā svāti sukhaḥ me astu / rādhe viśākhe su havā anurādhā jyeṣṭhā su nakṣatram ariṣṭa mūlam /
analyzed: puṇyam pūrvā phalgunyau ca atra hastaḥ citrā śivā svāti sukhaḥ me astu   rādhe viśākhe su havā anurādhā jyeṣṭhā su nakṣatram ariṣṭa mūlam  /
translated: The two preceding Phalguni stars are auspicious, and Hâstha, and auspicious Citrâ, and the propitious Svâtî. May they be propitious to me. The two Râdhâs, and the easy-invoking Anurâdhâ, and Jyeṣṭhā, and the auspicious Mûla.

original: annam pūrvā rāsatām me aṣādhāḥ ūrjam devī uttarāḥ ā vahantu / abhijit me rāsatām puṇyam eva śravaṇaḥ śraviṣṭhāḥ kurvatām su puṣṭim /
analyzed: annam pūrvā rāsatām me aṣādhāḥ ūrjam devī uttarāḥ ā vahantu   abhijit me rāsatām puṇyam eva śravaṇaḥ śraviṣṭhāḥ kurvatām su puṣṭim  /
translated: May the two preceding Aṣâḍhâs give me food, and may the Goddess Uttara Aṣâḍhâ bring me strength. May Abhijit give me only merit, and may Śravaṇa and Śraviṣṭhā bring me good nourishment.

original: ā me mahat śatabhiṣaj varīyaḥ ā me dvayā proṣṭhapadā su śarma / ā revatī ca aśvayujau bhagam me ā me rayim bharaṇyaḥ ā vahantu /
analyzed: ā me mahat śatabhiṣaj varīyaḥ ā me dvayā proṣṭhapadā su śarma   ā revatī ca aśvayujau bhagam me ā me rayim bharaṇyaḥ ā vahantu  /
translated: May the great Śatabhiṣâ bring me great things, and may the two preceding Proṣṭhapadâs bring me good protection. May Revatî and the two Aśvayujas bring me good fortune, and may the Bharaṇîs bring me wealth.

original: yāni nakṣatrāṇi divi antarikṣe apsu bhūmau yāni nageṣu dikṣu / prakalpayan candramāḥ yāni eti sarvāṇi mama etāni śivāni santu //
analyzed: yāni nakṣatrāṇi divi antarikṣe apsu bhūmau yāni nageṣu dikṣu   prakalpayan candramāḥ yāni eti sarvāṇi mama etāni śivāni santu  /
translated: The stars which are in the heavens, in the atmosphere, in the waters, on the earth, in the mountains, in the quarters, as the moon moves on, allotting them, may all these be auspicious to me.

original: aṣṭāviṃśāni śivāni śagmāni saha yogam bhajantu me / yogam pra padye kṣemam ca kṣemam pra padye yogam ca namaḥ ahar rātrābhyām astu //
analyzed: aṣṭāviṃśāni śivāni śagmāni saha yogam bhajantu me   yogam pra padye kṣemam ca kṣemam pra padye yogam ca namaḥ ahar rātrābhyām astu
translated: May the twenty-eight auspicious and powerful stars be united with me. I enter on union, and on peace. I enter on peace, and on union. Honour be to day and night.

original: svastitam me su prātar su sāyam su divam su mṛgam su śakunam me astu / su havam agne svasti amartyam gatvā punar āya abhinandan //
analyzed: svastitam me su prātar su sāyam su divam su mṛgam su śakunam me astu     / su havam agne svasti amartyam gatvā punar āya abhinandan  /
translated: May I have good luck in the morning, good luck in the evening, good luck in the day, good luck in the night, good luck in hunting, good luck in hawking. May I have good luck in calling on the gods, O immortal Agni, and returning again, may I be welcomed.

original: anuhavam parihavam parivādam parikṣavam / sarvaiḥ me rikta kumbhān parā tān savitar suva //
analyzed: anuhavam parihavam parivādam parikṣavam    sarvaiḥ me rikta kumbhān parā tān savitar suva  /
translated: The call that follows, the call that surrounds, the slander, the abuse, all the empty vessels for me, O Savitar, lead them away.

original: apapāpam parikṣavam puṇyam bhakṣīmahi kṣavam / śivā te pāpa nāsikām puṇya gaḥ ca abhi mehatām /
analyzed: apapāpam parikṣavam puṇyam bhakṣīmahi kṣavam   śivā te pāpa nāsikām puṇya gaḥ ca abhi mehatām  /
translated: The sin that is hidden, the sin that is manifest, may we enjoy the sin that is meritorious. May the one who goes to the meritorious urinate on thy auspicious nose, O sin.

original: imāḥ yāḥ brahmaṇaḥ pate viṣucīḥ vāte īrate / sadhrīcīḥ indra tāḥ kṛtvā mahyam śivatamāḥ kṛdhi //
analyzed: imāḥ yāḥ brahmaṇaḥ pate viṣucīḥ vāte īrate    sadhrīcīḥ indra tāḥ kṛtvā mahyam śivatamāḥ kṛdhi  /
translated: These, O Lord of prayer, which fly in different directions or with the wind, make them, O Indra, fly towards me, and make them most auspicious for me.

original: svasti naḥ astu abhayam naḥ astu namaḥ ahar uratrābhyām astu //
analyzed: svasti naḥ astu abhayam naḥ astu namaḥ ahar uratrābhyām astu
translated: May we have welfare, may we have freedom from fear. Let there be homage to the day and the night.

original: śāntā dyauḥ śāntā pṛthivī śāntam idam uru antarikṣam / śāntāḥ udanvatīḥ āpaḥ śāntāḥ naḥ santu oṣadhīḥ /
analyzed: śāntā dyauḥ śāntā pṛthivī śāntam idam uru antarikṣam   śāntāḥ udanvatīḥ āpaḥ śāntāḥ naḥ santu oṣadhīḥ  /
translated: The sky is peaceful, the earth is peaceful, this wide atmosphere is peaceful. The waters that contain the clouds are peaceful, may the plants be peaceful to us.

original: śāntāni pūrvarūpāṇi śāntam naḥ astu kṛta akṛtam / śāntam bhūtam ca bhavyam ca sarvam eva śam astu naḥ /
analyzed: śāntāni pūrvarūpāṇi śāntam naḥ astu kṛta akṛtam   śāntam bhūtam ca bhavyam ca sarvam eva śam astu naḥ  /
translated: The former forms are peaceful, peaceful be what is done and what is left undone for us. Peaceful be the past and the future, and all be well with us.

original: iyam yā parameṣṭhinī vāc devī brahma saṃśitā / yayā eva sasṛje ghoram tayā eva śāntiḥ astu naḥ /
analyzed: iyam yā parameṣṭhinī vāc devī brahma saṃśitā   yayā eva sasṛje ghoram tayā eva śāntiḥ astu naḥ  /
translated: This speech of yours, O Parameshthin, which is divine, and purified by prayer, wherewith ye have created the terrible, with that same speech be ye propitious unto us.

original: idam yat parameṣṭhinam manaḥ vām brahma saṃśitam / yena eva sasṛje ghoram tena eva śāntiḥ astu naḥ /
analyzed: idam yat parameṣṭhinam manaḥ vām brahma saṃśitam   yena eva sasṛje ghoram tena eva śāntiḥ astu naḥ  /
translated: This mind of yours, O Parameshthin, which is purified by prayer, wherewith ye have created the terrible, with that same mind be ye propitious unto us.

original: imāni yāni pañca indriyāni manaḥ ṣaṣṭhāni me hṛdi brahmaṇā saṃśitāni / yaiḥ eva sasṛje ghoram taiḥ eva śāntiḥ astu naḥ /
analyzed: imāni yāni pañca indriyāni manaḥ ṣaṣṭhāni me hṛdi brahmaṇā saṃśitāni   yaiḥ eva sasṛje ghoram taiḥ eva śāntiḥ astu naḥ  /
translated: These five organs of mine, with the mind as the sixth, which are purified by prayer in my heart, wherewith ye have created the terrible, with those same organs be ye propitious unto us.

original: śam naḥ mitraḥ śam varuṇaḥ śam viṣṇuḥ śam prajāpatiḥ / śam naḥ indraḥ bṛhaspatiḥ śam naḥ bhavatu aryamā /
analyzed: śam naḥ mitraḥ śam varuṇaḥ śam viṣṇuḥ śam prajāpatiḥ   śam naḥ indraḥ bṛhaspatiḥ śam naḥ bhavatu aryamā  /
translated: May Mitra, Varuna, Vishnu, Prajapati be gracious to us. May Indra, Brihaspati, Aryaman be gracious to us.

original: śam naḥ mitraḥ śam varuṇaḥ śam vivasvān cham antakaḥ / utpātāḥ pārthiva antarikṣāḥ śam naḥ divicarāḥ grahāḥ /
analyzed: śam naḥ mitraḥ śam varuṇaḥ śam vivasvān cham antakaḥ   utpātāḥ pārthiva antarikṣāḥ śam naḥ divicarāḥ grahāḥ  /
translated: May Mitra, Varuna, Vivasvan, Antaka, the terrestrial and atmospheric portents, the planets that move in the sky, be gracious to us.

original: śam naḥ bhūmiḥ vepyamānā śam ulkā nirhatam ca yat / śam gāvaḥ lohita kṣīrāḥ śam bhūmiḥ ava tīryatīḥ /
analyzed: śam naḥ bhūmiḥ vepyamānā śam ulkā nirhatam ca yat  / śam gāvaḥ lohita kṣīrāḥ śam bhūmiḥ ava tīryatīḥ  /
translated: May the trembling earth be gracious to us, and what is destroyed by the falling star. May the cows with red milk be gracious to us, and the earth covered with water.

original: nakṣatram ulkā abhihatam śam astu naḥ śam naḥ abhicārāḥ śam u santu kṛtyāḥ / śam naḥ nikhātāḥ valgāḥ śam ulkāḥ deśa upasargāḥ śam u naḥ bhavantu /
analyzed: nakṣatram ulkā abhihatam śam astu naḥ śam naḥ abhicārāḥ śam u santu kṛtyāḥ   śam naḥ nikhātāḥ valgāḥ śam ulkāḥ deśa upasargāḥ śam u naḥ bhavantu  /
translated: May the star struck by a meteor be auspicious to us. May the curses and the spells be auspicious to us.

original: śam naḥ grahāḥ cāndramasāḥ śam ādityaḥ ca rāhuṇā / śam naḥ mṛtyuḥ dhūmaketuḥ śam rudrāḥ tigma tejasaḥ /
analyzed: śam naḥ grahāḥ cāndramasāḥ śam ādityaḥ ca rāhuṇā   śam naḥ mṛtyuḥ dhūmaketuḥ śam rudrāḥ tigma tejasaḥ  /
translated: May the planets and the moon be auspicious to us, may the sun with Rahu be auspicious to us. May death and the comet be auspicious to us, may the Rudras of sharp energy be auspicious to us.

original: śam rudrāḥ śam vasavaḥ śam ādityāḥ śam agnayaḥ / śam naḥ mahā ṛṣayaḥ devāḥ śam devāḥ śam bṛhaspatiḥ //
analyzed: śam rudrāḥ śam vasavaḥ śam ādityāḥ śam agnayaḥ   śam naḥ mahā ṛṣayaḥ devāḥ śam devāḥ śam bṛhaspatiḥ  /
translated: May the Rudras be auspicious to us, may the Vasus be auspicious to us, may the Adityas be auspicious to us, may the fires be auspicious to us. May the great sages, the gods, all the gods, and Brihaspati be auspicious to us.

original: brahma prajāpatiḥ dhātā lokāḥ vedāḥ sapta ṛṣayaḥ agnayaḥ / taiḥ me kṛtam svastyayanam indraḥ me śarma yacchatu brahmā me śarma yacchatu / viśve me devāḥ śarma yacchantu sarve me devāḥ śarma yacchantu /
analyzed: brahma prajāpatiḥ dhātā lokāḥ vedāḥ sapta ṛṣayaḥ agnayaḥ   taiḥ me kṛtam svastyayanam indraḥ me śarma yacchatu brahmā me śarma yacchatu   viśve me devāḥ śarma yacchantu sarve me devāḥ śarma yacchantu  /
translated: Brahma, Prajapati, the creator, the worlds, the Vedas, the seven sages, the fires - may they bring me well-being. May Indra grant me protection, may Brahma grant me protection. May all the gods grant me protection, may all the gods grant me protection.

original: yāni kāni cit śāntāni loke sapta ṛṣayaḥ viduḥ / sarvāṇi śam bhavantu me śam me astu abhayam me astu //
analyzed: yāni kāni cit śāntāni loke sapta ṛṣayaḥ viduḥ   sarvāṇi śam bhavantu me śam me astu abhayam me astu  /
translated: Whatever peaceful things the seven sages know in the world, may all of them be auspicious to me. May there be peace for me, may there be fearlessness for me.

original: śāntiḥ śāntiḥ śāntiḥ śāntibhiḥ /
analyzed: śāntiḥ śāntiḥ śāntiḥ śāntibhiḥ
translated: Peace, peace, peace, with the peaceful ones.

original: yat iha ghoram yat iha krūram yat iha pāpam tat śāntam tat śivam sarvam eva śam astu naḥ //🔽śam naḥ indra agnī bhavatām avobhiḥ śam naḥ indrāvaruṇā rāta havyā / śam indrāsomā suvitāya śam yoḥ śam naḥ indrāpūṣaṇā vājasātau /
analyzed: yat iha ghoram yat iha krūram yat iha pāpam tat śāntam tat śivam sarvam eva śam astu naḥ  śam naḥ indra agnī bhavatām avobhiḥ śam naḥ indrāvaruṇā rāta havyā   śam indrāsomā suvitāya śam yos śam naḥ indrāpūṣaṇā vājasātau  /
translated: Whatever is terrible here, whatever is cruel here, whatever is sinful here, that is appeased, that is auspicious. May everything be well with us.🔽Be auspicious to us, O Indra and Agni, with your favours. Be auspicious to us, O Indra and Varuna, who receive offerings. Be auspicious to us, O Indra and Soma, for prosperity and strength. Be auspicious to us, O Indra and Pusan, in the winning of strength.

original: śam naḥ bhagaḥ śam u naḥ śaṃsaḥ astu śam naḥ puraṃdhiḥ śam u santu rāyaḥ / śam naḥ satyasya suyamasya śaṃsaḥ śam naḥ aryamā puru jātaḥ astu /
analyzed: śam naḥ bhagaḥ śam u naḥ śaṃsaḥ astu śam naḥ puraṃdhiḥ śam u santu rāyaḥ   śam naḥ satyasya suyamasya śaṃsaḥ śam naḥ aryamā puru jātaḥ astu  /
translated: Be auspicious to us, O Bhaga, and let our praise be auspicious to us. Be auspicious to us, O Purandhi, and let our riches be auspicious. Be auspicious to us, O truth, and the well-governed praise. Be auspicious to us, O Aryaman, who is born in many places.

original: śam naḥ dhātā śam u dhartā naḥ astu śam naḥ urūcī bhavatu svadhābhiḥ / śam rodasī bṛhatī śam naḥ adriḥ śam naḥ devānām su havāni santu //
analyzed: śam naḥ dhātā śam u dhartā naḥ astu śam naḥ urūcī bhavatu svadhābhiḥ   śam rodasī bṛhatī śam naḥ adriḥ śam naḥ devānām su havāni santu  /
translated: Be auspicious to us, O Dhatr, and let our supporter be auspicious to us. Be auspicious to us, O vast one, with your own powers. Be auspicious to us, O great heaven and earth. Be auspicious to us, O mountain. Be auspicious to us the easy invocations of the gods.

original: śam naḥ agniḥ jyotiḥ anīkaḥ astu śam naḥ mitrāvaruṇau aśvinā śam / śam naḥ su kṛtām su kṛtāni santu śam naḥ iṣiraḥ abhi vātu vātaḥ /
analyzed: śam naḥ agniḥ jyotiḥ anīkaḥ astu śam naḥ mitrāvaruṇau aśvinā śam   śam naḥ su kṛtām su kṛtāni santu śam naḥ iṣiraḥ abhi vātu vātaḥ  /
translated: Be auspicious to us, O Agni, whose face is light. Be auspicious to us, O Mitra, Varuna, and the Ashvins. Be auspicious to us, the well-performed rites of the virtuous. Be auspicious to us, and let the wind blow upon us.

original: śam naḥ dyāvāpṛthivī pūrva hūtau śam antarikṣam dṛśaye naḥ astu / śam naḥ oṣadhīḥ vaninaḥ bhavantu śam naḥ rajasaḥ patiḥ astu jiṣṇuḥ /
analyzed: śam naḥ dyāvāpṛthivī pūrva hūtau śam antarikṣam dṛśaye naḥ astu  / śam naḥ oṣadhīḥ vaninaḥ bhavantu śam naḥ rajasaḥ patiḥ astu jiṣṇuḥ  /
translated: May Heaven and Earth be gracious to us when first we call, and may the Firmament be gracious to our sight. Gracious to us be Plants and Trees, and gracious be the Lord of the wide air, the Victorious.

original: śam naḥ indraḥ vasubhiḥ devaḥ astu śam ādityebhiḥ varuṇaḥ su śaṃsaḥ / śam naḥ rudraḥ rudrebhiḥ jalāṣaḥ śam naḥ tvaṣṭā gnābhiḥ iha śṛṇotu //
analyzed: śam naḥ indraḥ vasubhiḥ devaḥ astu śam ādityebhiḥ varuṇaḥ su śaṃsaḥ   śam naḥ rudraḥ rudrebhiḥ jalāṣaḥ śam naḥ tvaṣṭā gnābhiḥ iha śṛṇotu  /
translated: Gracious to us be Indra with the Vasus, gracious be Varuṇa the righteous with the Âdityas. Gracious to us be Rudra with the Rudras. Gracious to us be Tvashtar here with the Ganas.

original: śam naḥ somaḥ bhavatu brahma śam naḥ śam naḥ grāvāṇaḥ śam u santu yajñāḥ / śam naḥ svarūnām mitayaḥ bhavantu śam naḥ prasvaḥ śam u astu vediḥ /
analyzed: śam naḥ somaḥ bhavatu brahma śam naḥ śam naḥ grāvāṇaḥ śam u santu yajñāḥ   śam naḥ svarūnām mitayaḥ bhavantu śam naḥ prasvaḥ śam u astu vediḥ  /
translated: Gracious to us be Soma, gracious Brahma, gracious to us be the pressing-stones and sacrifices. Gracious to us be the measures of our hymns. Gracious to us be the out-breath, gracious the altar.

original: śam naḥ sūryaḥ uru cakṣāḥ ud etu śam naḥ bhavantu pradiśaḥ catasraḥ / śam naḥ parvatāḥ dhruvayaḥ bhavantu śam naḥ sindhavaḥ śam u santu āpaḥ /
analyzed: śam naḥ sūryaḥ uru cakṣāḥ ud etu śam naḥ bhavantu pradiśaḥ catasraḥ   śam naḥ parvatāḥ dhruvayaḥ bhavantu śam naḥ sindhavaḥ śam u santu āpaḥ  /
translated: Gracious to us be Sûrya, the far-beholding. Gracious to us be the four regions of the sky. Gracious to us be the firm mountains. Gracious to us be the rivers and the waters.

original: śam naḥ aditiḥ bhavatu vratebhiḥ śam naḥ bhavantu marutaḥ su arkāḥ / śam naḥ viṣṇuḥ śam u pūṣā naḥ astu śam naḥ bhavitram śam u astu vāyuḥ //
analyzed: śam naḥ aditiḥ bhavatu vratebhiḥ śam naḥ bhavantu marutaḥ su arkāḥ   śam naḥ viṣṇuḥ śam u pūṣā naḥ astu śam naḥ bhavitram śam u astu vāyuḥ  /
translated: Gracious to us be Aditi with her ordinances. Gracious to us be the Maruts with their fair songs. Gracious to us be Vishnu, gracious be Pûshan. Gracious to us be Bhava, gracious Vâyu.

original: śam naḥ devaḥ savitā trāyamāṇaḥ śam naḥ bhavantu uṣasaḥ vibhātīḥ / śam naḥ parjanyaḥ bhavatu prajābhyaḥ śam naḥ kṣetrasya patiḥ astu śaṃbhuḥ /
analyzed: śam naḥ devaḥ savitā trāyamāṇaḥ śam naḥ bhavantu uṣasaḥ vibhātīḥ   śam naḥ parjanyaḥ bhavatu prajābhyaḥ śam naḥ kṣetrasya patiḥ astu śaṃbhuḥ  /
translated: May Savitar the God, the Guardian, prosper us: may the bright Dawns be gracious unto us. May Parjanya be kind unto the people: may the auspicious Lord of the Field prosper us.

original: śam naḥ satyasya patayaḥ bhavantu śam naḥ arvantaḥ śam u santu gāvaḥ / śam naḥ ṛbhavaḥ su kṛtaḥ su hastāḥ śam naḥ bhavatu pitaraḥ haveṣu //
analyzed: śam naḥ satyasya patayaḥ bhavantu śam naḥ arvantaḥ śam u santu gāvaḥ   śam naḥ ṛbhavaḥ su kṛtaḥ su hastāḥ śam naḥ bhavatu pitaraḥ haveṣu  /
translated: May the Lords of Truth prosper and bless us: may the Steeds and the Cows be kind and gracious. May the R̥ibhus, skilful, deft of hand, bless us: may the Fathers in our invocations bless us.

original: śam naḥ devāḥ viśva devāḥ bhavantu śam sarasvatī saha dhībhiḥ astu / śam abhiṣācaḥ śam u rātiṣācaḥ śam naḥ divyāḥ pārthivāḥ śam naḥ apyāḥ /
analyzed: śam naḥ devāḥ viśva devāḥ bhavantu śam sarasvatī saha dhībhiḥ astu  / śam abhiṣācaḥ śam u rātiṣācaḥ śam naḥ divyāḥ pārthivāḥ śam naḥ apyāḥ  /
translated: May the All-Gods, the Gods, be kind and gracious: with their own thoughts may Sarasvatî be gracious. May the Bestowers of wealth and gifts be gracious: gracious to us be the Celestial, Terrestrial, and the Waters' Gods.

original: śam naḥ ajaḥ ekapād devaḥ astu śam ahiḥ budhnyaḥ śam samudraḥ / śam naḥ apām napāt peruḥ astu śam naḥ pṛṣṇiḥ bhavatu deva gopā /
analyzed: śam naḥ ajaḥ ekapād devaḥ astu śam ahiḥ budhnyaḥ śam samudraḥ   śam naḥ apām napāt peruḥ astu śam naḥ pṛṣṇiḥ bhavatu deva gopā  /
translated: Gracious to us be the God Aja-Ekapad, gracious the Dragon of the Deep, gracious the Ocean. Gracious to us be the far-spreading Son of Waters: gracious to us be Prithivî, the Goddess, the Guardian.

original: ādityāḥ rudrāḥ vasavaḥ juṣantām idam brahma kriyamāṇam navīyaḥ / sṛṇvantu naḥ divyāḥ pārthivāsaḥ go jātāḥ uta ye yajñiyāsaḥ /
analyzed: ādityāḥ rudrāḥ vasavaḥ juṣantām idam brahma kriyamāṇam navīyaḥ   sṛṇvantu naḥ divyāḥ pārthivāsaḥ go jātāḥ uta ye yajñiyāsaḥ  /
translated: May the Âdityas, Rudras, Vasus accept this newest prayer of ours. May the Celestial, the Earth's, and those born of the Cow, who are to be adored, hear us.

original: ye devānām ṛtvijaḥ yajñiyāsaḥ manoḥ yajatrāḥ amṛtāḥ ṛta jñāḥ / te naḥ rāsantām uru gāyam adya yūyam pāta svastibhiḥ sadā naḥ /
analyzed: ye devānām ṛtvijaḥ yajñiyāsaḥ manoḥ yajatrāḥ amṛtāḥ ṛta jñāḥ   te naḥ rāsantām uru gāyam adya yūyam pāta svastibhiḥ sadā naḥ  /
translated: May the divine priests of the gods, worthy of sacrifice, who are consecrated by Manu, immortal, knowing truth, grant us wide pasture today. Protect us ever with your blessings.

original: tat astu mitrāvaruṇā tat agne śam yos asmabhyam idam astu śastam / aśīmahi gādham uta pratiṣṭhām namaḥ dive bṛhate sādanāya /
analyzed: tat astu mitrāvaruṇā tat agne śam yos asmabhyam idam astu śastam   aśīmahi gādham uta pratiṣṭhām namaḥ dive bṛhate sādanāya  /
translated: Let that be so, O Mitra-Varuṇa, O Agni, let that be for our welfare and blessing. May we attain the ford and the firm ground. Homage to the lofty heaven, the seat of all.

original: uṣāḥ apa svasuḥ tamaḥ sam vartayati vartanim su jāta tā / ayā vājam deva hitam sanema madema śata himāḥ su vīrāḥ /
analyzed: uṣāḥ apa svasuḥ tamaḥ sam vartayati vartanim su jāta tā    ayā vājam deva hitam sanema madema śata himāḥ su vīrāḥ  /
translated: Dawn removes the darkness of her sister, and sets her on the path of the well-born. May we win the prize bestowed by the gods. May we rejoice a hundred winters with brave sons.

original: indrasya bāhū sthavirau vṛṣāṇau citrāḥ imāḥ vṛṣabhau pārayiṣṇū / tau yokṣe prathamaḥ yogaḥ āgate yābhyām jitam asurāṇām svar yat /
analyzed: indrasya bāhū sthavirau vṛṣāṇau citrāḥ imāḥ vṛṣabhau pārayiṣṇū   tau yokṣe prathamaḥ yogaḥ āgate yābhyām jitam asurāṇām svar yat  /
translated: The two mighty arms of Indra are the two bulls, these two variegated bulls that save. I yoke them, the first yoke, when the yoke comes, by which the heaven of the Asuras was conquered.

original: āśuḥ śiśānaḥ vṛṣabhaḥ na bhīmaḥ ghanāghanaḥ kṣobhaṇaḥ carṣaṇīnām / saṃkrandanaḥ animiṣaḥ eka vīraḥ śatam senāḥ ajayat sākam indraḥ /
analyzed: āśuḥ śiśānaḥ vṛṣabhaḥ na bhīmaḥ ghanāghanaḥ kṣobhaṇaḥ carṣaṇīnām    saṃkrandanaḥ animiṣaḥ eka vīraḥ śatam senāḥ ajayat sākam indraḥ  /
translated: Swift, sharpened, terrible as a bull, the crusher of the strong, the agitator of men, the roaring, the watchful, the single hero, Indra with them conquered a hundred armies at once.

original: saṃkrandanena animiṣeṇa jiṣṇunā āyodhyena duścyavanena dhṛṣṇunā / tat indreṇa jayata tat sahadhvam yudhaḥ naraḥ iṣu hastena vṛṣṇā /
analyzed: saṃkrandanena animiṣeṇa jiṣṇunā āyodhyena duścyavanena dhṛṣṇunā     tat indreṇa jayata tat sahadhvam yudhaḥ naraḥ iṣu hastena vṛṣṇā  /
translated: With him who roars and never shuts his eyelids, the Victor, him who fights and conquers, Indra,🔽With him who conquers, Indra, who rules with bowmen and with those who gird their quivers on, who marshals troops,

original: saḥ iṣu hastaiḥ sa niṣaṅgibhiḥ vaśī saṃsraṣṭā sa yudhaḥ indraḥ gaṇena / saṃsṛṣṭa jit soma pāḥ bāhu śardhī ugra dhanvā pratihitābhiḥ astā /
analyzed: saḥ iṣu hastaiḥ sa niṣaṅgibhiḥ vaśī saṃsraṣṭā sa yudhaḥ indraḥ gaṇena    saṃsṛṣṭa jit soma pāḥ bāhu śardhī ugra dhanvā pratihitābhiḥ astā  /
translated: Who conquers in the fight, who drinks the Soma, who waxes strong with arms, who wields a mighty bow, and shoots his arrows to the mark,

original: bala vijñāyaḥ sthaviraḥ pravīraḥ sahasvān vājī sahamānaḥ ugraḥ / abhivīraḥ abhiṣatvā sahaḥ jit jaitram indra ratham ā tiṣṭha go vidam /
analyzed: bala vijñāyaḥ sthaviraḥ pravīraḥ sahasvān vājī sahamānaḥ ugraḥ    abhivīraḥ abhiṣatvā sahaḥ jit jaitram indra ratham ā tiṣṭha go vidam  /
translated: The mighty, the heroic, the victorious, the strong, the conquering, the powerful, the bold, the conqueror of men, the winner of the spoil, O Indra, mount thy conquering car that finds the kine.🔽Rejoice in this your hero, in the mighty Indra, O ye friends, be ye allied with him.

original: imam vīram anu harṣadhvam ugram indram sakhāyaḥ anu sam rabhadhvam / grāma jitam go jitam vajra bāhum jayantam ajma pramṛṇantam ojasā /
analyzed: imam vīram anu harṣadhvam ugram indram sakhāyaḥ anu sam rabhadhvam    grāma jitam go jitam vajra bāhum jayantam ajma pramṛṇantam ojasā  /
translated: The conqueror of villages and cattle, the wielder of the thunderbolt, the victor, the crusher of the foe with might,🔽Indra who with his might assails the cow-stalls, the fierce, the hundred-hated, the spoiler,

original: abhi gotrāṇi sahasā gāhamānaḥ adāyaḥ ugraḥ śatamanyuḥ indraḥ / duścyavanaḥ pṛtanāṣāh ayodhyaḥ asmākam senāḥ avatu pra yutsu //
analyzed: abhi gotrāṇi sahasā gāhamānaḥ adāyaḥ ugraḥ śatamanyuḥ indraḥ    duścyavanaḥ pṛtanāṣāh ayodhyaḥ asmākam senāḥ avatu pra yutsu  /
translated: Indra who conquers in the war, who fights, who never yields, who guards our armies in the fray.

original: bṛhaspate pari dīya rathena rakṣaḥ hā amitrām apabādhamānaḥ / prabhañjam śatrūn pramṛṇan amitrān asmākam edhi avitā tanūnām /
analyzed: bṛhaspate pari dīya rathena rakṣaḥ hā amitrām apabādhamānaḥ   prabhañjam śatrūn pramṛṇan amitrān asmākam edhi avitā tanūnām  /
translated: O Brihaspati, come hither on thy car, slaying the fiends, repelling our enemies. Breaking our foes, crushing our adversaries, be thou the protector of our bodies.

original: indraḥ eṣām netā bṛhaspatiḥ dakṣiṇā yajñaḥ puras etu somaḥ / deva senānām abhibhañjatīnām jayantīnām marutaḥ yantu madhye /
analyzed: indraḥ eṣām netā bṛhaspatiḥ dakṣiṇā yajñaḥ puras etu somaḥ    deva senānām abhibhañjatīnām jayantīnām marutaḥ yantu madhye  /
translated: Indra their leader, Brihaspati their guide, let the sacrifice go before them, and Soma. In the van of the conquering, overcoming hosts of the gods let the Maruts go.

original: indrasya vṛṣṇaḥ varuṇasya rājñaḥ ādityānām marutām śardhaḥ ugram / mahāmanasām bhuvana cyavānām ghoṣaḥ devānām jayatām ud asthāt /
analyzed: indrasya vṛṣṇaḥ varuṇasya rājñaḥ ādityānām marutām śardhaḥ ugram   mahāmanasām bhuvana cyavānām ghoṣaḥ devānām jayatām ud asthāt  /
translated: The mighty host of Indra, the king Varuna, the Maruts, and the Adityas, the mighty host of the gods of great spirit, who shake the world, the shout of the conquering gods hath arisen.

original: asmākam indraḥ samṛteṣu dhvajeṣu asmākam yāḥ iṣavaḥ tāḥ jayantu / asmākam vīrāḥ uttare bhavantu asmān devāsaḥ avata haveṣu /
analyzed: asmākam indraḥ samṛteṣu dhvajeṣu asmākam yāḥ iṣavaḥ tāḥ jayantu    asmākam vīrāḥ uttare bhavantu asmān devāsaḥ avata haveṣu  /
translated: Let Indra be with us when our banners are victorious. Let our arrows be victorious. Let our heroes be victorious. Help us, O gods, in the battles.

original: idam ucchreyaḥ avasānam āgām śive me dyāvāpṛthivī abhūtām / asapatnāḥ pradiśaḥ me bhavantu na vai tvā dviṣmaḥ abhayam naḥ astu /
analyzed: idam ucchreyaḥ avasānam āgām śive me dyāvāpṛthivī abhūtām    asapatnāḥ pradiśaḥ me bhavantu na vai tvā dviṣmaḥ abhayam naḥ astu  /
translated: I have come to this most excellent abode. May heaven and earth be propitious to me. May the quarters be friendly to me, without foes. We do not hate thee. Let us have peace.

original: yatas indra bhayāmahe tatas naḥ abhayam kṛdhi / maghavam chagdhi tava tvam naḥ ūtibhiḥ vi dviṣaḥ vi mṛdhaḥ jahi //
analyzed: yatas indra bhayāmahe tatas naḥ abhayam kṛdhi   maghavam chagdhi tava tvam naḥ ūtibhiḥ vi dviṣaḥ vi mṛdhaḥ jahi  /
translated: From whatever, Indra, we are afraid, from that make us free from fear. Be gracious, O thou bountiful One, with thy protections: drive away our foes, drive off our enemies.

original: indram vayam anūrādham havāmahe anu rādhyāsma dvipadā catuṣpadā / mā naḥ senāḥ araruṣīḥ upa guḥ viṣūciḥ indra druhaḥ vi nāśaya //
analyzed: indram vayam anūrādham havāmahe anu rādhyāsma dvipadā catuṣpadā    mā naḥ senāḥ araruṣīḥ upa guḥ viṣūciḥ indra druhaḥ vi nāśaya  /
translated: We call on Indra, the bestower of great boons: may he bestow on us bipeds and quadrupeds. Let not the red-spotted arrow reach us: drive thou away, O Indra, the curse and the evil spirit.

original: indraḥ trātā uta vṛtra hā para sphānaḥ vareṇyaḥ / sa rakṣitā caramatas sa madhyatas sa paścāt sa purastāt naḥ astu /
analyzed: indraḥ trātā uta vṛtra hā para sphānaḥ vareṇyaḥ   sa rakṣitā caramatas sa madhyatas sa paścāt sa purastāt naḥ astu  /
translated: Indra is our protector and the Vr̥itra-slayer, the bounteous, the excellent. He is our guardian from behind, from the front, from the side, from the middle.

original: urum naḥ lokam anu neṣi vidvān svar yat jyotiḥ abhayam svasti / ugrā te indra sthavirasya bāhū upa kṣayema śaraṇā bṛhantā /
analyzed: urum naḥ lokam anu neṣi vidvān svar yat jyotiḥ abhayam svasti  / ugrā te indra sthavirasya bāhū upa kṣayema śaraṇā bṛhantā  /
translated: O thou who knowest, lead us to a wide sphere of life, to the light of heaven, to safety, to fearlessness. O Indra, may we dwell in the shadow of thy mighty and lofty arms.

original: abhayam naḥ karati antarikṣam abhayam dyāvāpṛthivī ubhe ime / abhayam paścāt abhayam purastāt uttarāt adharāt abhayam naḥ astu /
analyzed: abhayam naḥ karati antarikṣam abhayam dyāvāpṛthivī ubhe ime   abhayam paścāt abhayam purastāt uttarāt adharāt abhayam naḥ astu  /
translated: The atmosphere gives us security: secure are these two worlds, the earth and heaven. Secure be the region behind us, secure in front, secure from above, secure from below.

original: abhayam mitrāt abhayam amitrāt abhayam jñātāt abhayam puras yaḥ / abhayam naktam abhayam divā naḥ sarvāḥ āśāḥ mama mitram bhavantu //🔽asapatnam purastāt paścāt naḥ abhayam kṛtam / savitā mā dakṣiṇatas uttarāt mā śacīpatiḥ /
analyzed: abhayam mitrāt abhayam amitrāt abhayam jñātāt abhayam puras yaḥ    abhayam naktam abhayam divā naḥ sarvāḥ āśāḥ mama mitram bhavantu  / asapatnam purastāt paścāt naḥ abhayam kṛtam   savitā mā dakṣiṇatas uttarāt mā śacīpatiḥ  /
translated: From the rear, from the right, from the left, from the nadir, from the zenith,🔽From the east, from the south, from the west, from the north, from all sides,🔽From the east may the Adityas protect me, from the south may the Maruts protect me,

original: divaḥ me ādityāḥ rakṣatu bhūmyāḥ rakṣantu agnayaḥ / indra agnī rakṣatām mā purastāt aśvinau abhitas śarma yacchatām / tiraścīn aghnyā rakṣatu jātavedāḥ bhūta kṛtaḥ me sarvatas santu varma /
analyzed: divaḥ me ādityāḥ rakṣatu bhūmyāḥ rakṣantu agnayaḥ   indra agnī rakṣatām mā purastāt aśvinau abhitas śarma yacchatām   tiraścīn aghnyā rakṣatu jātavedāḥ bhūta kṛtaḥ me sarvatas santu varma  /
translated: From the west may the Rudras protect me, from the north may the Vasus protect me, from below may the Sadhyas protect me, from above may the All-gods protect me.

original: agniḥ mā pātu vasubhiḥ purastāt tasmin krame tasmim śraye tām puram praimi / sa mā rakṣatu sa mā gopāyatu tasmai ātmānam pari dade svāhā /
analyzed: agniḥ mā pātu vasubhiḥ purastāt tasmin krame tasmim śraye tām puram praimi   sa mā rakṣatu sa mā gopāyatu tasmai ātmānam pari dade svāhā  /
translated: May Agni protect me from the east with the Vasus, in that step, in that abode, I enter that city. May he protect me, may he guard me. To him I give myself, hail!🔽May Vayu protect me from the south with the Maruts, in that step, in that abode, I enter that city. May he protect me, may he guard me. To him I give myself, hail!🔽May Indra protect me from the west with the Rudras, in that step, in that abode, I enter that city. May he protect me, may he guard me. To him I give myself, hail!

original: vāyuḥ mā antarikṣeṇa etasyāḥ diśaḥ pātu tasmin krame tasmim śraye tām puram praimi / sa mā rakṣatu sa mā gopāyatu tasmai ātmānam pari dade svāhā /
analyzed: vāyuḥ mā antarikṣeṇa etasyāḥ diśaḥ pātu tasmin krame tasmim śraye tām puram praimi   sa mā rakṣatu sa mā gopāyatu tasmai ātmānam pari dade svāhā  /
translated: May Soma protect me from the north with the Visve Devas, in that step, in that abode, I enter that city. May he protect me, may he guard me. To him I give myself, hail!

original: somaḥ mā rudraiḥ dakṣiṇāyāḥ diśaḥ pātu tasmin krame tasmim śraye tām puram praimi / sa mā rakṣatu sa mā gopāyatu tasmai ātmānam pari dade svāhā /
analyzed: somaḥ mā rudraiḥ dakṣiṇāyāḥ diśaḥ pātu tasmin krame tasmin śraye tām puram praimi   sa mā rakṣatu sa mā gopāyatu tasmai ātmānam pari dade svāhā  /
translated: May Soma, with the Rudras, protect me from the southern region. In that course, in that shelter, I enter that fortress. May he protect me, may he guard me. To him I give myself, All-hail!

original: varuṇaḥ mā ādityaiḥ etasyāḥ diśaḥ pātu tasmin krame tasmim śraye tām puram praimi / sa mā rakṣatu sa mā gopāyatu tasmai ātmānam pari dade svāhā /
analyzed: varuṇaḥ mā ādityaiḥ etasyāḥ diśaḥ pātu tasmin krame tasmim śraye tām puram praimi   sa mā rakṣatu sa mā gopāyatu tasmai ātmānam pari dade svāhā  /
translated: May Varuna, with the Adityas, protect me from this region. In that course, in that shelter, I enter that fortress. May he protect me, may he guard me. To him I give myself, All-hail!

original: sūryaḥ mā dyāvāpṛthivībhyām pratīcyāḥ diśaḥ pātu tasmin krame tasmim śraye tām puram praimi / sa mā rakṣatu sa mā gopāyatu tasmai ātmānam pari dade svāhā /
analyzed: sūryaḥ mā dyāvāpṛthivībhyām pratīcyāḥ diśaḥ pātu tasmin krame tasmim śraye tām puram praimi   sa mā rakṣatu sa mā gopāyatu tasmai ātmānam pari dade svāhā  /
translated: May Surya, with Heaven and Earth, protect me from the western region. In that course, in that shelter, I enter that fortress. May he protect me, may he guard me. To him I give myself, All-hail!

original: āpaḥ mā oṣadhīmatīḥ etasyāḥ diśaḥ pāntu tāsu krame tāsu śraye tām puram praimi / tāḥ mā rakṣantu tāḥ mā gopāyantu tābhyaḥ ātmānam pari dade svāhā /
analyzed: āpaḥ mā oṣadhīmatīḥ etasyāḥ diśaḥ pāntu tāsu krame tāsu śraye tām puram praimi   tāḥ mā rakṣantu tāḥ mā gopāyantu tābhyaḥ ātmānam pari dade svāhā  /
translated: May the Waters, with the Plants, protect me from this region. In them may I find a course, in them a shelter, I enter that fortress. May they protect me, may they guard me. To them I give myself, All-hail!

original: viśvakarmā mā sapta ṛṣibhiḥ udīcyāḥ diśaḥ pātu tasmin krame tasmim śraye tām puram praimi / sa mā rakṣatu sa mā gopāyatu tasmai ātmānam pari dade svāhā /
analyzed: viśvakarmā mā sapta ṛṣibhiḥ udīcyāḥ diśaḥ pātu tasmin krame tasmim śraye tām puram praimi   sa mā rakṣatu sa mā gopāyatu tasmai ātmānam pari dade svāhā  /
translated: May Visvakarman, with the seven Rishis, protect me from the northern region. In that course, in that shelter, I enter that city. May he protect me, may he guard me. To him I give myself up. All hail!

original: indraḥ mā marutvān etasyāḥ diśaḥ pātu tasmin krame tasmim śraye tām puram praimi / sa mā rakṣatu sa mā gopāyatu tasmai ātmānam pari dade svāhā /🔽prajāpatiḥ mā prajananavān saha pratiṣṭhayā dhruvāyāḥ diśaḥ pātu tasmin krame tasmim śraye tām puram praimi / sa mā rakṣatu sa mā gopāyatu tasmai ātmānam pari dade svāhā /
analyzed: indraḥ mā marutvān etasyāḥ diśaḥ pātu tasmin krame tasmim śraye tām puram praimi   sa mā rakṣatu sa mā gopāyatu tasmai ātmānam pari dade svāhā  / prajāpatiḥ mā prajananavān saha pratiṣṭhayā dhruvāyāḥ diśaḥ pātu tasmin krame tasmim śraye tām puram praimi   sa mā rakṣatu sa mā gopāyatu tasmai ātmānam pari dade svāhā  /
translated: May Indra, with the Maruts, protect me from this region. In that course, in that shelter, I enter that city. May he protect me, may he guard me. To him I give myself up. All hail!🔽May Prajapati, with offspring and with the firm foundation, protect me from the firm region. In that course, in that shelter, I enter that city. May he protect me, may he guard me. To him I give myself up. All hail!

original: bṛhaspatiḥ mā viśvaiḥ devaiḥ ūrdhvāyāḥ diśaḥ pātu tasmin krame tasmim śraye tām puram praimi / sa mā rakṣatu sa mā gopāyatu tasmai ātmānam pari dade svāhā /
analyzed: bṛhaspatiḥ mā viśvaiḥ devaiḥ ūrdhvāyāḥ diśaḥ pātu tasmin krame tasmim śraye tām puram praimi   sa mā rakṣatu sa mā gopāyatu tasmai ātmānam pari dade svāhā  /
translated: May Brihaspati, with all the gods, protect me from the upward region. In that course, in that shelter, I enter that city. May he protect me, may he guard me. To him I give myself up. All hail!

original: agnim te vasuvantam ṛchantu / ye māghāyavaḥ prācyāḥ diśaḥ abhidāsān /
analyzed: agnim te vasuvantam ṛchantu   ye māghāyavaḥ prācyāḥ diśaḥ abhidāsān  /
translated: Let the Vasus come to thee, O Agni, who hateth me and whom I hate.

original: vāyum te antarikṣavantam ṛchantu / ye māghāyavaḥ etasyāḥ diśaḥ abhidāsān /
analyzed: vāyum te antarikṣavantam ṛchantu   ye māghāyavaḥ etasyāḥ diśaḥ abhidāsān  /
translated: Let the winds, with the atmosphere, overtake the sorcerers who hate me from this quarter.

original: somam te rudravantam ṛchantu / ye māghāyavaḥ dakṣiṇāyāḥ diśaḥ abhidāsān /
analyzed: somam te rudravantam ṛchantu   ye māghāyavaḥ dakṣiṇāyāḥ diśaḥ abhidāsān  /
translated: Let the moon, with Rudra, overtake the sorcerers who hate me from the southern quarter.

original: varuṇam te ādityavantam ṛchantu / ye māghāyavaḥ etasyāḥ diśaḥ abhidāsān /🔽sūryam te dyāvāpṛthivīvantam ṛchantu / ye māghāyava pratīcyāḥ diśaḥ abhidāsān /

analyzed: apaḥ te oṣadhīmatīḥ ṛchantu   ye māghāyavaḥ etasyāḥ diśaḥ abhidāsān  /
translated: Let the waters, with the plants, overtake the sorcerers who hate me from this quarter.

original: viśvakarmāṇam te sapta ṛṣivantam ṛchantu / ye māghāyavaḥ udīcyāḥ diśaḥ abhidāsān /
analyzed: viśvakarmāṇam te sapta ṛṣivantam ṛchantu   ye māghāyavaḥ udīcyāḥ diśaḥ abhidāsān  /
translated: Let the seven Rishis, with Vishvakarman, overtake the sorcerers who hate me from the northern quarter.

original: indram te marutvantam ṛchantu / ye māghāyavaḥ etasyāḥ diśaḥ abhidāsān /🔽prajāpatim te prajananavantam ṛchantu / ye māghāyavaḥ dhruvāyāḥ diśaḥ abhidāsān /
analyzed: indram te marutvantam ṛchantu   ye māghāyavaḥ etasyāḥ diśaḥ abhidāsān  / prajāpatim te prajananavantam ṛchantu   ye māghāyavaḥ dhruvāyāḥ diśaḥ abhidāsān  /

original: bṛhaspatim te viśvadevavantam ṛchantu / ye māghāyavaḥ ūrdhvāyāḥ diśaḥ abhidāsān /
analyzed: bṛhaspatim te viśvadevavantam ṛchantu   ye māghāyavaḥ ūrdhvāyāḥ diśaḥ abhidāsān  /
translated: Let Brihaspati, with the All-gods, overtake the sorcerers who hate me from the upper quarter.

original: mitraḥ pṛthivyāḥ ud akrāmat tām puram pra nayāmi vaḥ / tām ā viśata tām pra viśata sā vaḥ śarma ca varma ca yacchatu //
analyzed: mitraḥ pṛthivyāḥ ud akrāmat tām puram pra nayāmi vaḥ   tām ā viśata tām pra viśata sā vaḥ śarma ca varma ca yacchatu  /
translated: Mitra hath mounted up from the earth: that fortress I lead you to. Enter it, enter it, and let it give you shelter and protection.

original: vāyuḥ antarikṣeṇa ud akrāmat tām puram pra nayāmi vaḥ / tām ā viśata tām pra viśata sā vaḥ śarma ca varma ca yacchatu //🔽sūryaḥ divā ud akrāmat tām puram pra nayāmi vaḥ / tām ā viśata tām pra viśata sā vaḥ śarma ca varma ca yacchatu //
analyzed: vāyuḥ antarikṣeṇa ud akrāmat tām puram pra nayāmi vaḥ   tām ā viśata tām pra viśata sā vaḥ śarma ca varma ca yacchatu  / sūryaḥ divā ud akrāmat tām puram pra nayāmi vaḥ   tām ā viśata tām pra viśata sā vaḥ śarma ca varma ca yacchatu  /

original: candramāḥ nakṣatraiḥ ud akrāmat tām puram pra nayāmi vaḥ / tām ā viśata tām pra viśata sā vaḥ śarma ca varma ca yacchatu //

translated: With the people Prajapati went forth. I lead you to that city. Enter it, enter it. May it give you protection and defence.🔽They have removed the human weapon which Indra and Agni, Dhatr, Savitar, Brihaspati,

original: apa nyadhuḥ pauruṣeyam vadham yam indra agnī dhātā savitā bṛhaspatiḥ / somaḥ rājā varuṇaḥ aśvinā yamaḥ pūṣā asmān pari pātu mṛtyoḥ /
analyzed: apa nyadhuḥ pauruṣeyam vadham yam indra agnī dhātā savitā bṛhaspatiḥ    somaḥ rājā varuṇaḥ aśvinā yamaḥ pūṣā asmān pari pātu mṛtyoḥ  /
translated: King Soma, Varuna, the Asvins, Yama, and Pusha have made. May they all protect us from death.🔽Those which the lord of the world, the creator of beings, the wind, made for the people,

original: yāni cakāra bhuvanasya yaḥ patiḥ prajāpatiḥ mātariśvā prajābhyaḥ / pradiśaḥ yāni vasate diśaḥ ca tāni me varmāṇi bahulāni santu /

translated: and those which he assigns to the quarters and the intermediate quarters, may they be for me manyfold protections.🔽The divine bodies which the gods, the lords of light, the embodied ones, have put on,

translated: The Brahman is the eldest: in the Brahman are stored all manly powers. The Brahman first spread out the highest heaven. The Brahman was the first-born of all existing things. Who may contend with him, the Brahman?🔽With that wherewith the Gods have compassed round Savitar God,

analyzed: yena devam savitāram pari devāḥ adhārayan    tena imam brahmaṇas pate pari rāṣṭrāya dhattana  / pari imam indram āyuṣe mahe kṣatrāya dhattana   yathā enam jarase nayāt jyok kṣatre adhi jāgarat  /
translated: With that, O Brahmanaspati, compass thou this one about for sovereignty.🔽For mighty power and lengthened life compass ye round this Indra. So that he may lead him to old age, so that he may watch over him in the race of kings.

original: pari imam indram āyuṣe mahe śrotrāya dhattana / yathā enam jarase nayāt jyok śrotre adhi jāgarat //
analyzed: pari imam indram āyuṣe mahe śrotrāya dhattana   yathā enam jarase nayāt jyok śrotre adhi jāgarat  /
translated: For mighty power and lengthened life compass ye round this Indra. So that he may lead him to old age, so that he may watch over him in the race of kings.

original: pari dhatta dhatta naḥ varcasā imam jarā mṛtyum kṛṇuta dīrgham āyuḥ / bṛhaspatiḥ prāyacchat vāsaḥ etat somāya rājñe paridhātavai u //
analyzed: pari dhatta dhatta naḥ varcasā imam jarā mṛtyum kṛṇuta dīrgham āyuḥ   bṛhaspatiḥ prāyacchat vāsaḥ etat somāya rājñe paridhātavai u
translated: Invest him with this robe, O Brahmanaspati, make his life long, free from old age and death. Brihaspati hath given this robe to be worn by King Soma.

original: jarām su gaccha pari dhatsva vāsaḥ bhava gṛṣṭīnām abhiśasti pāḥ u / śatam ca jīva śaradaḥ purūcī rāyaḥ ca poṣam upasaṃvyayasva //
analyzed: jarām su gaccha pari dhatsva vāsaḥ bhava gṛṣṭīnām abhiśasti pāḥ u  śatam ca jīva śaradaḥ purūcī rāyaḥ ca poṣam upasaṃvyayasva  /
translated: Go to old age, put on the robe. Be thou a refuge from the curse of those who rub. Live a hundred winters yet, and to the end of life enjoy prosperity.

original: pari idam vāsaḥ adhithāḥ svastaye abhūḥ vāpīnām abhiśasti pāḥ u / śatam ca jīva śaradaḥ purūcīḥ vasūni cāruḥ vi bhajāsi jīvan /
analyzed: pari idam vāsaḥ adhithāḥ svastaye abhūḥ vāpīnām abhiśasti pāḥ u  śatam ca jīva śaradaḥ purūcīḥ vasūni cāruḥ vi bhajāsi jīvan  /
translated: Thou hast put on this robe for happiness: thou hast become the guard of the waters from the curse. Live a hundred winters yet, and, lovely, distribute among the living treasures manifold.

original: yoge yoge tavastaram vājevāje havāmahe / sakhāyaḥ indram ūtaye /
analyzed: yoge yoge tavastaram vājevāje havāmahe    sakhāyaḥ indram ūtaye
translated: In every need we call on Indra for our help, in every fight we call on him, O friends, for aid.

original: hiraṇya varṇaḥ ajaraḥ su vīraḥ jarā mṛtyuḥ prajayā sam viśasva / tat agniḥ āha tat u somaḥ āha bṛhaspatiḥ savitā tat indraḥ /
